WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: carpal tunnel syndrome from repetitive wrist/keyboard use (median nerve compression), not primary hypothyroidism.

Reasoning: bilateral hand paresthesias that worsen by the end of work days and improve on days off are classic for repetitive strain/median nerve compression at the wrist. Young age and the clear temporal relation to work point to mechanical compression. Type 1 diabetes and hypothyroidism can predispose to carpal tunnel, but hypothyroidism would usually produce other systemic signs (fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation) and symptoms would not be so tightly tied to work activity. Next steps: perform Phalen/Tinel exam, consider nerve conduction studies, try wrist splints/ergonomic changes; check thyroid function and glycemic control as part of evaluation.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: carpal tunnel syndrome from repetitive wrist/keyboard use (median nerve compression).

Reasoning: bilateral hand paresthesias that worsen by the end of the workday and remit on days off strongly point to an overuse entrapment neuropathy of the median nerve at the wrist. Diabetic neuropathy is unlikely after only 2 years of type 1 diabetes and typically begins in the feet as a symmetric distal "stocking‑glove" neuropathy. Pregnancy-related or endocrine causes (e.g., hypothyroidism) are less likely given a negative pregnancy test and the clear temporal relation to work activity.
WRONG

Reasoning: symptoms are activity-related (worse by end of workday, improve on days off) and in both hands — classic for repetitive strain/median nerve entrapment. Diabetic neuropathy is unlikely after only 2 years and would be more chronic and length-dependent; pregnancy is excluded. (Hypothyroidism can predispose to CTS, but the work-related pattern points to repetitive median nerve compression.)
WRONG
Most likely cause: carpal tunnel syndrome (median nerve compression) from repetitive wrist use.

Reasoning: bilateral hand tingling worse by the end of the workday and relieved on days off is classic for a work‑related entrapment neuropathy in a typist. Diabetic peripheral neuropathy is usually a symmetric, persistent distal “glove‑and‑stocking” loss that develops after longer disease duration; hypothyroidism can cause carpal tunnel but would typically have systemic features and wouldn’t classically fluctuate with work activity. You can confirm with Tinel/Phalen maneuvers and nerve conduction studies.

Management is warm compresses and topical antibiotic ointment; incision/drainage if persistent.

No — the most likely diagnosis is herpes simplex keratitis (dendritic corneal ulcer). WRONG
Acute dacryocystitis from nasolacrimal duct obstruction.

Reasoning: A week of worsening unilateral eye pain with a focal tender, erythematous swelling at the medial canthus (over the lacrimal sac) and low‑grade fever is classic for infection of the lacrimal sac secondary to nasolacrimal duct obstruction. Lack of vision change or pain with extraocular movement argues against orbital cellulitis; the anatomic location distinguishes dacryocystitis from preseptal cellulitis.
WRONG
An isolated lateral ankle sprain — rupture of the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL). The plantarflexion/inversion mechanism and positive anterior drawer with a negative talar tilt point to ATFL injury (no malleolar fracture).
CORRECT
Most likely an isolated anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) sprain (common lateral ankle sprain), not a deltoid ligament injury.

Reasoning: plantarflexion + inversion is the classic mechanism for ATFL injury; a positive anterior drawer test localizes instability to the ATFL, while a negative talar-tilt makes CFL involvement unlikely. A deltoid (medial) ligament sprain would result from eversion, not inversion.
CORRECT
Most likely an isolated anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) sprain — probably a partial-to-complete ATFL tear.

Reason: classic plantarflexion + inversion mechanism injures the ATFL first; a positive anterior‑drawer test specifically localizes laxity to the ATFL, while a negative talar‑tilt test argues the calcaneofibular ligament is intact. Lack of malleolar point tenderness makes fracture unlikely.
CORRECT
Yes — an isolated anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) sprain, likely grade I–II. Plantarflexion + inversion is the classic mechanism for ATFL injury; a positive anterior drawer test localizes instability to the ATFL, while a negative talar tilt implies the calcaneofibular ligament is intact. No malleolar point tenderness argues against fracture.
CORRECT
Most likely: anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) sprain.

Reasoning: plantarflexion + inversion is the classic mechanism for ATFL injury; a positive anterior drawer indicates ATFL laxity (it resists anterior talar translation in plantarflexion); a negative talar-tilt suggests the calcaneofibular ligament is intact. Deltoid (medial) ligament sprains occur with eversion and produce medial pain/tenderness, which are not present here.
CORRECT
Sigmoid volvulus — twisting of a redundant sigmoid colon causing large-bowel obstruction (classical “coffee‑bean”–shaped, massively dilated colon on abdominal x‑ray).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: sigmoid volvulus.

Reasoning: Older patient with chronic constipation and laxative use, progressive abdominal distention and colicky lower‑abdominal pain with faint bowel sounds, and the plain abdominal film classically shows a massively dilated, U‑shaped/“coffee‑bean” loop of sigmoid colon. Infectious colitis typically causes fever and diarrhea and does not produce this pattern of large‑bowel obstruction.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: sigmoid volvulus.

Reasoning: A 62-year-old with chronic constipation on laxatives, acute colicky lower‑abdominal pain and marked distension is a classic presentation of sigmoid volvulus. The plain abdominal film classically shows a massively dilated, U‑ or coffee‑bean–shaped loop of colon with loss of gas in the distal colon, consistent with a twisted sigmoid causing large‑bowel obstruction. This differs from small‑bowel obstruction (central multiple air‑fluid levels), fecal impaction (large stool burden without the single, massively dilated loop/coffee‑bean configuration), and acute colonic pseudo‑obstruction (Ogilvie) which typically occurs in very sick or postoperative patients with more diffuse colonic dilatation.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: sigmoid volvulus.

Reason: elderly patient with chronic constipation and laxative use, acute progressive abdominal distension and colicky pain, and the abdominal radiograph classically shows a massively dilated inverted U–shaped/coffee‑bean large-bowel loop directed toward the right upper quadrant with loss of gas distally — the typical appearance of sigmoid volvulus.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: sigmoid volvulus.

Reason: elderly patient with chronic constipation and sudden colicky lower abdominal pain and marked distension suggests large‑bowel obstruction. The abdominal x‑ray in this setting typically shows a single, massively dilated sigmoid loop (the “coffee‑bean”/inverted‑U sign) consistent with volvulus. Infectious colitis would usually cause fever, frequent bloody/watery diarrhea and mucosal inflammation rather than a radiographic obstructive pattern and gross colonic distension.
CORRECT
Aromatase deficiency (CYP19A1 mutation) — 46,XX virilized female with maternal virilization in pregnancy, lack of estrogen (absent breast development, tall stature, osteoporosis/fractures), hyperandrogenic signs (acne, clitoromegaly), and multicystic ovaries.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Aromatase deficiency (placental aromatase defect).

Reasoning: Maternal virilization during pregnancy plus a virilized 46,XX newborn strongly suggests fetal/placental inability to convert androgens to estrogens. The patient’s primary amenorrhea with absent breast development, tall stature and early osteoporotic fractures reflect estrogen deficiency, and the multicystic ovaries and severe acne reflect excess androgens — all classic for aromatase deficiency (not typical for classic CAH, which does not usually cause maternal virilization).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: aromatase (placental) deficiency.

Reasoning: maternal virilization during pregnancy plus a 46,XX child with ambiguous genitalia at birth, progressive virilization and severe acne, lack of breast development (no estrogen effect), tall stature and early fractures from failure of estrogen‑mediated epiphyseal closure/osteopenia, and polycystic ovaries with a normal uterus are classic for aromatase deficiency. Other diagnoses (complete AIS, 5α‑reductase deficiency, or classic CAH) are inconsistent with the maternal virilization, presence of a uterus/ovaries, and the pattern of absent estrogen effects.
CORRECT
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is aromatase deficiency (placental aromatase deficiency).

Reasoning: maternal virilization during pregnancy + newborn virilization (labial fusion, clitoromegaly) indicates excess fetal/placental androgens that were not converted to estrogens. The patient’s high stature, osteoporosis with low-trauma fractures, and absent breast development (Tanner I) reflect estrogen deficiency. Persistent hyperandrogenism explains severe acne and polycystic-appearing ovaries; labs would show low estrogens with markedly elevated androgens and secondary ↑ gonadotropins. Other diagnoses (eg, CAH, androgen insensitivity, 5α‑reductase deficiency) do not fit the combination of maternal virilization plus lack of breast development and osteopenia.
CORRECT
Aromatase deficiency.

Reasoning: Maternal virilization during pregnancy (mother had new hirsutism) indicates fetal/placental androgen excess that was not converted to estrogens by the placenta — classic for aromatase deficiency. The patient’s ambiguous genitalia at birth, lack of breast development (Tanner I) despite functioning ovaries/uterus, tall stature with osteoporosis/fragility fractures, and hyperandrogenic signs (acne, ovarian cysts) are all explained by inability to make estrogens from androgens. In contrast, congenital adrenal hyperplasia would virilize the female fetus but ordinarily does not cause maternal virilization and typically allows breast development at puberty.

Alternate diagnoses (ischemic stroke, SAH, acute-angle–closure glaucoma, temporal arteritis) are less consistent with the exam and findings.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: hypertensive emergency (malignant hypertension) causing papilledema.

Reasoning: she has severely elevated BP (185/110) with acute diffuse headache, nausea/vomiting, bilateral blurring of optic disc margins (papilledema) and proteinuria — findings consistent with acute end‑organ damage from malignant hypertension. Giant cell arteritis more typically causes new focal/temporal headache in older adults, elevated ESR/CRP, systemic symptoms, and usually sudden monocular ischemic optic neuropathy (not bilateral papilledema); those features and inflammatory markers are not present here.

Reason: The combination of hemoptysis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane is classic for anti‑GBM disease. Microscopic polyangiitis is pauci‑immune (typically ANCA positive) and would not show linear IgG deposition.

Reasoning: The combination of hemoptysis with bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (hematuria, RBC casts, rising creatinine) plus renal biopsy showing linear IgG deposition along the GBM is classic for anti‑GBM disease. Other causes (eg, SLE, postinfectious GN, IgA nephropathy, granulomatosis with polyangiitis) produce granular, mesangial, or pauci‑immune patterns rather than a smooth linear IgG staining of the basement membrane.

Yes — the most likely diagnosis is Goodpasture syndrome (anti-GBM disease).

Reason: the patient has hemoptysis with pulmonary infiltrates plus rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RBC casts, rising creatinine), and renal immunofluorescence shows linear IgG along the glomerular basement membrane — the classic finding for anti-GBM disease. CORRECT

CORRECT

Reasoning: a 61‑year‑old with fever, acute constant left‑lower‑quadrant abdominal pain, change in bowel habits (intermittent constipation and recent diarrhea), and localized LLQ tenderness fits sigmoid diverticulitis. Cholecystitis would present with right‑upper‑quadrant/Murphy sign findings rather than isolated LLQ pain. (Confirm with CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast and manage based on severity.)
CORRECT
Most likely acute sigmoid diverticulitis.

Reasoning: Classic presentation for diverticulitis — a 61-year-old with risk factors (age, obesity, low-fiber/high‑fat diet, chronic constipation) who has new, localized left‑lower‑quadrant tenderness plus fever, nausea/vomiting and focal abdominal findings without generalized peritonitis. Focality and fever make generalized gastroenteritis less likely; ischemic colitis usually causes bloody stools and occurs with vascular risk/acute hypotension; gynecologic and ureteral causes are less consistent with this picture. 

Next steps: obtain CBC, CMP, and CT abdomen/pelvis with IV and oral contrast to confirm uncomplicated vs complicated diverticulitis and guide management (outpatient oral antibiotics and bowel rest if uncomplicated; admission/intervention if complicated).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute sigmoid diverticulitis.

Why: classic in a 61‑year‑old with fever and new, constant left‑lower‑quadrant abdominal pain, focal tenderness on exam, and a recent change in bowel habits (intermittent constipation with current nausea/vomiting/diarrhea). The presentation is localized rather than diffuse and lacks peritonitis, which fits uncomplicated diverticulitis.

Key differentials (less likely): gastroenteritis (would be more diffuse and commonly lacks focal LLQ tenderness), ischemic colitis (often bloody stools), small‑bowel obstruction or volvulus (would show distension/obstipation), and gynecologic causes (less likely at this age). 

Next step to confirm: CT abdomen/pelvis with oral and IV contrast (plus CBC) to look for inflammation, abscess, or complication.
CORRECT
Diverticulitis is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: The patient is an older, obese woman with fever, acute onset constant abdominal pain localized to the left lower quadrant, nausea/vomiting and recent change in bowel habits—classic for acute sigmoid diverticulitis. Cholecystitis would classically cause right upper quadrant pain and a positive Murphy sign (or referred right shoulder pain), not isolated LLQ tenderness. Next steps to confirm: CBC (look for leukocytosis), CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast (best test for suspected diverticulitis). If RUQ pathology were still a concern, right‑upper‑quadrant ultrasound and LFTs would be appropriate.
CORRECT
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. In advanced AIDS (CD4 <50) CMV causes painless progressive visual loss with hemorrhagic, fluffy "pizza‑pie/brushfire" retinal lesions on fundus exam; treat with ganciclovir (systemic ± intravitreal).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: CMV retinitis.

Reasoning: In a patient with advanced AIDS (CD4 42), painless progressive visual loss with funduscopic findings of hemorrhagic, granular ("pizza‑pie"/cotton‑wool and hemorrhage) retinal lesions involving central and peripheral retina is classic for CMV retinitis. HSV/VZV can cause necrotizing retinitis but are less common in this setting and often have a different clinical course; CMV is treated with ganciclovir/valganciclovir.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: progressive outer retinal necrosis (PORN) — herpetic necrotizing retinitis (usually VZV/HSV) in advanced AIDS.

Reasoning: He’s profoundly immunosuppressed (CD4 ≪50) and painless vision loss affecting central and peripheral fields. The classic PORN fundus shows multifocal deep, pale/necrotic retinal lesions with little vitritis or retinal hemorrhage and very rapid progression, whereas CMV retinitis typically has fluffy, perivascular “pizza‑pie” hemorrhagic lesions.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: CMV retinitis.

Reasoning: In a patient with AIDS and CD4 <50 who is nonadherent to ART, painless progressive central and peripheral vision loss with fundoscopic “fluffy, yellow‑white” retinal lesions with hemorrhage (the classic “pizza‑pie” appearance) is typical of cytomegalovirus retinitis. Other causes (toxoplasma, HSV/VZV necrotizing retinitis) have different patterns and/or more pain/inflammation; CMV is the most common in this setting. Treatment is systemic antivirals (ganciclovir/valganciclovir).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: CMV retinitis.

Reasoning: In an AIDS patient with CD4 42 who is off therapy, painless subacute loss of central and peripheral vision and the classic fundoscopic appearance (fluffy, granular retinal lesions with scattered hemorrhages — the “pizza‑pie” or hemorrhagic necrotizing retinitis) fit CMV. HSV/VZV cause acute retinal necrosis (ARN) or progressive outer retinal necrosis (PORN); ARN is usually painful with significant anterior uveitis/vitritis, while PORN (seen in very immunocompromised patients) shows rapid confluent deep retinal necrosis with little hemorrhage. CMV is far more common in AIDS patients with CD4 <50. Diagnostic confirmation is by PCR of aqueous/vitreous or clinical appearance; treat CMV with ganciclovir/valganciclovir.
CORRECT
Somatic symptom disorder. 

She has real somatic complaints (hernia, abdominal/ bowel symptoms) but excessive worry and health‑related behaviors (repeated ED/clinic visits, hours/day worrying, persistent concern despite reassurance), consistent with somatic symptom disorder rather than illness‑anxiety disorder.
CORRECT
Most appropriate diagnosis: Illness anxiety disorder (formerly hypochondriasis).

Reasoning: She is preoccupied with having a serious illness (incarcerated bowel) despite medical reassurance, repeatedly seeks care/reevaluation, and spends hours worrying about her health. Her somatic findings are minimal/intermittent and there is no evidence she is intentionally producing symptoms or seeking external gain (which would suggest factitious disorder or malingering). The pattern fits illness anxiety disorder.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Illness anxiety disorder.

Reasoning: Her predominant problem is excessive anxiety and preoccupation with having a serious illness (hernia incarceration/bowels “dying”) despite minimal or no persistent somatic findings and repeated reassurance. She repeatedly seeks reassurance (ED/clinic visits) and spends hours worrying about illness rather than reporting ongoing, distressing somatic symptoms—this pattern fits illness anxiety disorder rather than somatic symptom disorder, which requires prominent, distressing somatic symptoms that drive the excessive thoughts/behaviors. (DSM‑5 duration criterion should be confirmed, but the clinical picture favors illness anxiety disorder.)
WRONG
Somatic symptom disorder.

She has actual somatic complaints (recurrent reducible inguinal swelling, abdominal pain, altered bowel habits) and persistently excessive thoughts, anxiety and health‑seeking behavior about those symptoms despite reassurance. That pattern (distressing somatic symptoms plus disproportionate and persistent worry/behavior) fits somatic symptom disorder rather than illness anxiety disorder, which requires minimal or no somatic symptoms.
CORRECT
No — the most appropriate diagnosis is somatic symptom disorder.  

She has genuine, persistent somatic complaints (abdominal pain/inguinal swelling) with excessive anxiety and health‑focused behaviors (hours of worry, frequent clinic/ED visits) rather than evidence of intentional symptom fabrication. Factitious disorder requires clear deception and purposeful production of symptoms to assume the sick role, which is not supported here; illness anxiety disorder would be considered only if somatic symptoms were absent or minimal.
CORRECT
The myocardial lesion most likely represents contraction‑band (catecholamine) necrosis caused by a massive adrenergic surge (and reperfusion/CPR). Intense sympathetic stimulation → Ca2+ overload and hypercontraction of myofibers with sarcolemmal rupture → focal hemorrhagic, hypercontracted (contraction‑band) lesions.
WRONG
Conclusion: Senile (degenerative) calcific aortic stenosis.

Reasoning: In an elderly patient this produces calcific nodules on the aortic cusps with a stiff, narrowed valve → chronic pressure overload of the left ventricle and marked concentric LV hypertrophy (small cavity, thick wall) on gross exam. The age, typical valve calcification (without commissural fusion seen in rheumatic disease), and the pattern of hypertrophy fit senile calcific aortic stenosis.
CORRECT
Conclusion: The heart shows concentric left ventricular hypertrophy from long‑standing systemic hypertension — not myocardial amyloid deposition.

Reasoning: In an elderly patient the common gross finding of a thickened, heavy left ventricular wall with a small chamber reflects chronic pressure overload (long‑standing hypertension) causing concentric hypertrophy. Amyloid infiltration produces a firm, waxy myocardium with pale, amorphous deposits (restrictive cardiomyopathy) and would be distinguished histologically (Congo red apple‑green birefringence). The clinical context and typical gross appearance favor hypertrophy from hypertension.
WRONG
No — the heart finding is best explained by contraction-band necrosis from a massive catecholamine surge and/or reperfusion injury (often after trauma and CPR), not amyloid deposition.

Reasoning: severe stress/adrenergic stimulation and reperfusion cause Ca2+ overload and hypercontraction of myocytes producing pale, hypercontracted, often hemorrhagic streaks (contraction-band necrosis) grossly. Amyloid produces a chronic, waxy, pale, stiff myocardium on gross exam and would not fit an acute traumatic/resuscitative setting.
WRONG
You are correct — senile (degenerative) calcific aortic stenosis.

Reason: In an elderly patient the classic gross lesion is heavy, nodular calcification and thickening of the aortic valve cusps (stiff, immobile leaflets) producing concentric left‑ventricular hypertrophy. Cardiac amyloid would produce a pale, firm, thickened (“waxy”) myocardium with restrictive physiology and Congo red positivity, not focal calcified aortic valve cusps.
CORRECT

CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). 

Reason: He has the classic pentad—fever, new neurologic signs, severe thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (Hgb 7 with schistocytes on smear) with normal PT/PTT; this fits ADAMTS13‑mediated TTP rather than ITP. Urgent plasma exchange is indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Babesiosis (Babesia microti infection).

Reasoning: The patient has fever with hemolytic anemia and severe thrombocytopenia but normal coagulation studies, and the peripheral smear shows intraerythrocytic organisms forming tetrads (Maltese‑cross) rather than schistocytes. This constellation fits babesiosis (tick exposure), which can cause fever, hemolysis, thrombocytopenia and CNS symptoms — unlike TTP, the smear here demonstrates parasites in RBCs rather than fragmented RBCs and the mechanism is parasitic hemolysis, not ADAMTS13‑mediated platelet aggregation.
WRONG
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Reason: he has the classic features of TTP — fever, acute neurologic signs, severe thrombocytopenia (20,000), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (Hb 7 with schistocytes on the smear), and normal PT/PTT (helps exclude DIC). This pattern reflects ADAMTS13-mediated platelet-rich microthrombi in small vessels and requires urgent plasma exchange.
CORRECT
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Reasoning: The patient has the classic features of TTP — fever, new neurologic deficits, severe thrombocytopenia (20k), and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (Hb 7.0 with schistocytes on the peripheral smear). Normal PT/PTT argues against DIC. ITP causes isolated immune platelet destruction without schistocytes or hemolytic anemia and would not explain the fever and focal neurologic findings. TTP (often due to ADAMTS13 deficiency) best fits.
CORRECT
Findings are most consistent with a pleural effusion — dullness to percussion, decreased tactile fremitus and breath sounds at the right base. In a patient with chronic kidney disease on dialysis the most likely cause is volume overload/uremic fluid accumulation producing a transudative pleural effusion (can be worsened by inadequate dialysis).
CORRECT
Conclusion: The findings are most consistent with a right-sided pleural effusion—likely from volume overload/inadequate dialysis in a patient with chronic kidney disease, not acute bronchitis.

Reasoning: Dullness to percussion with decreased tactile fremitus and diminished breath sounds localize to pleural fluid. Acute bronchitis produces wheeze/rhonchi with normal percussion and normal or increased fremitus, not a focal dullness. In dialysis patients, volume overload or uremia-related pleuritis commonly causes pleural effusions.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: right-sided pleural effusion — probably from volume overload related to her chronic kidney disease/dialysis.

Reasoning: the physical exam triad for effusion is dullness to percussion + decreased tactile fremitus + decreased breath sounds over the lung base, exactly as described. Consolidation (lobar pneumonia) would increase fremitus and produce bronchial breath sounds/egophony; pneumothorax gives hyperresonance and absent fremitus; pulmonary edema is usually bilateral with crackles. Next steps would be upright chest x‑ray or bedside ultrasound and diagnostic (±therapeutic) thoracentesis.
CORRECT
Most likely a pleural effusion — in a dialysis patient this is commonly from volume overload or uremic/dialysis-associated pleuritis.

Reasoning: the combination of dullness to percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and decreased breath sounds over the right base is classic for fluid in the pleural space. Consolidation (lobar pneumonia) would give dullness with increased fremitus and bronchial breath sounds; pneumothorax gives hyperresonance and absent fremitus. Confirm with chest x‑ray or bedside ultrasound and consider thoracentesis for diagnosis/treatment.
CORRECT
The most likely cause is a pleural effusion (likely a transudative effusion from volume overload/uremic pleuritis related to her chronic kidney disease and dialysis).

Reasoning: localized dullness to percussion with decreased tactile fremitus and diminished breath sounds over the right base are classic for fluid in the pleural space. Acute bronchitis produces diffuse wheeze/rhonchi and usually normal percussion and fremitus (or increased fremitus with lobar consolidation), so the exam favors pleural effusion.
CORRECT

CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

Reasoning: A 4-year-old with a unilateral, smooth, non‑tender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline and new hypertension is classic for Wilms tumor (peak age 2–5). Renal cell carcinoma is far less likely in this age group (usually older children/adults) and neuroblastoma more often crosses the midline and has systemic findings (eg, periorbital ecchymoses, catecholamine‑positive urine).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

Reasoning: A 2–4-year-old with a unilateral, smooth, non‑tender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline plus new-onset hypertension strongly suggests a renal tumor (Wilms) — hypertension is common from tumor production of renin or renal compression. Neuroblastoma more often presents in younger children, with a firm mass that can cross the midline and catecholamine-related findings (eg, ↑VMA/HVA), which are absent here. Normal labs and the clinical exam fit Wilms tumor.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

Reasoning: A 2–5-year-old with a unilateral, smooth, non–midline-crossing abdominal/flank mass and new hypertension fits Wilms tumor. Neuroblastoma is less likely because it often crosses the midline, causes systemic symptoms and catecholamine-related findings, whereas Wilms classically presents as an asymptomatic, unilateral flank mass and can cause HTN from renin secretion.
CORRECT
Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

Reasoning: This child’s presentation—age 2–4 years, a painless, unilateral, smooth abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, and new systemic hypertension—is classic for Wilms tumor. Renal cell carcinoma is very uncommon in preschool children and more typical in adults (often with hematuria or constitutional symptoms). Neuroblastoma often crosses the midline and produces catecholamine-related findings. The history and exam strongly favor Wilms tumor.
CORRECT
Rupture of an atherosclerotic coronary plaque with superimposed thrombus causing acute occlusion of the coronary artery (most likely the LAD producing an anterior ST‑elevation myocardial infarction).
WRONG
The most likely etiology is an acute occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery — an anterior-wall STEMI.

Reasoning: the ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads (anterior leads V1–V4) consistent with anterior wall infarction, and the LAD supplies the anterior wall and septum. An LAD occlusion produces this pattern and elevated troponin.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is most consistent with an acute posterior wall MI from occlusion of the posterior descending artery (most commonly a branch of the right coronary artery), not an LAD occlusion.

Reasoning: the ECG shows ST depression in V1–V3 with tall R waves/upright T waves there — classic reciprocal changes of posterior ST elevation. LAD occlusion produces ST elevation in the anterior precordial leads (V1–V4), which this tracing does not show. In most patients the PDA arises from the RCA, so an RCA occlusion producing a posterior MI is the likeliest etiology.
WRONG
I can’t be sure from the clinical details alone — I need to see the ECG (or a description of which leads show ST-elevation/depression) to localize the infarct and identify the culprit artery.

Reason: infarct localization depends on which leads show ST elevations — anterior leads (V1–V4) indicate LAD, inferior leads (II, III, aVF) indicate RCA (or sometimes LCx), lateral leads (I, aVL, V5–V6) indicate LCx/obtuse marginal, and posterior MI shows ST depression with tall R waves in V1–V2 (posterior wall supplied by RCA or LCx). Please upload the ECG image or tell me which leads have ST changes and I’ll identify the most likely artery.
WRONG
I can’t confidently change the diagnosis without seeing the ECG — please upload the image or tell me which leads have ST elevation. 

Reason: LAD occlusion produces ST elevation in the anterior precordial leads (V1–V4); RCA (inferior MI) produces ST elevation in II, III, and aVF (often III > II) with reciprocal depression in I and aVL and can show right‑ventricular involvement with ST elevation in V4R. Tell me the leads with ST changes and I’ll give a definitive answer.
WRONG

CORRECT

The AST > ALT and elevated GGT support alcohol-related liver injury rather than cholecystitis (which would not produce a markedly elevated lipase).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute alcohol‑induced pancreatitis.

Reasoning: The classic presentation (severe epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, vomiting) in a heavy alcohol user plus a markedly elevated serum lipase (≈800 U/L, well above the usual diagnostic threshold of >3× normal) is diagnostic for acute pancreatitis. The AST>ALT and elevated GGT/alkaline phosphatase reflect chronic alcohol-related liver injury but do not rule out pancreatitis. Alternative diagnoses (acute cholangitis, alcoholic hepatitis, bowel ischemia) are less consistent with the striking lipase elevation and the typical pain pattern.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute pancreatitis — specifically acute alcoholic pancreatitis.

Reasoning: severe epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back with vomiting, a history of heavy alcohol use, and a markedly elevated serum lipase (~800 U/L, well over 3× normal) are diagnostic. The elevated GGT and AST>ALT pattern support alcohol-related liver injury as the likely etiology. Vital signs (fever, tachycardia, borderline hypotension) reflect systemic inflammation.
CORRECT
Acute pancreatitis — most likely alcohol-related. 

Reasoning: Lipase is markedly elevated (~800 U/L), which (>3× normal) is diagnostic when coupled with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and vomiting. The patient’s heavy alcohol history supports alcoholic pancreatitis. Acute cholecystitis usually causes RUQ pain, fever and may only cause mild lipase rise, not this degree.
CORRECT
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis).

Reason: the classic triad of upper airway involvement (epistaxis/chronic sinus/lung infections), pulmonary disease with hemoptysis, and renal involvement with hematuria plus elevated inflammatory markers is most consistent with GPA (typically c-ANCA/PR3 positive).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis).

Reasoning: The combination of upper‑airway disease with epistaxis, lower‑airway hemorrhage (hemoptysis), and renal involvement (recurrent hematuria) with systemic inflammation is classic for GPA. Chronic/recurrent sinus/lung infections and a resolving lung infiltrate fit the typical chronic necrotizing upper‑ and lower‑airway disease. This is distinct from IgA nephropathy, which causes episodic hematuria after mucosal infections but does not produce pulmonary hemorrhage or destructive nasopharyngeal disease. Appropriate diagnostic tests are c‑ANCA (PR3‑ANCA), urinalysis with RBC casts, chest imaging/CT, and confirmatory renal biopsy; treatment typically requires immunosuppression (eg, corticosteroids + cyclophosphamide or rituximab).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Goodpasture syndrome (anti–glomerular basement membrane disease).

Reasoning: The patient has a pulmonary–renal syndrome — acute hemoptysis from alveolar hemorrhage plus hematuria from glomerulonephritis — which is classically caused by anti‑GBM disease. The chest x‑ray showing a resolving lobar opacity and a recent history of pulmonary infection can precipitate alveolar hemorrhage in Goodpasture’s. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is characterized by destructive upper‑airway lesions (chronic sinusitis, nasal ulcers or septal perforation), which aren’t described here (an isolated epistaxis can occur from many causes), so the lack of chronic sinonasal disease makes GPA less likely. Confirm with anti‑GBM (anti–α3 type IV collagen) antibodies and renal biopsy showing linear IgG deposition; treat with plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.
WRONG
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener) — most likely.

Reasoning: The patient has a pulmonary-renal syndrome (hemoptysis + hematuria) plus spontaneous epistaxis/upper‑airway involvement and a history of recurrent lung/ENT infections. That triad (upper airway/sinus disease, focal lung lesions, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis) is classic for GPA (c‑ANCA/PR3-associated small‑vessel vasculitis). By contrast, anti‑GBM (Goodpasture) causes pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis but typically does not produce chronic nasal/sinus disease or recurrent ENT infections. Confirm with c‑ANCA/PR3 testing, urinalysis/renal function, anti‑GBM antibody testing and tissue biopsy if needed.
CORRECT
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener) is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: the patient has the classic pulmonary–renal and ENT involvement — hemoptysis, hematuria, and spontaneous epistaxis — plus recurrent sinus/lung infections and elevated inflammatory markers. GPA is a necrotizing granulomatous small‑vessel vasculitis that commonly produces upper airway disease (epistaxis/sinusitis), lung nodules/cavitary disease with hemoptysis, and glomerulonephritis with hematuria (often c‑ANCA/PR3 positive). IgA nephropathy typically causes isolated recurrent hematuria (often following mucosal infections) but does not cause hemoptysis or epistaxis, so it is much less likely. (Anti‑GBM disease is another pulmonary–renal differential but usually lacks the chronic ENT manifestations of GPA.)
CORRECT
Intussusception — most likely an ileocolic intussusception (telescoping of a proximal bowel segment into the adjacent distal segment), causing bowel obstruction and the palpable abdominal mass.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: intussusception.

Reasoning: The operative finding that one segment of intestine has telescoped (folded) into an adjacent segment is the definition of intussusception. Presentation with an infant having vomiting (bilious), obstruction (not passing stool), irritability, and a palpable abdominal mass fits classic intussusception. Meckel’s diverticulum is an ileal outpouching, not telescoping of bowel.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: intussusception.

Reasoning: a 10‑month‑old with acute vomiting/intestinal obstruction, an irritable infant, a palpable abdominal ("sausage") mass, and at laparotomy one bowel segment telescoped/folded into the adjacent segment is the classic description of intussusception (invagination). Volvulus/malrotation is twisting of the bowel rather than one segment folding into another, so the operative finding you describe points to intussusception.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: Intussusception — most likely an ileocolic intussusception.

Reasoning: A 10‑month‑old with acute vomiting (now bilious), failure to pass stool, an irritable infant with a palpable abdominal (sausage) mass, and operative finding of one bowel segment folded/telescoped into the adjacent segment are classic for intussusception. Volvulus/malrotation would show twisting rather than telescoping.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is intussusception.

Reasoning: the classic picture—an infant (~10 months) with acute vomiting (now bilious), failure to pass stool, irritability, and a palpable periumbilical/“sausage-shaped” abdominal mass—plus the operative description of one intestinal segment folded/telescoped into an adjacent segment is the definition of intussusception. Meckel’s diverticulum is an ileal outpouching that more typically causes painless rectal bleeding or can serve as a lead point for intussusception, but it is not described as an intestinal segment folded into another.
CORRECT
Acute gouty arthritis (an acute gout attack) due to monosodium urate crystal deposition. The synovial fluid shows negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals (classic for gout); cloudy fluid with high WBCs and a negative culture and the recent alcohol binge support an acute gout flare.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute gouty arthritis (monosodium urate crystal arthritis).

Reasoning: sudden, severe nocturnal monoarthritis with warmth/erythema and cloudy inflammatory synovial fluid plus needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy is diagnostic for gout. Culture-negative fluid and the crystal morphology exclude septic arthritis and calcium pyrophosphate deposition (pseudogout, which has positively birefringent, rhomboid crystals).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute gouty arthritis (monosodium urate crystal arthritis).

Reasoning: the synovial fluid shows classic negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals, which are diagnostic of gout. The clinical picture — sudden nocturnal severe monoarthritis after alcohol binge, inflammatory synovial WBC (~30,000/µL), fever and elevated ESR/white count — all fit an acute gout attack. (Pseudogout would show rhomboid, positively birefringent crystals; septic arthritis is less likely with a negative culture and the presence of MSU crystals, though rarely both can coexist.)
CORRECT
Most likely acute gout (gouty arthritis) due to monosodium urate crystals.

Reason: the synovial fluid shows classic needle‑shaped, negatively birefringent crystals (diagnostic of MSU/gout). The clinical picture—acute, severe, nocturnal monoarthritis with alcohol trigger, fever, elevated WBC/ESR and sterile culture—fits gout. (Pseudogout would show rhomboid, positively birefringent crystals.)
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Acute gouty arthritis.

Reasoning: The synovial fluid shows needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals — this is diagnostic of monosodium urate crystals (gout). The presentation (sudden severe nocturnal monoarticular pain, swelling, warmth) and a recent alcohol binge (a common trigger) further support acute gout. Reactive arthritis would not produce urate crystals on polarized microscopy and typically follows a GI/urogenital infection with an oligoarthritis of the lower extremities and associated symptoms (conjunctivitis, urethritis), which are absent here.
CORRECT
Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury — avulsion fracture of the PCL's tibial attachment (classic posterior "dashboard"–type injury with a positive posterior drawer).

A medial meniscus tear would not produce a posterior drawer sign or this avulsion pattern.

Reasoning: landing on the anterior knee with the knee flexed is the classic mechanism (direct posteriorly directed force to the tibia) for PCL injury. The exam shows posterior translation of the tibia with the knee flexed (positive posterior drawer), and the x‑ray demonstrates an avulsion at the tibial attachment — all consistent with a tibial‑side PCL avulsion. An ACL injury would produce anterior tibial translation, not posterior.
CORRECT

CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury — specifically avulsion of the PCL from its tibial attachment.

The exam finding of posterior translation of the tibia with a posterior drawer test is diagnostic for PCL disruption. An avulsion fracture at the posterior tibial insertion fits the x-ray. A medial meniscus tear would more likely present with joint‑line pain, locking/catching or a positive McMurray test, not posterior tibial displacement.
CORRECT

WRONG

Reasoning: an elderly man living alone with poor intake + corkscrew/fragile hair and scattered ecchymoses (perifollicular hemorrhages), bone pain/rib fractures on imaging, poor wound healing/bleeding tendency, and constitutional/behavioral changes are classic for vitamin C deficiency (impaired collagen synthesis). The presentation fits scurvy rather than a nonspecific “poor dietary intake.” Treatment is vitamin C supplementation and nutritional support.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: scurvy (vitamin C deficiency).

Reasoning: the constellation of corkscrew/fragile coiled hair, scattered ecchymoses/perifollicular hemorrhages, poor healing/rib pain with characteristic radiographic bone changes, and a history of probable poor intake (elderly with dementia living alone) is classic for vitamin C deficiency. These findings explain bleeding/bruising and bone pain/fractures that can mimic abuse, but the hair morphology and perifollicular hemorrhage are specific for scurvy. Treat with vitamin C repletion.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: vitamin C deficiency (scurvy).

Reasoning: an elderly, likely malnourished man living alone with easy bruising/perifollicular hemorrhages, corkscrew/fragile hair, poor wound healing and rib pain with radiographic subperiosteal changes is classic for scurvy. The neuro/mental status changes can be seen with systemic illness and his cholinesterase inhibitor (donepezil) can cause diarrhea; the constellation of skin/hair findings and bone pain points to vitamin C deficiency rather than elder abuse.
WRONG

Living alone with dementia predisposes to malnutrition/poor intake. WRONG

CORRECT
Conclusion: He most likely developed secondary acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) from progression of his myelodysplastic syndrome — not Burkitt lymphoma.

Reasoning: Prior MDS with chronic transfusion support predisposes to transformation to AML. The combination of new constitutional symptoms/weight loss, bleeding signs (petechiae/purpura) from severe thrombocytopenia (platelets 40k), anemia, and leukocytosis is classic for acute leukemia. Burkitt lymphoma is typically a rapidly growing B‑cell lymphoma of younger patients with jaw/abdominal masses and t(8;14) biology — it does not fit this patient’s history or typical presentation.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is most consistent with transformation of his myelodysplastic syndrome to acute myeloid leukemia (secondary/therapy‑related AML).

Reasoning: 
- MDS commonly progresses to AML; prior chemotherapy and ongoing transfusion‑dependent MDS increase that risk.  
- Clinical picture (fatigue, weight loss, new infections, mucocutaneous bleeding/petechiae from severe thrombocytopenia) fits leukemic transformation.  
- Lab pattern (anemia, marked thrombocytopenia, new leukocytosis) suggests marrow replaced by blast cells (peripheral blasts and marrow blasts >20% would confirm AML).  
- Other diagnoses (ALL is much less likely in this elderly patient and MDS does not transform to ALL; CML has a different chronic presentation).
CORRECT
Conclusion: Transformation of his myelodysplastic syndrome to acute myelogenous leukemia (secondary AML).

Reasoning: Prior MDS with need for transfusions puts him at high risk of transformation to AML. CORRECT
No — this presentation is most consistent with secondary acute myeloid leukemia (AML), not Burkitt lymphoma.

Reasoning: a 73‑year‑old with prior myelodysplastic syndrome and prior chemotherapy has a high risk of transformation to AML. The clinical picture (fatigue, infections, mucocutaneous bleeding with petechiae/purpura) plus anemia, thrombocytopenia (platelets 40k) and leukocytosis are classic for marrow failure with circulating myeloblasts seen in AML. Burkitt lymphoma classically occurs in younger patients (or immunocompromised hosts), presents with rapidly growing extranodal masses (jaw/abdomen) and a different lymphoma morphology/biology (c‑myc translocation) rather than post‑MDS marrow transformation.
CORRECT

CORRECT
Most likely squamous cell carcinoma of the vocal cord (glottic laryngeal cancer).

CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Squamous-cell carcinoma of the vocal cord (laryngeal carcinoma, glottic).

Reasoning: The lesion is described as a rough, vegetating (exophytic/irregular) lesion on the free edge of the vocal cord in a long-term smoker with months of progressive hoarseness and new hemoptysis — classic for glottic cancer. Polypoid corditis/Reinke edema or vocal polyps are typically smooth, gelatinous or pedunculated lesions (often bilateral for Reinke edema), related to chronic irritation or voice abuse, and usually do not present as an irregular, friable vegetating mass with hemoptysis. Definitive diagnosis requires direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.

CORRECT

Correct — signet-ring cells.

CORRECT

Reasoning: He has a real, chronic somatic complaint (back pain) for >6 months with persistent anxiety and excessive health-related behaviors (extensive internet research, repeated medical visits, and requests for imaging) despite normal exams and tests. Malingering or factitious disorder is unlikely given no external gain or evidence of symptom fabrication.
CORRECT

Reasoning: he has a year of persistent, distressing back pain with normal exam/labs/imaging and repeatedly seeks reassurance and medical evaluation — behavior and preoccupation disproportionate to findings and lasting >6 months. Conversion disorder is unlikely because his symptoms are not neurologic deficits incompatible with disease.
CORRECT
Most likely: illness anxiety disorder (hypochondriasis).

Reasoning: he has excessive fear of a serious disease (worry about pancreatic cancer) despite normal examinations, labs, and prior evaluations; current physical complaints are minimal or non‑specific (mild back pain, recent bloating) and do not explain the level of health anxiety. He pursues reassurance (requests CT) and has a pattern of repeated evaluations (prior chest‑pain workup). This fits illness anxiety disorder rather than conversion disorder (no neurological signs), somatic symptom disorder (where the somatic complaints themselves are prominent and cause the excessive concern), or malingering/factitious disorder (no clear external incentive or evidence of feigning).
WRONG

This fits somatic symptom disorder rather than conversion disorder (which produces neurological deficits incompatible with disease, eg paralysis/anaesthesia) or illness anxiety disorder (where somatic symptoms are minimal or absent). There’s no evidence of feigning (malingering/factitious disorder).
CORRECT
Aplastic anemia (bone marrow failure) — pancytopenia with a hypocellular, fatty (“empty”) marrow on biopsy consistent with marrow aplasia.
WRONG
The correct diagnosis is aplastic anemia (bone marrow aplasia).  

Reason: the patient has pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia) and the biopsy in this setting classically shows a markedly hypocellular marrow with fatty replacement and absence of blasts or malignant infiltration — findings inconsistent with acute myelogenous leukemia, which would show a hypercellular marrow packed with myeloblasts (>20% blasts).
WRONG
Correct diagnosis: Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).

Reasoning: The patient has pancytopenia with a bone marrow biopsy showing sheets of myeloblasts (often with Auer rods and myeloperoxidase positivity) meeting the diagnostic threshold of >20% blasts. This fits AML. CML would classically present with marked leukocytosis with a granulocytic left shift, basophilia and splenomegaly rather than pancytopenia and marrow packed with blasts.
CORRECT
Correct diagnosis: aplastic anemia.

Reasoning: the patient has pancytopenia (low Hgb, WBC, platelets) and the bone marrow biopsy in this setting shows hypocellular marrow with fatty (adipose) replacement and markedly decreased hematopoietic elements — findings characteristic of aplastic anemia rather than leukemias (which produce hypercellular marrow with blasts or granulocytic hyperplasia).
WRONG
Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).

Reasoning: The patient has pancytopenia (anemia, severe neutropenia, thrombocytopenia) and the marrow biopsy demonstrates a predominance of myeloblasts (often with Auer rods) consistent with AML. CML would typically present with marked leukocytosis and granulocytic hyperplasia with few blasts in the chronic phase, not the cytopenias and blast-filled marrow seen here.
CORRECT
Primary CNS lymphoma (AIDS-related B-cell lymphoma). 

Rationale: In an AIDS patient with CD4 <50, systemic lymphadenopathy and cytopenias, and a solitary periventricular/relatively homogeneously enhancing brain mass on MRI, primary CNS lymphoma is most likely. Toxoplasmosis typically produces multiple ring-enhancing lesions; positive toxoplasma IgG is common and not diagnostic.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (JC virus reactivation).

Reasoning: Profound immunosuppression (CD4 56) with subacute progressive cognitive decline and focal motor deficit (right leg weakness) is classic for PML. MRI in PML shows multifocal, asymmetric white-matter lesions (nonenhancing, no significant mass effect) rather than the ring-enhancing lesions of toxoplasmosis or the homogenously enhancing periventricular mass of primary CNS lymphoma. Confirmation is by JC virus PCR in CSF; treatment is immune reconstitution with antiretroviral therapy.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) from JC virus.

Reasoning: subacute–chronic cognitive decline, gait disturbance and focal leg weakness in a severely immunosuppressed patient (CD4 56) is classic for PML. MRI in PML shows asymmetric, multifocal white‑matter lesions that do not enhance and have little or no mass effect — unlike primary CNS lymphoma, which typically produces a solitary, periventricular, homogeneously or ring‑enhancing mass with mass effect. Toxoplasmosis (positive IgG) usually causes multiple ring‑enhancing lesions with edema and clinical fever/acute deterioration. The next step to confirm would be JC virus PCR on CSF.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma.

Reasoning: In an AIDS patient with CD4 56, a solitary/deep (periventricular) enhancing brain mass that is homogeneously enhancing on MRI favors primary CNS lymphoma (EBV-related diffuse large B‑cell lymphoma) over toxoplasmosis, which classically produces multiple ring‑enhancing, necrotic lesions in basal ganglia or cortex. The presence of generalized lymphadenopathy also supports a lymphoproliferative process. Toxoplasma IgG positivity increases pretest probability of toxoplasmosis but is not diagnostic; empiric anti‑toxoplasma therapy is often tried if imaging shows multiple ring lesions. Definitive confirmation here would be CSF EBV PCR or brain biopsy.
WRONG
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML).

Reasoning: In a severely immunosuppressed patient (CD4 56) with months of cognitive decline and subacute focal neurologic deficits, PML from JC virus is most likely if brain MRI shows multifocal, asymmetric white‑matter lesions that do not enhance and produce little or no mass effect. By contrast, primary CNS lymphoma typically appears as one (or few) periventricular, homogeneously enhancing mass lesions with more mass effect, and toxoplasmosis (given positive IgG) causes multiple ring‑enhancing lesions. Confirmation of PML is by CSF JC virus PCR (or characteristic MRI appearance plus compatible clinical course). If you can, paste or describe the MRI enhancement pattern and lesion distribution and I’ll refine the diagnosis.
CORRECT
Adjustment disorder (specifically adjustment disorder with anxiety). Symptoms began after an identifiable work stressor, have been present for a short time (<6 months), cause impairment, and remit as the stressor is relieved — unlike GAD, which requires ≥6 months.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with anxiety.

Reasoning: Symptoms began within months of an identifiable stressor (excessive work hours, stressful conditions), are time-limited (2 months) and improved when the stressor abated, and consist of anxiety, irritability, concentration and sleep disturbance rather than recurrent unexpected panic attacks. GAD requires ≥6 months of symptoms and panic disorder requires recurrent panic attacks, so adjustment disorder with anxious mood best fits.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Adjustment disorder — specifically "adjustment disorder with anxiety."

Reasoning: His symptoms began within months of an identifiable stressor (excessive work demands), cause marked distress and functional impairment, and markedly improved after the stressor was reduced. This fits DSM criteria for adjustment disorder. Other options are less likely: GAD requires ≥6 months of pervasive worry; PTSD/acute stress disorder require a qualifying traumatic exposure; "burnout" is a descriptive/occupational term, not a DSM diagnosis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Adjustment disorder (with anxious mood).

Reasoning: His symptoms began within 3 months of a clearly identifiable stressor (excessive work hours/strain), caused marked distress and functional impairment, and substantially improved after the stressor was reduced — all characteristic of adjustment disorder. This is distinct from GAD (requires ≥6 months of pervasive worry), PTSD/acute stress disorder (require traumatic event and specific symptom clusters), and “burnout” (not an official DSM diagnosis).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Adjustment disorder.

Reasoning: His symptoms (irritability, anxiety, sleep disturbance, poor concentration) began within 2 months of a clearly identifiable stressor (excessive work hours), cause marked distress and functional impairment, and improved after the stressor was reduced. This pattern fits adjustment disorder. Panic disorder is unlikely because he has no history of recurrent unexpected panic attacks (abrupt surges of intense fear with autonomic symptoms) or the required course criteria for panic disorder.
CORRECT
Acute hemolysis from glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency — an X-linked inability to generate NADPH in RBCs (impairing reduced glutathione), leading to oxidative damage (eg, after TMP‑SMX) and intravascular/extravascular hemolysis.
CORRECT
Most likely cause: glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency — an X‑linked enzyme deficiency leading to decreased NADPH and reduced glutathione, causing oxidative injury to RBCs after sulfa exposure and acute hemolysis.

Reasoning: acute hemoglobinuria shortly after trimethoprim‑sulfamethoxazole in a boy of African descent, with normocytic anemia, reticulocytosis, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, low haptoglobin and “blood” on urine with few RBCs (hemoglobinuria) — all fit oxidant‑induced hemolysis from G6PD deficiency. Absent beta chains (β‑thalassemia) would cause chronic microcytic anemia, not an acute sulfa‑triggered hemolytic episode.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is acute hemolysis from glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency — an X‑linked enzymatic defect causing decreased NADPH and reduced glutathione, so RBCs are vulnerable to oxidative drugs (trimethoprim‑sulfamethoxazole) and develop intravascular hemolysis.

Reasoning (brief): The child’s acute dark urine, scleral icterus, low haptoglobin, predominantly indirect hyperbilirubinemia, hemoglobinuria (urine blood 3+ with few RBCs), reticulocytosis, male sex and West African ancestry, and temporal relation to a sulfa antibiotic are classic for oxidative‑triggered hemolysis from G6PD deficiency.
CORRECT
Yes — the most likely cause is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency causing acute oxidative hemolysis triggered by trimethoprim‑sulfamethoxazole.

Why: onset shortly after an oxidant drug, African descent male, dark urine with a positive blood dipstick but few RBCs (hemoglobinuria), indirect hyperbilirubinemia, low haptoglobin, reticulocytosis and splenomegaly all point to hemolysis. G6PD deficiency (X‑linked) → decreased NADPH → reduced glutathione deficiency → RBCs cannot neutralize oxidative stress → hemoglobin denatures (Heinz bodies) and cells are hemolyzed.
CORRECT
No — the most likely cause is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency causing acute oxidant‑induced intravascular hemolysis.

Reasoning: acute dark urine with blood on dipstick but few RBCs, low haptoglobin, indirect hyperbilirubinemia and recent sulfa exposure point to intravascular hemolysis from an oxidative trigger. He’s an 8‑year‑old boy from West Africa (high G6PD prevalence) and the presentation is sudden rather than the chronic, severe microcytic anemia of absent β‑globin (β‑thalassemia major), which presents in infancy with markedly low MCV and transfusion dependence.
CORRECT
Cholesteatoma of the middle ear/mastoid eroding bone (including the facial canal) — a keratinizing squamous epithelial mass from chronic otitis media that causes foul-smelling otorrhea, conductive hearing loss (ossicular erosion/impedance) and can produce a peripheral (LMN) facial nerve palsy by bony erosion of CN VII.
CORRECT
Conclusion: A cholesteatoma of the middle ear with bony erosion of the facial canal causing a peripheral (LMN) facial nerve palsy.

Reasoning: The patient has foul-smelling otorrhea, a history of recurrent ear infections, conductive hearing loss, and an otoscopic appearance consistent with a retraction pocket/pearly keratinous mass — classic for cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas are keratinizing squamous epithelial growths that cause local bone erosion (including the facial canal), producing acute peripheral facial palsy. Tympanosclerosis causes white plaques and ossicular fixation with conductive loss but does not typically produce foul discharge or bony erosion leading to facial paralysis. Immediate ENT evaluation (CT temporal bone and surgical removal) is indicated.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is most likely a cholesteatoma eroding the bony facial (Fallopian) canal and causing an ipsilateral lower‑motor‑neuron facial palsy.

Why: The history of recurrent childhood ear infections and a month of foul, chronic otorrhea plus conductive hearing loss and the characteristic otoscopic finding (pearly/keratinous mass or retraction pocket) point to cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas expand and chronically inflame the middle ear/mastoid, causing bone erosion — the facial nerve runs through the temporal bone/middle ear and can be exposed or destroyed, producing facial droop. Other possibilities are less consistent: idiopathic Bell palsy would not have chronic otorrhea or conductive hearing loss; Ramsay Hunt (herpes zoster oticus) produces vesicles and often sensorineural hearing loss; a glomus tumor gives a vascular mass and pulsatile tinnitus rather than foul discharge.
CORRECT
Answer: Yes — a cholesteatoma causing local bone erosion with extension into the facial (Fallopian) canal, producing conductive hearing loss and ipsilateral lower motor–neuron facial palsy.

Reasoning: Chronic foul otorrhea and history of recurrent middle‑ear disease with otoscopic evidence of a retraction pocket/pearly keratin mass and conductive hearing loss classically indicate a cholesteatoma. These lesions expand and erode ossicles (causing conductive loss) and surrounding bone, and can erode the facial nerve canal producing an LMN facial palsy that affects the entire hemiface (inability to close the eye and asymmetric smile). This fits the findings better than Bell palsy or stroke, which lack chronic ear drainage and conductive hearing loss.
CORRECT
Cholesteatoma is most likely.  

Cholesteatomas are keratinizing squamous epithelial masses in the middle ear/mastoid that arise after chronic/recurrent otitis media, produce foul-smelling otorrhea, cause conductive hearing loss, and are locally destructive — they can erode ossicles and the facial canal producing a peripheral (LMN) facial palsy. Tympanosclerosis causes white, chalky plaques/scarring of the tympanic membrane with conductive hearing loss but is not typically associated with foul discharge or bone erosion/facial nerve paralysis.
CORRECT

Mild hepatomegaly fits hepatic accumulation/injury from A1AT deficiency. Pulmonary edema would be acute and would not explain the long history, family pattern, nor associated liver findings.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency.

Reasoning: young onset progressive obstructive lung disease in a lifelong non‑smoker, positive family history of early “COPD” deaths, hepatomegaly (hepatic involvement/cirrhosis) and very prolonged expiration are classic for A1AT deficiency causing panacinar emphysema. (Clubbing and crackles can occur with chronic lung disease or superimposed bronchiectasis/infection, but the combination of early COPD in a non‑smoker plus liver findings strongly favors A1AT.) Next step: measure serum A1AT level and perform phenotype/genotype testing.
CORRECT
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency causing early panacinar emphysema.

Reasoning: He is a young (32) non‑smoker with progressive obstructive symptoms (markedly prolonged expiratory time), a family history of early-onset COPD, and evidence of liver involvement (hepatomegaly) — the classic combination for AAT deficiency. Other causes are less likely: asthma would usually respond to therapy and not cause familial early COPD with liver disease; cystic fibrosis presents earlier and with GI/sinopulmonary features; interstitial lung disease is restrictive (shorter expiratory time). Confirm with serum AAT level and phenotyping/genotyping (eg, PiZZ).
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency causing early-onset emphysema.

Reasoning: a 32‑year‑old non‑smoker with progressive “asthma” refractory to treatment, a strong family history of early COPD, marked prolongation of expiration (>6 s) consistent with obstructive disease, and hepatomegaly (AAT causes panacinar emphysema plus hepatic disease) points to AAT deficiency. Pulmonary edema is usually an acute cardiogenic picture with inspiratory crackles, orthopnea, signs of left‑sided heart failure, and alveolar (not prolonged expiratory) physiology — it does not explain the chronic progressive obstructive pattern or the family history.

Marked hypertriglyceridemia (TG 675 mg/dL) is a well‑known cause of acute pancreatitis. Recurrent similar hospitalizations point to recurrent or chronic pancreatitis. Findings argue against acute cholecystitis (no fever, normal ALP/ALT, and pain pattern/radiation more typical of pancreatitis).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: chronic (recurrent) pancreatitis — likely related to metabolic risk (poorly controlled diabetes with severe hypertriglyceridemia).

Reasoning: Recurrent episodes of dull epigastric pain radiating to the back that are worse with meals and accompanied by nausea/vomiting are classic for chronic pancreatitis. Her history of multiple prior hospitalizations with similar complaints supports recurrent pancreatic inflammation. Marked hypertriglyceridemia (675 mg/dL) and long‑standing poorly controlled diabetes (HbA1c 9.1%, acanthosis nigricans) are metabolic risk factors for pancreatitis. Normal vitals and liver enzymes do not exclude chronic pancreatitis. Diabetic gastroparesis would present more with early satiety, bloating and prolonged vomiting rather than severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: recurrent acute pancreatitis due to severe hypertriglyceridemia.

Reasoning: The history of epigastric pain radiating to the back that worsens with meals and recurrent similar hospitalizations fits pancreatitis. Her triglycerides are markedly elevated (675 mg/dL), a well‑recognized cause of acute pancreatitis (TG >500 mg/dL). The diabetic/insulin‑resistant state (acanthosis nigricans, HbA1c 9.1%) explains the severe hypertriglyceridemia; LFTs do not suggest gallstone etiology.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: recurrent (chronic) pancreatitis — most consistent with hypertriglyceridemia-induced pancreatitis.

Reasoning: the pain is epigastric, dull, radiates to the back and worsens after meals (classic for pancreatic pain), she has a history of repeated similar attacks, and triglycerides are markedly elevated (675 mg/dL), a well‑known trigger for pancreatitis. Normal temperature, LFTs and lack of focal RUQ findings make acute cholecystitis less likely.

Reason: X-linked recessive history (male child, maternal uncle affected) with easy bruising and hemarthrosis fits hemophilia. CORRECT
Hemophilia A (hemarthrosis) — a bleeding disorder causing blood to accumulate in the joint.

Reasoning: The boy is a young male with lifelong easy bruising and an uncle who died after surgery (X‑linked inheritance), a markedly prolonged aPTT (67 s) with normal bleeding time, and a bloody joint aspirate after minor trauma — all classic for an intrinsic factor deficiency (most commonly factor VIII, i.e. Hemophilia A). Septic arthritis would usually produce a purulent aspirate with very high synovial WBCs (typically >50,000/µL), systemic signs of infection, and would not explain the prolonged aPTT or family history.

CORRECT
Most likely a full‑thickness rotator‑cuff tear (supraspinatus).

Reason: classic painful arc (60–120°), positive drop‑arm sign (can’t lower from 90°), intact passive ROM (rules out adhesive capsulitis), and lack of response to subacromial lidocaine (argues against isolated impingement/bursitis) — all point to mechanical loss of tendon function rather than purely inflammatory pain.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: full-thickness rotator cuff tear (most likely supraspinatus tendon).

Reasoning: pain in the subacromial region with a painful arc (60–120°) plus a positive drop-arm/weakness on slow lowering indicates inability of the rotator cuff to eccentrically control abduction — classic for a tear. Normal passive ROM argues against adhesive capsulitis. Lack of pain/strength improvement after subacromial lidocaine makes isolated bursitis/impingement or tendinopathy unlikely (those usually improve with local anesthetic); failure to improve suggests a structural tendon tear. CORRECT
Rotator cuff tear (most likely a full-thickness supraspinatus tear).

Reasoning: The painful arc (60–120°), positive drop-arm test (unable to slowly lower from 90°), preserved passive ROM with loss of active abduction, and lack of response to subacromial lidocaine are classic for a rotator cuff tendon tear. Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically bilateral with prolonged morning stiffness (>45 min), systemic inflammatory markers, and diffuse proximal aching rather than a focal painful arc and true weakness on resisted motion.
CORRECT

Reason: acute, painless monocular vision loss with new floaters/photopsias and a "curtain" defect, plus recent cataract surgery (a risk factor). Urgent ophthalmology evaluation for retinal repair is required.

Reasoning: The sudden painless “curtain” loss of vision with flashes and black spots (floaters) is classic for retinal detachment, and cataract surgery is a known risk factor. The anterior chamber and pupils are normal (no mid‑dilated nonreactive pupil, corneal edema, or severe pain that you would see in acute angle‑closure glaucoma), and the focal visual field defects fit a peripheral retina detachment progressing centrally.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: rhegmatogenous retinal detachment of the left eye.

Reasoning: acute monocular “curtain” of vision loss with new floaters and flashes is classic for retinal detachment, and recent cataract surgery (a known risk factor) increases the likelihood. The focal visual-field defects on confrontation (nasal/inferior) fit a retinal break/detachment pattern. Alternative causes (central retinal artery occlusion, optic neuritis, stroke, or corneal/ anterior-chamber pathology) are less consistent given the painless onset, preserved pupillary reactivity, and the specific symptoms of flashes/floaters. Fundoscopic exam after dilation will confirm (elevated/grey retina, retinal tear, subretinal fluid).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (retinal detachment).

Why: the sudden "curtain" of vision loss, new flashes and black spots (floaters), acute peripheral visual-field defects, painless presentation, and the recent cataract surgery (a risk factor for posterior vitreous detachment and subsequent retinal tear/detachment) are classic for retinal detachment. Anterior-segment exam is normal (localizes the problem posteriorly). Alternatives (eg, central retinal artery occlusion, ischemic optic neuropathy, isolated vitreous hemorrhage) are less consistent with the progressive curtain-like peripheral field loss and flashes. 

This is an ophthalmic emergency — urgent ophthalmology evaluation and prompt repair are required to try to preserve vision.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Reason: The acute “curtain” of vision loss with flashes/floaters, monocular peripheral field defects and marked drop in acuity, with a normal anterior chamber and reactive pupils, is classic for retinal detachment (recent cataract surgery is a known risk factor). Acute angle‑closure glaucoma would cause severe ocular pain, headache/nausea, corneal haze, a mid‑dilated poorly reactive pupil and a shallow anterior chamber—all of which are absent here. Urgent dilated fundus exam and prompt ophthalmology referral for repair are indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely methemoglobinemia from the local anesthetic (eg, prilocaine/benzocaine) used during the dental procedure. Oxidation of hemoglobin iron from Fe2+ to Fe3+ (methemoglobin) prevents O2 binding/delivery, produces cyanosis and an SpO2 ≈85% that does not correct with oxygen or ventilation.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: methemoglobinemia from an oxidizing local anesthetic (eg, prilocaine/benzocaine) used during the dental procedure.

Reasoning: acute central cyanosis with low pulse-ox (~85%) that does not correct with supplemental O2 or assisted ventilation and clear lungs points to dysfunctional hemoglobin. Oxidation of hemoglobin Fe2+ → Fe3+ (methemoglobin) prevents O2 binding/release and produces a characteristic 85% SpO2 plateau. Topical/local anesthetics (prilocaine, benzocaine) are classic causes. Sulfhemoglobinemia is much rarer, not typically caused by these agents, and does not respond to methylene blue (whereas methemoglobinemia does).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: methemoglobinemia from a topical/local anesthetic (eg, prilocaine/benzocaine) given during the dental procedure — the stem’s “pilocarpine” is almost certainly a typo.

Reasoning: the patient is deeply cyanotic with an SpO2 ≈85% that does not improve with 100% O2 or assisted ventilation, and his lungs/airway are clear — classic for methemoglobinemia (Fe2+ → Fe3+ hemoglobin cannot bind O2). Pulse oximetry typically reads ~85% regardless of PaO2, and exposure to certain local anesthetics (benzocaine, prilocaine) can precipitate this. Treatment is IV methylene blue (unless G6PD deficiency).
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is methemoglobinemia from an oxidizing local anesthetic (most likely prilocaine or topical benzocaine in the dental setting), not pilocarpine.

Reasoning: Cyanosis with low pulse oximetry (~85%) that does not improve with oxygen or ventilation, clear lungs and normal respiratory effort, and acute collapse after dental anesthesia are classic for methemoglobinemia (Fe2+ → Fe3+ hemoglobin unable to carry O2). Dental agents often implicated are prilocaine or benzocaine — the question’s “pilocarpine” is likely an error. Confirm with ABG (high PaO2 with low measured SpO2 and “oxygen saturation gap”), chocolate‑brown blood, and treat promptly with IV methylene blue.
CORRECT
Methemoglobinemia is more likely.

Reasoning: Dental local anesthetics (classically benzocaine or prilocaine — the record’s “pilocarpine” is almost certainly a typo) can oxidize hemoglobin’s Fe2+ to Fe3+ (methemoglobin), which cannot carry O2. Methemoglobinemia causes central cyanosis, a pulse oximeter that often reads ~85% regardless of true PaO2, normal lung exam and PO2, and no improvement with oxygen/ventilation. Diagnosis is by co‑oximetry; treatment is methylene blue. Sulfhemoglobinemia is much rarer, usually linked to sulfur‑containing drugs, is irreversible for the RBC lifespan, and also does not respond to methylene blue, so it’s less likely in this clinical context.
CORRECT
Aplastic anemia — acquired bone marrow failure causing pancytopenia (low reticulocyte count) with a hypocellular marrow and no malignant/abnormal cell population.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Aplastic anemia (acquired bone marrow failure).

Reasoning: The patient has pancytopenia (Hb 8.2, WBC 2.2K, platelets 88K) with a low reticulocyte count (poor marrow response) and a bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity without abnormal infiltrate — the classic picture of aplastic anemia. Infectious mononucleosis is unlikely because it usually causes lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes and systemic viral prodrome/lymphadenopathy, not a hypocellular marrow with pancytopenia.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: aplastic anemia (severe bone marrow failure due to aplasia).

Reasoning: The patient has pancytopenia with a very low reticulocyte count (hypoproliferative anemia) and a bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity without an abnormal cell population—classic for aplastic anemia. Alternatives are less likely: acute leukemia would produce marrow hypercellularity/blasts, PNH shows hemolysis with an elevated retic count and hemoglobinuria, and myelodysplastic syndrome usually shows dysplasia/cytogenetic abnormalities (and typically occurs in older patients; although hypocellular MDS exists, it would still show dysplastic features). Workup should include drug/toxin/viral (hepatitis, EBV, HIV) history, flow cytometry for PNH, viral serologies, and cytogenetics to exclude hypocellular MDS.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: severe aplastic anemia (acquired bone marrow failure).

Reasoning: he has pancytopenia (anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) with a low reticulocyte count (poor marrow production) and a bone marrow that is hypocellular with no abnormal cell population — the classic pattern for aplastic anemia. 

Why not leukemia or megaloblastic anemia: acute leukemia would show blasts and a hypercellular marrow; megaloblastic anemia typically has a hypercellular marrow with dysplastic megaloblastic changes and macrocytosis. Hypersplenism or hemolysis would usually have an elevated reticulocyte count. Myelodysplastic syndromes can mimic marrow failure but usually show dysplastic/abnormal cells and are more common in older patients.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is aplastic anemia.

Reasoning: He has pancytopenia (low Hgb, WBC, and platelets) with a very low reticulocyte count (hypoproliferative anemia) and a bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity/"empty" marrow — the classic triad for aplastic anemia (bone marrow failure). Infectious mononucleosis (EBV) typically produces fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, atypical lymphocytosis (not leukopenia) and a reactive/hypercellular marrow rather than a hypocellular one, so it does not fit this presentation.
CORRECT
Alcohol withdrawal–related hallucinosis (acute alcoholic hallucinosis).  

Rationale: Hallucinations beginning ~12 hours after last drink with preserved orientation, fine tremor and diaphoresis fit alcohol withdrawal hallucinosis. Delirium tremens is more severe, occurs later (48–72 hr) with marked disorientation and autonomic instability.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: alcohol withdrawal hallucinosis (acute alcohol withdrawal).

Reasoning: Hallucinosis typically begins within 6–24 hours after last drink, with preserved orientation, visual/auditory hallucinations, tremor, anxiety and diaphoresis — exactly this picture 12 hours after heavy drinking. Wernicke encephalopathy would produce confusion, ataxia and ophthalmoplegia from thiamine deficiency, not isolated formed hallucinations with normal orientation.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: alcohol withdrawal–related hallucinosis (alcoholic hallucinosis).

Reasoning: the symptoms began about 12 hours after heavy drinking, the patient is alert and oriented (preserved sensorium) and has isolated threatening auditory hallucinations with tremor and diaphoresis — a classic picture of alcoholic hallucinosis/early alcohol withdrawal. Delirium tremens would occur later (typically 48–96 hr) with global disorientation and much more severe autonomic disturbance. Acute stimulant psychosis is less likely given the timing and history.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: alcoholic hallucinosis (alcohol withdrawal–related auditory hallucinations).

Reasoning: Classic features are onset within 12–24 hours after heavy alcohol use/cessation, preserved orientation and clear sensorium, prominent auditory hallucinations, mild autonomic signs and tremor. Delirium tremens is less likely because he is alert and oriented with normal vitals and no marked autonomic instability or severe confusion; primary psychosis or stimulant-induced psychosis is less likely given the temporal relation to alcohol withdrawal.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is alcoholic hallucinosis.

Reasoning: The patient is 12 hours after heavy drinking and is alert, oriented, and experiencing primarily auditory hallucinations with preserved sensorium — classic for alcoholic (alcohol-related) hallucinosis which typically begins within 12–24 hours of cessation. Wernicke encephalopathy would present with the triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia/nystagmus and ataxia (ocular signs and impaired mentation), which are absent here. Delirium tremens is usually later (48–72+ hours) with marked disorientation and autonomic instability.
CORRECT
