Conversion disorder usually produces one or a few neurologic symptoms (e.g., motor/sensory loss, seizures) that are not explained by medical disease, whereas this case shows long-standing, varied physical complaints (GI, pelvic, musculoskeletal) and high health-care use.
CORRECT
Acute pyelonephritis (most likely ascending E. coli infection). The fever, flank pain/CVA tenderness and white blood cell casts (renal parenchymal involvement) with Gram‑negative bacteria are classic for pyelonephritis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute pyelonephritis.

Reasoning: Fever, flank pain and dysuria plus urinary WBC casts indicate renal parenchymal (not just lower tract) infection. The presence of Gram‑negative bacteria in the urine (classically E. coli) supports an ascending bacterial infection of the kidney. Acute interstitial nephritis would more typically follow a new drug, often has rash/eosinophilia, and is not associated with bacteriuria.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute (bacterial) pyelonephritis.

Reason: the combination of fever, dysuria, right flank pain, urinary white‑cell casts (indicating renal parenchymal inflammation) and Gram‑negative bacteria (classic uropathogens such as E. coli) points to an ascending kidney infection. Lack of recent new medications makes acute interstitial nephritis unlikely, and simple cystitis would not typically cause fever and flank pain.
CORRECT
Acute (bacterial) pyelonephritis.

She has fever, dysuria and right flank/CVA pain plus WBC casts on urinalysis (indicates renal parenchymal/tubular inflammation) and Gram‑negative organisms (E. coli most common). Cystitis would usually lack fever/CVA tenderness and WBC casts; drug‑induced interstitial nephritis usually follows new medications and often shows eosinophils.
CORRECT
Acute pyelonephritis — the presentation (fever, dysuria, unilateral flank pain) plus WBC casts and Gram-negative bacteria in the urine is classic for an ascending bacterial renal parenchymal infection.  

Acute interstitial nephritis typically follows a new drug or infection, often shows eosinophiluria and sterile pyuria or negative urine cultures, and is less likely to present with bacteriuria/Gram‑negative organisms and the focal flank pain described. Urine culture and clinical course would confirm pyelonephritis.
CORRECT
Findings are most consistent with subacute infective endocarditis — classically due to Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly S. bovis) bacteremia from the colon (associated with colon adenocarcinoma) with mitral-valve vegetation causing new regurgitant murmur and peripheral stigmata (Osler nodes, Roth spots, splinter/conjunctival hemorrhages).
WRONG
Conclusion: Infective endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis (mitral valve involvement).

Reasoning: The patient has fever, a new holosystolic apical murmur (mitral regurgitation), Osler nodes/tender fingertip nodules, Roth spots, conjunctival hemorrhage and embolic/immune phenomena — classic subacute IE. Her recent colon surgery and severe UTI predispose to Enterococcus (a gram‑positive, bile- and salt‑tolerant coccus) as the most likely pathogen after GI/GU procedures.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is most likely infective endocarditis due to Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly Streptococcus bovis) bacteremia from the colonic malignancy.

Reasoning: The patient has classic subacute IE (fever, new holosystolic MR murmur, Osler nodes, Roth spots, splinter/conjunctival hemorrhages). S. gallolyticus is strongly associated with colonic neoplasia and can enter the bloodstream after colonic lesions or surgery, causing endocarditis—making it far more likely here than S. sanguinis (a viridans strep linked to dental procedures).
WRONG
Most likely: Enterococcus faecalis bacteremia causing subacute infective endocarditis of the mitral valve, originating from her prior urinary tract infection/hospitalization.

Reasoning: She has classic infective endocarditis findings (fever, new holosystolic murmur at the apex = MR, Osler nodes, Roth spots, conjunctival hemorrhage). Recent severe UTI and recent GI/urinary tract hospitalization/surgery are strong risk factors for Enterococcus (normal GI/GU flora that commonly causes endocarditis in older patients after GU/GI procedures). (Streptococcus gallolyticus [S. bovis] is associated with colon cancer, but given the recent UTI/ICU course Enterococcus is most likely.)
CORRECT
Yes — Enterococcus faecalis is the most likely cause.  

This presentation is classic infective endocarditis (fever, new mitral regurg murmur, Osler nodes, Roth spots), and Enterococcus faecalis is strongly associated with endocarditis following genitourinary or gastrointestinal instrumentation/surgery (recent hemicolectomy and severe UTI). By contrast, viridans streptococci (eg, S. sanguinis) are classically linked to dental procedures. Enterococci are gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci that tolerate bile/NaCl and commonly cause post-GI/GU endocarditis and often require specific combination therapy (eg, ampicillin ± gentamicin).
CORRECT
Ludwig angina — a rapidly progressive bilateral submandibular/submental (floor-of-mouth) cellulitis from an infected mandibular molar, causing submandibular swelling, dysphagia and systemic infection in a diabetic patient.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Ludwig angina (bilateral submandibular/sublingual space cellulitis) — a serious odontogenic neck-space infection.

Reasoning: The acute onset of fever, leukocytosis, dysphagia and submandibular/anterior neck swelling originating from a decayed lower molar in a diabetic patient is classic for Ludwig angina. This infection of the submandibular and sublingual spaces from an infected mandibular molar can rapidly compromise the airway. A sublingual hematoma would be noninfectious (usually traumatic or anticoagulant-related) and would not explain fever, pus drainage, leukocytosis, or the dental source.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: an odontogenic submandibular-space abscess/cervical cellulitis (dental‑origin submandibular abscess), not classic Ludwig angina.

Reasoning: there is a clearly infected lower third molar with purulent drainage and ipsilateral submandibular/anterior neck swelling, fever and leukocytosis in a diabetic patient — findings localize to a submandibular odontogenic abscess/cervical cellulitis. Classic Ludwig angina is bilateral, involves the sublingual and submental spaces with floor-of-mouth elevation and tongue displacement causing airway compromise; those hallmark features are not described here.
WRONG
Yes — most likely Ludwig angina.

Reasoning: the patient has an infected lower molar with purulent drainage and acute bilateral submandibular/anterior neck swelling, dysphagia, fever and leukocytosis. Ludwig angina is a rapidly progressive cellulitis of the submandibular/sublingual spaces that classically arises from mandibular molar infections (worse in diabetics) and presents with neck/floor‑of‑mouth swelling and swallowing/airway symptoms. This fits much better than peritonsillar abscess (tonsillar findings/uvular deviation, not dental origin) or Lemierre syndrome (septic IJV thrombophlebitis after pharyngitis with septic emboli).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Ludwig angina.

Reasoning: This is a rapidly spreading odontogenic cellulitis of the submandibular/submental/sublingual spaces classically arising from an infected mandibular molar. The patient has a decayed lower third molar with purulent drainage, fever, leukocytosis, dysphagia and tender submandibular/anterior neck swelling, and risk factors (diabetes) — all consistent with Ludwig angina. A sublingual hematoma would be associated with trauma or coagulopathy/anticoagulation and bluish blood-filled swelling without fever, leukocytosis, or purulent dental drainage, making it far less likely here.
CORRECT
Excessive collagen deposition during wound healing (keloid formation) — TGF-β–driven fibroblast proliferation and overproduction of collagen (exuberant scar formation).
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is an exuberant scar (keloid/hypertrophic scar) from excessive collagen deposition during wound healing — not diabetic poor healing.

Reasoning: A firm, non-tender nodular scar developing within months at a healed stab site with histology showing abundant fibroblasts and collagen is classic for an excessive scar (keloid/hypertrophic scar) caused by overactive fibroblasts and increased TGF-β–driven collagen synthesis. Diabetes causes impaired/slow healing and ulceration rather than a collagenous nodular overgrowth.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is hypertrophic scar formation — excess, localized collagen deposition (TGF-β–driven fibroblast proliferation and fibrosis), not a keloid.

Reasoning: The lesion appeared within months and is confined to the original wound site (no extension beyond margins) and microscopy shows abundant fibroblasts and collagen. Keloids characteristically extend beyond the wound, show thick, disorganized “keloidal” collagen and often recur after excision. These features fit a hypertrophic scar.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is keloid formation — an excessive TGF-β–mediated wound-healing response causing fibroblast proliferation and abundant collagen deposition.

Reasoning: A raised, firm nodular scar appearing months after injury on the chest with abundant fibroblasts and collagen is classic for a keloid. Keloids result from overactive repair (↑TGF-β signaling) and produce excessive, disorganized collagen bundles, distinguishing them from hypertrophic scars (which remain within wound borders and may regress).
CORRECT
No — this is keloid formation: an overgrowth of scar tissue with exuberant fibroblast proliferation and abundant collagen deposition (driven in part by TGF-β) occurring months after skin injury.  

Reason: the firm, nodular, raised scar with intact epithelium and histology showing plentiful collagen/fibroblasts is classic for keloid. Diabetes causes impaired/poor wound healing (delayed closure, increased infection, decreased angiogenesis and leukocyte function), not an excessive collagenous nodular scar.
CORRECT
This presentation meets criteria for acute liver failure (fulminant hepatic failure): acute onset jaundice, coagulopathy (INR ≥1.5 / TP activity <40%), and hepatic encephalopathy (disorientation, asterixis) in a previously healthy young patient. Given his high‑risk sexual behavior, the most likely cause is acute viral hepatitis — most likely acute hepatitis B.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Acute (fulminant) liver failure from acute viral hepatitis — most likely acute hepatitis B.

Reasoning: He has acute onset jaundice over days with marked hyperbilirubinemia, very high transaminases (AST and ALT both ~600), impaired synthetic function (TP activity <40% / INR 1.5), and hepatic encephalopathy (disorientation, asterixis) — fulfilling criteria for acute/fulminant hepatic failure. His minimal alcohol intake and lack of chronic heavy drinking make alcoholic hepatitis unlikely; his high‑risk sexual behavior points toward acute viral hepatitis (eg, HBV) as the probable cause.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute (fulminant/hyperacute) hepatic failure — most likely from acute viral hepatitis B.

Reasoning: he has hepatic encephalopathy (disorientation, asterixis), coagulopathy (TP activity <40%, INR ≈1.5) and marked jaundice with very high bilirubin and transaminases developing over about a week in a previously healthy person — meeting criteria for acute liver failure (encephalopathy + INR ≥1.5 without chronic liver disease). His high‑risk sexual history makes acute HBV a likely cause; other causes (acetaminophen toxicity, recreational drugs) are possible but less supported by the history.
CORRECT
Acute (fulminant) hepatic failure — most likely due to acute viral hepatitis (eg, hepatitis B).

Reasoning: he has new-onset hepatic encephalopathy (disorientation, asterixis) occurring within ~1 week of jaundice plus coagulopathy (INR 1.5, prothrombin activity <40%), which meets the definition of acute/fulminant liver failure. Very high bilirubin and markedly elevated AST/ALT support severe hepatocellular injury; epistaxis reflects the coagulopathy. His high‑risk sexual behavior is a strong clue for acute hepatitis B as the precipitant (other causes would include acetaminophen toxicity, ischemic or drug-induced liver injury).
CORRECT
No — the most likely diagnosis is acute (fulminant) hepatic failure.

Reasoning: he has recent onset jaundice (≈1 week) with hepatic encephalopathy (disorientation, asterixis) and coagulopathy (TP activity <40% / INR 1.5), which satisfies the definition of acute/fulminant liver failure. Alcoholic hepatitis is unlikely given his minimal alcohol use, the AST:ALT ≈1 (not >2), and markedly elevated transaminases — alcoholic hepatitis typically occurs in heavy chronic drinkers and shows AST>ALT (usually <500 IU/L). Acute viral or drug‑induced liver injury causing fulminant failure would be more consistent.
CORRECT
Dubin–Johnson syndrome.

Reason: chronic, predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with otherwise normal LFTs and a characteristically dark/black liver from pigment-laden hepatocytes (vs Rotor, which has similar labs but a normal-appearing liver).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Dubin–Johnson syndrome.

Reasoning: She has lifelong scleral icterus with isolated conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total 5.2 mg/dL, direct 4.0 mg/dL), normal transaminases/alkaline phosphatase, benign clinical course, and a darkly pigmented (“black”) liver noted at surgery — classic for Dubin–Johnson (defect in canalicular bilirubin excretion/MRP2). Gilbert syndrome is incorrect (unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia), and Rotor syndrome lacks the characteristic black liver.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Dubin–Johnson syndrome.

Reasoning: She has chronic mild jaundice since youth, a markedly elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin with normal AST/ALT/ALP, and an intraoperative “black” liver — the classic triad for Dubin–Johnson (autosomal‑recessive defect in canalicular excretion, MRP2). Rotor syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but the liver is not grossly pigmented; Gilbert syndrome causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. These findings point to Dubin–Johnson.
CORRECT
Yes — Dubin-Johnson syndrome. 

Reason: lifelong mild jaundice with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total 5.2 mg/dL, direct 4.0 mg/dL), otherwise normal liver enzymes, and a characteristically black, pigmented liver at surgery are classic for Dubin‑Johnson (autosomal recessive defect in canalicular excretion/MRP2). Rotor syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but does not produce a black liver; Gilbert syndrome causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
CORRECT
Dubin–Johnson syndrome — the black liver, predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, normal transaminases/ALP, and long-standing benign jaundice fit Dubin–Johnson, not Gilbert.

Reasoning: Dubin–Johnson causes chronic, mainly direct (conjugated) hyperbilirubinemia with normal AST/ALT/ALP and a characteristically black, pigmented liver. Gilbert causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (elevated indirect bilirubin) and would not produce a dark liver. (Rotor syndrome also gives conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but lacks the black liver pigment.)
CORRECT
Infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein–Barr virus. The classic findings — fever, severe pharyngitis with tonsillar exudates and soft‑palate petechiae, bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, macular rash, and hepatosplenomegaly in a young adult — are most consistent with EBV mononucleosis. Confirm with a heterophile (Monospot) test or EBV-specific serology; advise avoidance of contact sports because of splenic rupture risk.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

Reasoning: The classic triad—fever, pharyngitis with exudative tonsils and palatal petechiae, and prominent bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy—plus hepatosplenomegaly and profound fatigue strongly point to EBV mononucleosis. Rubella usually causes a milder illness with a face‑to‑body rash and postauricular nodes rather than exudative tonsillitis/hepatosplenomegaly. Confirm with a heterophile (Monospot) test or EBV serologies (VCA IgM); management is supportive and avoid ampicillin (causes rash) and contact sports while the spleen is enlarged.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute HIV infection (primary HIV/acute retroviral syndrome).

Reasoning: the presentation (1 week of fever, sore throat, profound fatigue, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, exudative pharyngitis, maculopapular trunk rash, and mild hepatosplenomegaly) fits acute retroviral syndrome and the patient has recent high‑risk sexual exposure. EBV mononucleosis is similar but a maculopapular rash is less common unless the patient received ampicillin, and the sexual risk and brief prodrome are more characteristic of primary HIV. Confirm with a 4th‑generation HIV antigen/antibody test and HIV RNA (PCR) if suspicion is high.
WRONG
Yes — most likely infectious mononucleosis (Epstein–Barr virus). 

Reason: the classic picture is fever, profound fatigue, exudative pharyngitis with soft‑palate petechiae, prominent posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, plus hepatosplenomegaly and a macular rash. This constellation in a young adult favors EBV mononucleosis over alternatives (acute HIV can cause fever/rash/lymphadenopathy but usually has more generalized nodes and less prominent exudative tonsillitis; CMV mononucleosis typically lacks marked pharyngeal exudates and posterior cervical nodes). A heterophile (Monospot) test or EBV serology would confirm.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is infectious mononucleosis (Epstein–Barr virus).

Reasoning: the combination of high fatigue, fever, marked posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, exudative tonsillitis, hepatosplenomegaly and a maculopapular rash fits EBV mono. Rubella can cause posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and soft‑palate petechiae (Forchheimer spots), but it usually causes a milder illness with a facial‑to‑trunk rash, is uncommon in vaccinated young adults, and does not typically produce exudative pharyngitis and splenomegaly. Confirm with a heterophile (Monospot) test and/or EBV serologies; test rubella IgM only if clinical suspicion remains.
CORRECT
Acute ascending cholangitis (acute bacterial cholangitis) from choledocholithiasis. She has Charcot’s triad — fever, jaundice and RUQ/epigastric pain — with leukocytosis and marked hyperbilirubinemia.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: Acute (ascending) cholangitis.

Reasoning: She has Charcot’s triad — fever, jaundice, and RUQ/epigastric pain — plus leukocytosis and marked hyperbilirubinemia, and a history of gallstones (likely CBD obstruction). These findings point to acute bacterial cholangitis rather than isolated acute pancreatitis.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: Acute ascending cholangitis.

Reason: She has the classic Charcot triad — fever, jaundice and biliary/epigastric pain — with leukocytosis and marked hyperbilirubinemia in the setting of gallstones, consistent with biliary obstruction complicated by infection. Acute cholecystitis is less likely because it usually does not produce significant jaundice; urgent antibiotics and biliary decompression (usually ERCP) are indicated.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: acute ascending cholangitis (acute cholangitis) due to common bile duct obstruction (likely choledocholithiasis).

Reasoning: she has Charcot’s triad — fever, jaundice (Tbili 6.4 mg/dL), and abdominal pain — plus leukocytosis and a history of gallstones. This pattern is most consistent with infected biliary obstruction rather than uncomplicated cholecystitis. Urgent biliary decompression (eg, ERCP) and IV antibiotics are indicated.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: Acute (ascending) cholangitis.

Reasoning: The patient has the classic Charcot triad — fever, jaundice, and abdominal (biliary) pain — plus leukocytosis and a marked hyperbilirubinemia (6.4 mg/dL) consistent with obstructive common bile duct pathology and infection. Acute pancreatitis would typically be supported by markedly elevated amylase/lipase and usually does not produce pronounced obstructive jaundice and fever unless complicated by a retained CBD stone.
CORRECT
Osgood–Schlatter disease — traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle: repetitive tensile stress from the quadriceps/patellar tendon on the developing apophysis causing inflammation, microavulsions/fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is Osgood–Schlatter disease — traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle.

Reasoning: In adolescent athletes, repetitive quadriceps contraction (running, jumping, squatting) produces traction on the patellar tendon insertion at the tibial tubercle, causing inflammation, microavulsion, and prominence of the apophysis. Osteopetrosis (diffuse increased bone density) would not present with isolated, activity‑related tibial tubercle pain.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle (Osgood–Schlatter) — repetitive tensile stress from the patellar tendon on the still‑open tibial apophysis causing inflammation, microavulsion/fragmentation and a painful swollen tubercle.

Reasoning: In adolescent athletes the secondary ossification center at the tibial tubercle is weak; repeated quadriceps contraction with running/squatting pulls on the patellar tendon, producing localized pain and enlargement of the tuberosity. This explains bilateral, activity‑related soreness without systemic findings.
CORRECT
Yes — this is Osgood‑Schlatter disease: a traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle. During adolescent growth spurts the secondary ossification center (apophysis) at the tibial tubercle is vulnerable; repetitive quadriceps contraction (running, jumping, squatting) pulls on the patellar tendon, causing microavulsions, inflammation and sometimes fragmentation of the tubercle, producing pain and a prominent, tender bump. Conservative treatment (rest/activity modification, NSAIDs, stretching/strengthening) is usually sufficient.
CORRECT
Osgood‑Schlatter disease — a traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle caused by repetitive pull of the patellar tendon on the immature secondary ossification center, producing inflammation/microavulsion and a tender, swollen tibial tubercle in active adolescents.  

Osteopetrosis is diffuse increased bone density from defective osteoclast resorption with fractures, anemia and cranial nerve issues, not an activity‑related, localized tibial tubercle pain in a healthy teen.
CORRECT
Most likely acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Rationale: The combination of weeks of fever, anorexia/weight loss, migrating bone/joint pain, pallor, petechiae/bruising (thrombocytopenia), hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and a CBC showing severe anemia, thrombocytopenia with leukocytosis is classic for acute leukemia in a child—ALL being the most common pediatric leukemia. Diagnosis is confirmed by peripheral smear/bone marrow showing blasts.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Reasoning: The child has constitutional symptoms, migratory bone/joint pain, pallor, petechiae/bruising (anemia + thrombocytopenia), hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis — a classic picture of acute leukemia in a child. Aplastic anemia would produce pancytopenia (including leukopenia), a hypocellular marrow, and typically no hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy, so it does not fit. Confirm with peripheral smear and bone marrow biopsy with flow cytometry.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Reasoning: a child with weeks of fever, weight loss, migratory bone/joint pain, pallor, easy bruising/petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy plus severe anemia and thrombocytopenia (with elevated white count) is classic for acute leukemia. Leukemia commonly causes marrow failure (anemia, thrombocytopenia), bone/joint pain from marrow expansion, and organ infiltration (hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy). Other possibilities (juvenile arthritis, ITP, infections, HLH) do not as neatly explain the combination of bleeding, marrow cytopenias and organomegaly. Confirm by peripheral smear (blasts) and bone marrow aspiration/flow cytometry.
CORRECT
Yes — most likely acute leukemia, most likely acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Reasoning: progressive weight loss, intermittent fevers, pallor, petechiae/bruising (from thrombocytopenia), hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy plus severe anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis are classic for bone‑marrow infiltration by malignant blasts. Migratory joint pain can occur from bone/bone‑marrow involvement. Alternative diagnoses (rheumatic fever, ITP, aplastic anemia, simple viral infection) do not account for the combination of lymphadenopathy/hepatosplenomegaly, cytopenias with leukocytosis and bleeding. 

Next step: examine peripheral smear for blasts and perform urgent bone marrow biopsy with flow cytometry/cytogenetics to confirm subtype and begin treatment.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute leukemia (eg, acute lymphoblastic leukemia).

Reasoning: The combination of bone/joint pain, constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, anorexia), pallor, petechiae/bruising, hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy points to marrow infiltration by malignant blasts. The CBC showing severe anemia, thrombocytopenia with leukocytosis is typical of acute leukemia (peripheral blasts often present). Aplastic anemia, by contrast, causes pancytopenia (including leukopenia), a hypocellular marrow and usually no hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy, so it does not fit this picture. Confirm with peripheral smear for blasts and bone marrow biopsy/flow cytometry.
CORRECT
These quad-screen results indicate fetal Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (especially B‑cell ALL).
CORRECT
The correct answer is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (especially B‑cell ALL).  

The quad‑screen pattern (↓AFP, ↑β‑hCG, ↓uE3, ↑inhibin A) suggests fetal Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), and children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of ALL (and also transient myeloproliferative disorder/acute megakaryoblastic AML in infancy). Hairy cell leukemia is not associated with Down syndrome.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (particularly B‑cell precursor ALL).

Reasoning: The quad‑screen pattern (↓AFP, ↑β‑hCG, ↓uE3, ↑inhibin A) is classic for trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). Children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of leukemia, most commonly B‑cell ALL (roughly a 10–20× increased risk). They also have a greatly increased risk of acute megakaryoblastic AML (M7), especially in infancy, but overall ALL is the single most common hematologic malignancy seen in Down syndrome.
CORRECT
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (especially B-cell ALL).

Reasoning: The quad-screen pattern (↓AFP, ↑β-hCG, ↓estriol, ↑inhibin A) is classic for fetal Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of leukemia overall, most commonly ALL (though they also have a notable risk for AML — particularly acute megakaryoblastic leukemia in infants).
CORRECT
The correct answer is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). 

Reason: The quad‑screen pattern (↓AFP, ↑β‑hCG, ↓estriol, ↑inhibin A) is typical of fetal Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of ALL (particularly B‑cell ALL) and also infant acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML M7); hairy cell leukemia is an adult disorder not associated with Down syndrome.
CORRECT
A postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (acute VSD) from transmural anterior MI. This mechanical complication typically occurs 3–7 days after MI (macrophage-mediated breakdown of necrotic myocardium), causes a new harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, acute left-to-right shunt, hypotension and cardiogenic shock — fitting her timing, murmur location, and hemodynamic collapse.
CORRECT
Conclusion: She most likely has a postinfarction ventricular septal rupture producing an acute VSD with cardiogenic shock.

Reasoning: New harsh holosystolic (pansystolic) murmur at the left lower sternal border on day 6 after an anterior MI, acute hypotension and tachycardia, and the typical 3–7 day timing (macrophage-mediated myocardial wall weakening) point to septal rupture. This differs from free‑wall rupture/tamponade (would cause muffled sounds and sudden collapse) and papillary muscle rupture (holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla from acute MR).
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is most consistent with an acute postinfarction ventricular septal rupture causing an acute left‑to‑right shunt and cardiogenic shock.

Reasoning: The patient had an extensive anterior transmural MI (ST elevation in V2–V5) and then acutely decompensated on day 6 with hypotension, tachycardia and a new harsh pansystolic (holosystolic) murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border — the classic timing (3–7 days) and murmur location for septal rupture after MI. Papillary‑muscle rupture would give a new holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla with acute pulmonary edema; free‑wall rupture causes tamponade without a harsh systolic murmur. Microscopic myocardial necrosis/macrophage infiltration weakens the septum and precipitates rupture, producing the sudden L→R shunt and hemodynamic collapse seen here.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is acute postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (VSD) causing a new left-to-right shunt and cardiogenic shock.

Reasoning: The complication classically occurs 3–7 days after transmural MI (patient’s day 6), produces a new harsh holosystolic/pansystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border with possible thrill, and precipitates hypotension/tachycardia and acute hemodynamic deterioration. Timing and murmur location argue against papillary muscle rupture (would give a new loud MR murmur at the apex/radiating to axilla) or free‑wall rupture/tamponade (would cause muffled heart sounds and rapid collapse without a loud pansystolic murmur). Declining troponins are consistent with an evolving, not ongoing, infarct.
CORRECT
Conclusion: The findings are most consistent with acute postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (VSD), not cardiac tamponade.

Reasoning: A new harsh holosystolic (pansystolic) murmur at the left lower sternal border 3–7 days after an anterior MI is classic for ventricular septal rupture with an acute left‑to‑right shunt, which produces hypotension, tachycardia and signs of heart failure. Free‑wall rupture with tamponade would produce sudden shock with JVD and muffled heart sounds (not a new harsh pansystolic murmur) and is usually rapidly fatal. The timing, murmur character and location point to VSD as the best explanation.
CORRECT
Malignant plasma cell proliferation (multiple myeloma) with excess monoclonal free light chains (Bence Jones proteins) precipitating in renal tubules — cast nephropathy causing eosinophilic intratubular casts, renal failure, and hypercalcemia from bone lysis.
CORRECT
Conclusion: The renal findings are most consistent with light-chain (Bence Jones) cast nephropathy from multiple myeloma—not nephritic syndrome.

Reasoning: Older man with back pain, weight loss and hypercalcemia suggests multiple myeloma. Monoclonal free light chains precipitate in renal tubules forming eosinophilic casts that obstruct and injure tubules, producing rising creatinine and characteristic biopsy/urine findings. Workup with serum/urine protein electrophoresis and bone marrow biopsy would confirm.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is myeloma cast nephropathy — excess monoclonal free light chains (Bence‑Jones proteins) precipitating with Tamm‑Horsfall protein in renal tubules, causing obstructing eosinophilic casts, tubular injury and interstitial inflammation.

Reasoning: The patient has the CRAB features (back pain/bone disease, hypercalcemia, renal failure, weight loss/fatigue in an elderly patient) consistent with multiple myeloma; the urine/bx finding of eosinophilic tubular casts is classic for light‑chain (myeloma) cast nephropathy. The precise mechanism is filtration of free monoclonal light chains that bind Tamm‑Horsfall mucoprotein in distal tubules and precipitate, producing obstructive casts and acute tubular/interstitial damage — more specific than the vague phrase “monoclonal protein overproduction.”
WRONG
Conclusion: This is myeloma cast nephropathy from monoclonal plasma-cell proliferation producing excess immunoglobulin light chains (Bence‑Jones proteins).

Reasoning: The triad of older age, back pain (bone involvement), weight loss/fatigue, hypercalcemia, rising creatinine, and eosinophilic intratubular casts is classic for multiple myeloma. Clonal plasma cells overproduce light chains that precipitate in renal tubules, forming eosinophilic obstructive casts and causing acute/chronic kidney injury. Confirm with serum/urine protein electrophoresis, free light‑chain assay, and bone marrow biopsy.
CORRECT
No — this is most consistent with myeloma cast nephropathy from monoclonal free light-chain (Bence Jones) overproduction due to multiple myeloma.

Reasoning: the age, back pain, weight loss and hypercalcemia, rising creatinine, and eosinophilic tubular casts point to light-chain (myeloma) cast nephropathy (tubular obstruction and inflammation). Nephritic syndrome would produce hematuria, RBC casts, oliguria and hypertension, which are not described. Confirm with serum/urine protein electrophoresis, serum free light chains and bone marrow biopsy.
CORRECT
His apnea is most likely central sleep apnea — failure of central respiratory drive (brainstem/medullary respiratory centers with decreased sensitivity to CO2), so there is cessation of respiratory effort despite an open airway (tracheostomy).
CORRECT
Most likely cause: central sleep apnea from loss of central respiratory drive (eg, brainstem/medullary dysfunction or respiratory depression from sedatives/opioids).

Reasoning: a tracheostomy bypasses upper‑airway obstruction, so persistent apneic episodes are not obstructive in origin. Continued apneas with absent inspiratory effort point to a central mechanism (impaired respiratory drive), which can be caused by brainstem lesions, metabolic derangements, or depressant medications.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Central sleep apnea — failure of respiratory drive from the brainstem (eg, sedative/opioid depression or central neurologic injury).

Reasoning: A tracheostomy bypasses upper‑airway obstruction, so persistent apneas are not obstructive. Continued pauses in breathing with an open airway indicate loss of ventilatory drive (central sleep apnea), commonly due to CNS causes or medications that depress the medullary respiratory center.
CORRECT
Central sleep apnea — a tracheostomy bypasses upper‑airway obstruction, so continued apneic episodes must be due to loss of respiratory drive (absent/insufficient ventilatory effort from the brainstem), not obstructive collapse.
CORRECT
Central sleep apnea — a tracheostomy bypasses the upper airway so obstructive events should be eliminated; ongoing apneas while sleeping indicate loss of respiratory drive (no respiratory effort), not a mechanical/ventilator obstruction.
CORRECT
Chronic chlorpromazine use causes pigmented drug deposits on the cornea and anterior lens — classically gray/brown corneal deposits with anterior subcapsular lens opacities (drug‑induced cataracts).
CORRECT
Conclusion: Not retinal hemorrhage — chlorpromazine classically causes pigmented corneal and lenticular deposits (leading to corneal opacities and cataract formation), which may be seen as brownish deposits/opacity on eye exam and can obscure the fundus view.

Reasoning: Chlorpromazine (a phenothiazine) causes dose‑dependent pigment deposition in the cornea and anterior lens (and can produce cataracts). Retinal hemorrhages are not a typical adverse effect of chlorpromazine (thioridazine at high doses can cause retinal pigmentary changes).
CORRECT
Conclusion: Long-term chlorpromazine classically produces corneal epithelial and anterior lens (subcapsular) pigmented deposits — on ophthalmoscopic exam you would most likely note a diminished red reflex from anterior lens opacities (pigmented cataract) and possibly visible pigment at the corneal/lenticular surface. True retinal lesions are not typical with chlorpromazine (retinal toxicity is more a thioridazine finding).

Reasoning: Phenothiazines cause pigment deposition in the cornea and anterior lens; these anterior changes can obscure the red reflex on ophthalmoscopy. Corneal deposits are real but are best seen on slit‑lamp exam rather than by direct ophthalmoscopy, which explains the confusion.
WRONG
Conclusion: Pigmented corneal epithelial/stromal deposits and anterior subcapsular lens opacities (brownish deposits/cataractous change), which can obscure the fundus view on ophthalmoscopy.

Reasoning: Long‑term phenothiazines (eg, chlorpromazine) cause photosensitization with progressive pigment deposition in the cornea and anterior lens capsule, producing brownish deposits and anterior subcapsular cataracts—best seen on slit‑lamp and can make ophthalmoscopic visualization of the retina difficult.
CORRECT
No — retinal hemorrhage is unlikely. Chronic chlorpromazine (a phenothiazine) classically produces pigmentary deposits in the cornea and anterior lens (visible as brown/golden deposits on ocular exam); frank retinal hemorrhages are not a typical side effect (retinal pigmentary changes are more associated with thioridazine or with vascular disease such as diabetic/hypertensive retinopathy).
CORRECT
Acute otitis media — acute suppurative middle ear infection (bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with middle‑ear effusion after a recent URI).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute otitis media.

Reasoning: a young child with fever and tugging at the ear following a recent upper respiratory infection is classic for AOM. Otoscopy in AOM typically shows a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with loss of normal landmarks and decreased mobility — unlike otitis externa, which causes external canal inflammation and pain with movement of the pinna and usually no systemic fever.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: otitis media with effusion (serous otitis media).

Reasoning: the history of a recent URI followed by persistent ear symptoms and the otoscopic appearance (amber fluid/air‑fluid level with an intact, non‑bulging tympanic membrane and loss of normal light reflex) are typical of middle‑ear effusion from eustachian tube dysfunction rather than acute bacterial otitis media. AOM usually shows a markedly bulging, erythematous TM and more prominent systemic/toxic signs; OME often follows a cold and is managed expectantly rather than immediately with antibiotics.
WRONG
Yes — acute otitis media. 

Reason: the child has acute onset ear pain/tugging and fever after a recent URI, and the otoscopic image is characteristic for AOM (bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with middle‑ear effusion). This differs from otitis externa (pain with tragal pressure and inflamed external canal) and from serous otitis media/effusion (typically no fever, TM may be retracted or amber with visible air‑fluid level rather than an acutely bulging, erythematous drum).
CORRECT
Acute otitis media. The history (toddler with fever and recent URI) and classic otoscopic findings — a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane — point to middle ear infection. Otitis externa typically causes canal erythema/discharge and marked pain with tragal/pinna manipulation and usually lacks systemic fever.
CORRECT
Repetitive traction (traction apophysitis) of the patellar tendon on the tibial tubercle — microavulsion/fragmentation of the tibial tubercle apophysis (Osgood–Schlatter disease) from repetitive quadriceps contraction during growth.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is Osgood–Schlatter disease — traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle from repetitive quadriceps/patellar-tendon pull.

Reasoning: Age (early adolescent boy), focal tenderness at the anterior superior tibia (tibial tubercle), pain with resisted knee extension, and x‑ray classically showing fragmentation/avulsion of the tibial tubercle point to overuse injury of the growth‑plate/apophysis. Iliotibial band syndrome causes lateral knee pain over the lateral femoral epicondyle, not anterior tibial tubercle pain.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is Osgood–Schlatter disease — traction apophysitis (repetitive microavulsion/inflammation and fragmentation of the tibial tubercle secondary ossification center from repeated quadriceps contraction).

Reasoning: A 12‑year‑old male athlete with gradual anterior superior tibial pain, tenderness at the tibial tubercle, pain with resisted knee extension, and a lateral x‑ray classically showing irregularity/fragmentation of the tubercle fits traction apophysitis. Lack of acute trauma argues against a true avulsion fracture; absence of erythema, fever, or effusion makes infection or septic arthritis unlikely; Sinding‑Larsen‑Johansson involves the inferior patella, not the tibial tubercle.
CORRECT
Yes — this is Osgood‑Schlatter disease (traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle).  

Reason: a 12‑year‑old boy in a running/kicking sport with anterior superior tibial tenderness that is worsened by resisted knee extension fits repetitive traction of the quadriceps on the immature tibial apophysis, producing microavulsion, fragmentation, and inflammation (visible on the lateral x‑ray). Management is conservative (activity modification, ice, NSAIDs, stretching).
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle (Osgood–Schlatter disease), not iliotibial band syndrome.

Reasoning: The pain is localized to the anterior superior tibia/tibial tubercle in an adolescent athlete and is reproduced by resisted knee extension (quadriceps/patellar tendon traction). The lateral x‑ray classically shows fragmentation/avulsion changes of the tibial tubercle. Pathophysiology is repetitive quadriceps contraction pulling on the secondary ossification center (microavulsion/apophysitis). Iliotibial band syndrome causes lateral femoral epicondyle/lateral knee pain in runners/cyclists and would not produce anterior tibial tubercle changes on exam or x‑ray.
CORRECT
Rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in the circle of Willis causing a subarachnoid hemorrhage — classically at the anterior communicating artery due to a congenital weakness in the arterial wall.
CORRECT
Most likely: subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured saccular (berry) aneurysm in the circle of Willis (classically the anterior communicating artery).

Reasoning: the description is a sudden "thunderclap" headache with nuchal rigidity and photophobia—classic for blood irritating the meninges. Lack of focal deficits fits SAH from an aneurysmal rupture. Carotid dissection more often produces neck/face pain, Horner’s syndrome or focal ischemic signs rather than the abrupt thunderclap headache with meningeal signs. Immediate noncontrast head CT (and CTA/cerebral angiography or LP if CT is negative) is indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely a ruptured saccular (berry) aneurysm causing subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Reasoning: the sudden "thunderclap" worst-ever headache, acute nuchal rigidity and photophobia (meningeal irritation) with no focal deficits are classic for blood in the subarachnoid space. Rupture of a berry aneurysm at a Circle of Willis arterial bifurcation (commonly anterior communicating artery) is the usual etiology; hypertension increases rupture risk. Meningitis, migraine, and intracerebral hemorrhage are less consistent with the abrupt presentation and exam findings.
CORRECT
Yes — the most likely etiology is a ruptured saccular (berry) aneurysm causing a subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Reasoning: the classic "thunderclap" headache (sudden, maximal at onset — "shot me in the back of my head") with nuchal rigidity and photophobia but no focal deficits is typical for SAH. Noncontrast head CT (or LP with xanthochromia if CT is negative) would confirm blood in the subarachnoid space. Other causes (migraine, meningitis, epidural/subdural hematoma, intracerebral bleed) are less consistent with this sudden presentation and exam.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (most likely from a ruptured saccular/berry aneurysm).

Reasoning: The sudden “worst headache”/thunderclap description with nuchal rigidity and photophobia are classic for meningeal irritation from blood in the subarachnoid space. Carotid dissection more typically causes unilateral neck/head pain, possible ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome or focal ischemic deficits — not prominent meningeal signs. The appropriate emergent workup would be noncontrast head CT (then lumbar puncture if CT is nondiagnostic).
CORRECT
This is euthyroid sick syndrome: acute severe illness–mediated inhibition of peripheral 5′-deiodinase activity → decreased conversion of T4 to active T3 (low T3, normal T4 and TSH, with increased rT3).
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is euthyroid sick syndrome from critical illness — cytokine-mediated inhibition of peripheral 5′-deiodinase leading to decreased conversion of T4 to active T3 (low T3, normal T4 and TSH; ↑rT3).

Reasoning: In sepsis/critical illness the peripheral conversion of T4→T3 is reduced (and reverse T3 is increased) without primary thyroid dysfunction; TSH is typically normal or low. Subacute (De Quervain) thyroiditis would cause thyrotoxicosis with suppressed TSH and elevated T4/T3 and usually painful/tender thyroid, which this patient lacks.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is nonthyroidal illness (“sick euthyroid”) caused by reduced peripheral conversion of T4 → T3 due to inhibition of type I 5′-deiodinase (often cytokine-mediated), with accumulation of inactive reverse T3.

Reasoning: In acute/severe illness (sepsis) you get low serum T3 with normal T4 and TSH — classic low-T3 syndrome. Normal TSH and a clinically euthyroid exam argue against primary thyroid disease; the biochemical pattern is explained by impaired peripheral deiodination (and increased rT3) rather than intrinsic thyroid failure.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is sick euthyroid syndrome due to reduced peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 — illness/cytokine-mediated inhibition of 5′-deiodinase with increased reverse T3.

Reasoning: In severe acute illness (sepsis, ICU), the earliest and most common abnormality is low T3 with normal T4 and a normal/low TSH. Cytokines and altered deiodinase activity inhibit conversion of T4 → T3 (type I 5′-deiodinase), shunting toward reverse T3 accumulation. Findings are not consistent with primary hypothyroidism (would have high TSH and low T4) or central hypothyroidism (low TSH).
CORRECT
No — the findings are most consistent with sick euthyroid syndrome (euthyroid sick) due to decreased peripheral T4→T3 conversion.

Reasoning: acute severe illness/sepsis commonly causes low free T3 with normal/low-normal free T4 and nonsuppressed TSH. Mechanism is cytokine-mediated inhibition of peripheral 5′-deiodinase (and increased production of reverse T3), lowering T3 levels without primary thyroid inflammation. De Quervain’s (subacute) thyroiditis would usually cause a painful, tender thyroid and biochemical hyperthyroidism (low TSH with elevated T4/T3 and elevated inflammatory markers), which this patient lacks.
CORRECT
The presence of vertical (or rotary/multidirectional) nystagmus on eye exam. Vertical nystagmus is classically associated with phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication.
CORRECT
Incorrect — the best finding would be nystagmus, classically vertical or rotary nystagmus.  

Reason: PCP intoxication commonly causes agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, analgesia and prominent nystagmus (especially vertical/rotary). Constricted pupils point toward opioid use, not PCP.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Prominent nystagmus — classically vertical (can be rotary or multidirectional) — is the physical finding most strongly suggestive of PCP intoxication.

Reasoning: PCP is a dissociative anesthetic that commonly produces marked nystagmus (especially vertical or rotary), psychosis/agitation, analgesia, hypertension and tachycardia. Nystagmus (particularly vertical) helps distinguish PCP from other sympathomimetics (cocaine/amphetamines) that produce similar agitation but not vertical/multidirectional nystagmus. Absence of nystagmus doesn’t rule out PCP, but its presence strongly supports the diagnosis.
CORRECT
Yes — prominent vertical (or rotary) nystagmus.

PCP (phencyclidine) classically produces dissociation with prominent nystagmus (often vertical or rotary), along with agitation, psychosis, tachycardia and hypertension. Vertical nystagmus is uncommon with typical stimulant intoxication and is a strong physical clue for PCP/ketamine-type intoxication.
CORRECT
No — prominent vertical (or rotary) nystagmus is most suggestive of PCP intoxication. PCP classically produces nystagmus, ataxia, agitation, and psychosis; pinpoint (constricted) pupils are characteristic of opioid intoxication, not PCP.
CORRECT
The spleen. Blunt left-upper-quadrant trauma with hypotension, peritonitis, and referred left-shoulder pain (Kehr sign from diaphragmatic/phrenic irritation by intraperitoneal blood) is most consistent with splenic injury.
CORRECT
Most likely the spleen.

Reason: Blunt abdominal trauma with hypotension, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness with guarding/rebound and a “seatbelt” pattern strongly suggests intra‑abdominal hemorrhage; left‑sided/referred shoulder pain (Kehr sign) points to splenic injury causing diaphragmatic irritation from hemoperitoneum. The spleen is the most commonly injured solid organ in blunt trauma.
CORRECT
Conclusion: The spleen is the most likely organ injured.

Reasoning: She has hypotension and peritoneal signs after blunt left‑sided thoracoabdominal trauma (seatbelt bruises) — classic for intra‑abdominal hemorrhage. Left shoulder/posterior shoulder pain is Kehr sign (referred pain via the phrenic nerve from diaphragmatic irritation), which points to a left upper‑quadrant source such as a splenic laceration. The liver would produce right‑sided findings; cardiac or thoracic causes are less consistent with the abdominal rigidity and hypovolemia.
CORRECT
Yes — splenic injury (likely rupture). 

Reason: blunt left‑sided abdominal trauma with hypotension and peritoneal signs suggests intraperitoneal hemorrhage, and the spleen is the most commonly injured organ in blunt trauma. Her sharp left‑shoulder pain is classic referred pain from diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign) via the phrenic nerve (C3–C5), localizing the problem to the left upper quadrant.
CORRECT
Spleen — the presentation (blunt abdominal trauma with hypotension/tachycardia, seatbelt ecchymoses, abdominal tenderness with rigidity, and left posterior shoulder pain) fits splenic rupture with intraperitoneal bleeding irritating the left hemidiaphragm (Kehr sign). The appendix is in the right lower quadrant and would not cause left shoulder pain or the acute hemorrhagic shock pattern seen here.
CORRECT
Coccidioides immitis (dimorphic fungus — spherules with endospores on H&E; mold phase with arthroconidia on Sabouraud/lactophenol cotton blue).
CORRECT
The infecting organism is Coccidioides (most likely Coccidioides immitis/posadasii) — pulmonary coccidioidomycosis.

Reasoning: The H&E showing large round spherules (containing endospores) is classic for Coccidioides in tissue; the organism is dimorphic and at 25–30°C grows as a fuzzy mold that produces arthroconidia (seen on lactophenol cotton blue). Cryptococcus neoformans would appear as budding yeast with a capsule and grow as yeast (not a fuzzy mold), so Cryptococcus is incorrect.
CORRECT
Blastomyces dermatitidis.

Reason: The H&E shows large, thick‑walled yeasts with broad‑based budding (classic for Blastomyces), and the organism grows as a fluffy mold at 25–30°C. The lactophenol cotton blue picture corresponds to the mold phase with conidia on short conidiophores ("lollipop" appearance). Coccidioides would display large spherules packed with endospores in tissue and barrel‑shaped arthroconidia in the mold phase, which does not match these findings.
WRONG
Conclusion: Coccidioides species (C. immitis/C. posadasii).

Reasoning: The H&E shows large spherules (rounded structures) filled with endospores — the classic tissue form of Coccidioides. The organism grows as a fluffy mold at ~30°C and the lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates arthroconidia/disjunctor-cell morphology seen in Coccidioides. These findings (spherules in tissue + mold with arthroconidia in culture) are diagnostic.
CORRECT
The infecting organism is Coccidioides species (Coccidioides immitis/posadasii).

Reasoning: The biopsy shows large spherules filled with endospores (classic tissue morphology of Coccidioides). The organism grew as a fuzzy mold at 30°C and the lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates arthroconidia—features of the saprophytic mold phase of Coccidioides. Cryptococcus neoformans would appear as encapsulated yeasts (mucoid colonies, narrow-based budding) rather than large spherules or a fuzzy mold on Sabouraud agar.
CORRECT
Acute compartment syndrome from prolonged compression ("found down" crush/ischemia) with subsequent reperfusion — causing muscle swelling/↑compartment pressure that compromises nerves and vessels (classic severe pain on passive stretch, tense swollen leg, loss of sensation, diminished pulses).
WRONG
Most probable cause: acute compartment syndrome from a crush/ischemic injury with reperfusion swelling.

Reasoning: being found down in cold suggests prolonged limb compression/ischemia; warming (reperfusion) causes capillary leak and muscle swelling within a nonexpandable fascial compartment, raising intracompartmental pressure. The tense, markedly swollen leg, pain on passive stretch, sensory loss, and diminished distal pulses are classic for compartment syndrome — an emergency requiring fasciotomy.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is acute compartment syndrome from prolonged compression/crush injury (found-down heroin intoxication) causing muscle swelling → increased intracompartmental pressure and ischemia.

Reasoning: The exam shows the classic signs of compartment syndrome — tense, swollen leg, severe pain out of proportion and worse with passive stretch, sensory loss and diminished distal pulses (pulses can be present early). Cellulitis causes erythema, warmth and diffuse tenderness but does not produce the acute pain with passive stretch, tense compartment, rapid neurovascular compromise, or require emergent fasciotomy. This is a surgical emergency (fasciotomy) and is associated with rhabdomyolysis from prolonged compression.
WRONG
Most probable cause: acute compartment syndrome from prolonged compression (crush-related rhabdomyolysis) after being down/unconscious.

Reasoning: the limb is markedly swollen, there is severe pain on passive stretch, sensory loss, tense compartment with relatively preserved pulses — classic signs of compartment syndrome, commonly caused by prolonged immobility/crush injury in intoxicated/homeless patients leading to muscle swelling and ischemia.
WRONG
Most probable cause: acute compartment syndrome from ischemia–reperfusion (reperfusion-associated edema) of the left lower leg from prolonged compression ("found down"/crush).

Reasoning: the history (heroin user found down), swollen tense leg, pain on passive stretch, sensory loss, and diminished pulses are classic for compartment syndrome. Prolonged ischemia during compression followed by reperfusion (rewarming) causes capillary leak and muscle edema, raising compartment pressures and producing the findings. This is a surgical emergency (urgent fasciotomy).
CORRECT
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) from systemic inflammation (most likely severe acute pancreatitis/sepsis). Inflammatory—neutrophil-mediated injury to the alveolar–capillary membrane increases permeability, producing protein-rich edema, diffuse bilateral infiltrates and a low PaO2/FiO2 (60/0.40 = 150), not cardiogenic failure.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute respiratory distress syndrome (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) from acute pancreatitis.

Reasoning: PaO2/FiO2 = 60/0.40 = 150 mm Hg (meets ARDS criteria), bilateral diffuse infiltrates, absence of cardiac failure signs (no JVD or murmur) and rapid onset after abdominal pain/epigastric tenderness (suggesting pancreatitis-induced systemic inflammation). Hospital-acquired pneumonia is unlikely so early (usually >48 hr) and would not explain the diffuse noncardiogenic pulmonary edema pattern.
CORRECT
Most likely: acute respiratory distress syndrome (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) from severe acute pancreatitis.

Reasoning: he has classic pancreatitis signs (epigastric tenderness, periumbilical ecchymosis) and then an acute hypoxemic respiratory failure with bilateral infiltrates and PaO2/FiO2 ≈150 on FiO2 0.40, consistent with moderate ARDS. Cardiac exam is normal, no JVD and no evidence of volume overload or cardiogenic pulmonary edema, making increased alveolar‑capillary permeability from systemic inflammation (pancreatitis‑induced ARDS) the best explanation.
CORRECT
Most likely: acute respiratory distress syndrome (noncardiogenic pulmonary edema) from severe acute pancreatitis.

Reasoning: He has epigastric tenderness and periumbilical ecchymosis (suggesting pancreatitis) and developed hypoxemia 12 hours later with bilateral lower‑lung opacities. PaO2/FiO2 ≈ 60/0.40 = 150 mm Hg (meets criteria for ARDS). Normal cardiac exam and absence of JVD make cardiogenic edema unlikely. Pancreatitis commonly triggers systemic inflammation and increased alveolar–capillary permeability causing ARDS.
CORRECT
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) — most likely noncardiogenic pulmonary edema from a systemic inflammatory insult (eg, pancreatitis/sepsis).

Reasoning: symptoms developed acutely (12 hr) after a recognized precipitant, CXR shows bilateral opacities, PaO2/FiO2 = 60/0.40 = 150 mm Hg (meets ARDS criteria), and there are no clinical signs of cardiogenic failure (normal cardiac exam, no JVD). Hospital‑acquired pneumonia is unlikely given the very short (12‑hr) interval after admission (HAP is defined ≥48 hr) and the diffuse bilateral picture consistent with ARDS.
CORRECT
The infant has Down syndrome (trisomy 21). She is most likely to have congenital heart disease—classically an endocardial cushion (atrioventricular septal) defect.
WRONG
Correct. The karyotype is trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), and children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (and also increased risk of AML), along with common problems like congenital AV septal defects and early-onset Alzheimer disease.
CORRECT
Conclusion: The baby has Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and is at increased future risk for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). 

Reasoning: The facial features, hypotonia, maternal age, and the karyotype are classic for trisomy 21; children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of ALL (and also congenital AV septal defects and early-onset Alzheimer disease). Macroorchidism is a feature of fragile X syndrome, not Down syndrome.
CORRECT
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

The infant’s features (flat face, upslanting palpebral fissures, hypotonia) and likely karyotype indicate trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), which carries a markedly increased risk of childhood ALL (and also congenital AV septal defects and early-onset Alzheimer disease later in life).
CORRECT
Correct — the infant most likely is at increased risk for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Reason: the clinical features and karyotype indicate trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). Children with Down syndrome have a markedly increased risk of childhood leukemias, especially ALL (and also acute megakaryoblastic AML), due to gene‑dosage effects from chromosome 21. Macroorchidism is a feature of fragile X syndrome, not Down syndrome.
CORRECT
Primary central nervous system lymphoma (EBV-associated diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the CNS).

Rationale: an HIV patient with CD4 depletion, a solitary large periventricular/corpus callosum mass, positive CSF EBV PCR, and subacute neuropsychiatric decline is classic for PCNSL. (Toxoplasmosis more often causes multiple lesions in basal ganglia and is less likely given TMP-SMX prophylaxis and positive EBV.)
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Primary CNS lymphoma (EBV-associated diffuse large B‑cell lymphoma).

Reasoning: In an HIV patient with CD4 90/µL, a solitary large (4.5 cm), periventricular/corpus callosum ring‑enhancing brain lesion and CSF positive for EBV DNA is classic for primary CNS lymphoma. Toxoplasmosis more often causes multiple smaller lesions and is not EBV‑positive, and HIV‑associated dementia produces diffuse cognitive impairment without a solitary enhancing mass.
CORRECT
Primary CNS lymphoma (EBV-associated diffuse large B‑cell lymphoma).

Reasoning: In an HIV patient with CD4 90/µL, a solitary large periventricular/corpus callosum ring‑enhancing mass strongly suggests PCNSL. Detection of EBV DNA in CSF is highly specific for EBV‑associated primary CNS lymphoma in immunocompromised patients. Toxoplasmosis is usually multiple lesions in basal ganglia/corticomedullary junction and would be less likely here (and TMP‑SMX prophylaxis further lowers that likelihood); glioblastoma can mimic this appearance but would not explain EBV+ CSF.
CORRECT
Primary central nervous system lymphoma (EBV-associated diffuse large B-cell lymphoma) is most likely.

Reasoning: In an AIDS patient with CD4 90, a solitary, large periventricular/corpus callosum enhancing mass favors PCNSL over toxoplasmosis (which more often causes multiple cortical–subcortical ring-enhancing lesions). Detection of EBV DNA in CSF is highly suggestive and commonly seen with AIDS-related primary CNS lymphoma. Additionally, the patient is on TMP‑SMX prophylaxis (which lowers risk of toxoplasmosis), further supporting lymphoma.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is primary CNS lymphoma (EBV-associated diffuse large B-cell lymphoma).

Reasoning: In an HIV patient with CD4 90, a solitary, large (4.5 cm), periventricular/callosal ring-enhancing mass and positive EBV DNA in CSF are highly characteristic of primary CNS lymphoma. HIV-associated dementia causes diffuse cognitive decline and brain atrophy or diffuse white-matter changes rather than a solitary enhancing mass, and would not produce EBV-positive CSF. (Toxoplasmosis—another HIV opportunist—more typically causes multiple lesions and EBV PCR is not positive in CSF.)
CORRECT
These pleural-fluid values meet Light's criteria for an exudative effusion (pleural/serum protein 3.8/7.0 = 0.543 > 0.5; pleural/serum LDH 54/82 ≈ 0.66 > 0.6). Exudates are most strongly associated with infection, malignancy, pulmonary embolism, and inflammatory disease — given the hepatosplenomegaly and systemic findings, a malignant process such as lymphoma is most likely.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is an exudative pleural effusion most strongly suggesting malignancy — classically lymphoma in this clinical context.

Reasoning: Light’s criteria are met (pleural/serum protein = 3.8/7.0 = 0.54 >0.5; pleural/serum LDH = 54/82 = 0.66 >0.6), so the effusion is exudative. Exudates are caused by infection, malignancy, pulmonary embolism, TB, etc. The concomitant hepatosplenomegaly and systemic signs make a hematologic malignancy (eg, lymphoma with malignant pleural involvement) the most likely association here, rather than an isolated pulmonary embolism.
WRONG
Conclusion: These findings are most consistent with a malignant (hematologic) pleural effusion from lymphoma (or leukemia).

Reasoning: The pleural/serum protein ratio (3.8/7.0 = 0.54) and pleural/serum LDH ratio (54/82 ≈ 0.66) meet Light’s criteria for an exudate. Hepatosplenomegaly and an abnormal hematologic workup point toward a hematologic malignancy (eg, lymphoma or leukemia) causing a malignant exudative effusion. Protein‑losing enteropathy would be expected to cause hypoalbuminemia and transudative effusions, so that is incorrect here.
WRONG
No — this is an exudative pleural effusion. Pleural/serum protein = 3.8/7.0 = 0.543 (>0.5) and pleural/serum LDH = 54/82 ≈ 0.66 (>0.6), meeting Light’s criteria for an exudate. Exudative effusions are most commonly due to malignancy, infection (parapneumonic/empyema), PE, or TB; the presence of hepatosplenomegaly makes a systemic malignancy such as lymphoma the most likely association.
WRONG
Pulmonary embolism. The pleural fluid meets Light’s criteria for an exudate (pleural protein/serum protein = 3.8/7.0 = 0.54 >0.5; pleural LDH/serum LDH = 54/82 ≈ 0.66 >0.6). PE commonly produces small, exudative (often bloody) pleural effusions and the presentation of tachycardia, tachypnea, low‑grade fever and basilar radiographic findings (eg, wedge infarct/Hampton’s hump) fits PE. (Hepatosplenomegaly would be atypical for isolated PE and might reflect a separate process.)
CORRECT
This is acute cardiogenic (flash) pulmonary edema from left‑sided heart failure — likely acute decompensation/ischemic LV dysfunction. Increased pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure caused transudation of fluid into the alveoli (orthopnea/PND, JVD, peripheral edema, CXR with pulmonary edema), and the rapid response to BIPAP plus diuretics/nitrates supports a cardiogenic cause. The low K+ and metabolic alkalosis are most consistent with recent loop‑diuretic therapy given as part of the acute treatment.
WRONG
Conclusion: His picture is most consistent with thiazide diuretic use (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide).

Reasoning: The acute nocturnal dyspnea, JVD and peripheral edema with CXR/ECG consistent with pulmonary edema indicate acute decompensated CHF. The lab pattern — hypokalemia (K 3.2), metabolic alkalosis (HCO3– 31) and mild hypercalcemia (Ca 10.9) — is characteristic of thiazides (contraction alkalosis, K wasting, decreased urinary Ca excretion). Loop diuretics would cause hypocalcemia, and ACE inhibitors would more commonly cause hyperkalemia, so hydrochlorothiazide best explains the abnormalities.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is acute decompensated congestive heart failure (flash pulmonary edema) with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to diuretic use / RAAS activation — not RTA type II.

Reasoning: PND/sudden nocturnal dyspnea, JVD and peripheral edema and rapid improvement with BiPAP/medical therapy point to cardiogenic pulmonary edema from CHF. The lab picture (low K+, elevated HCO3−) is consistent with contraction/metabolic alkalosis from loop (or thiazide) diuretics and/or aldosterone excess from RAAS activation in heart failure. Proximal RTA (type II) would cause a normal anion‑gap metabolic acidosis from bicarbonate wasting, not metabolic alkalosis, so RTA II is incorrect.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is acute cardiogenic (flash) pulmonary edema from decompensated congestive heart failure, with lab abnormalities reflecting diuretic‑induced contraction alkalosis (hypokalemia and mild hypercalcemia consistent with thiazide use).

Reasoning: Sudden nocturnal dyspnea, JVD, peripheral edema and the chest x‑ray/EKG findings are classic for acute pulmonary edema from heart failure. The metabolic alkalosis with low K+ and mildly high Ca2+ is typical of chronic diuretic use (thiazides cause hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypercalcemia) producing volume contraction that can precipitate decompensation. Renal tubular acidosis type II would produce metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.
WRONG
Conclusion: Hydrochlorothiazide use is the best explanation.

Reasoning: The patient’s labs show hypokalemia (K 3.2), metabolic alkalosis (HCO3− 31) and hypercalcemia (Ca 10.9) — the classic triad produced by thiazide diuretics (contraction alkalosis, K+ wasting, and increased renal Ca2+ reabsorption). Thiazides are commonly combined with ACE inhibitors (lisinopril) so the med list may have omitted it. Renal tubular acidosis type II is incorrect because RTA II produces a non‑anion gap metabolic acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia.
CORRECT
Mechanical gastric outlet obstruction from pyloric channel stenosis due to chronic peptic ulcer disease (most likely H. pylori–related duodenal ulceration with scarring), causing retention of gastric contents and nonbilious vomiting.
WRONG
No — this presentation is due to mechanical gastric outlet obstruction from pyloric stenosis caused by chronic peptic ulcer disease (scarring/fibrosis of the pylorus/duodenal bulb), not merely inflammation/edema.

Reasoning: classic duodenal-ulcer history (epigastric pain relieved by food/antacids, nocturnal pain), nonbilious vomiting of undigested food, succussion splash and tympanitic epigastric mass (gastric distention/retention), positive fecal occult blood, and electrolyte/volume abnormalities from prolonged vomiting all point to chronic pyloric narrowing (fixed obstruction) rather than transient inflammatory edema.
WRONG
Conclusion: Gastric outlet obstruction from peptic ulcer disease (duodenal/pyloric ulcer causing edema/scar stenosis) leading to nonbilious vomiting.

Reasoning: Nonbilious, undigested vomiting with succussion splash and an epigastric tympanic mass indicates retained gastric contents/gastric outlet obstruction. Epigastric pain that is relieved by food and worse at night, positive stool occult blood, smoking, and the acute presentation are classic for duodenal peptic ulcer disease; inflammation or chronic scarring at the pylorus/duodenal bulb narrows the outlet and produces the vomiting, dehydration, hypokalemia and elevated BUN. This explains the findings better than abnormal gastric rotation.
WRONG
Conclusion: Gastric outlet obstruction from pyloric channel stenosis due to chronic peptic (most likely duodenal) ulcer disease.

Reasoning: Nonbilious vomiting of undigested food, early satiety, succussion splash and an epigastric tympanitic mass indicate retained gastric contents/proximal obstruction. Epigastric pain that improves with food and positive stool occult blood point to duodenal ulcer/upper GI bleeding. Dehydration with hypokalemia is typical after repetitive vomiting. These findings are most consistent with scarring/stenosis of the pylorus from chronic peptic ulcer disease rather than a malrotation.
WRONG
Conclusion: His vomiting is due to gastric outlet obstruction from peptic ulcer disease — acute inflammation/edema of the pyloric channel (duodenal ulcer causing pyloric obstruction).

Reasoning: Nonbilious vomiting of undigested food, early satiety, a tympanitic epigastric mass and a succussion splash indicate retained stomach contents/gastric outlet obstruction. The epigastric pain that improves with food and is worse at night is typical for duodenal ulcer (PUD), and positive stool occult blood plus dark-brown emesis support upper-GI bleeding from an ulcer. In PUD, acute inflammation and edema of the pyloric channel (or chronic scarring/fibrosis) can obstruct gastric emptying — explaining his presentation.
CORRECT
Preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis.  
Findings: eyelid erythema/tender swelling with intact cranial nerves and no pain on extraocular movements — unlike orbital cellulitis which causes pain with EOM, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, or visual changes.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: dacryocystitis.

Reasoning: The child has a focal, tender, red swelling at the medial canthus (recurrent episodes), consistent with infection of the lacrimal sac from nasolacrimal duct obstruction. Lack of ophthalmoplegia, normal cranial nerves and no pain with extraocular movements argues against orbital cellulitis; the lesion’s medial-canthal location and purulence/recurrence make dacryocystitis more likely than diffuse preseptal cellulitis or a chalazion/hordeolum.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis.

Reason: the child has diffuse eyelid/periorbital redness, swelling and tenderness but intact cranial nerves and no pain or limitation with extraocular movements — findings localize the infection anterior to the orbital septum (preseptal cellulitis). A hordeolum is a focal, painful lid-margin abscess (a stye); orbital cellulitis would produce painful EOMs, ophthalmoplegia, possible vision/CN changes.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis.

Reasoning: acute, painful, erythematous eyelid swelling confined to the eyelid, tender to palpation, with intact cranial nerves and no pain on extraocular movements — findings localize the infection anterior to the orbital septum. Orbital cellulitis would cause ophthalmoplegia, pain with eye movements, proptosis or vision changes. A hordeolum is usually a focal lid-margin abscess, not diffuse eyelid swelling.
WRONG
Dacryocystitis.

The swelling is centered at the medial canthus over the lacrimal sac, is tender and erythematous, and there are no extraocular-movement deficits or cranial-nerve findings — features typical of an infected lacrimal sac (dacryocystitis) rather than a hordeolum, which is a localized eyelid-margin/stye lesion. Recurrent episodes are also compatible with chronic nasolacrimal duct obstruction leading to intermittent dacryocystitis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion).

Rationale: The patient has hypotonic hyponatremia (calculated serum osm ≈ 257 mOsm/kg) with inappropriately concentrated urine (Uosm 334 mOsm/kg) and urine Na >40 mEq/L, consistent with euvolemic hyponatremia from excess ADH.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH), most commonly due to ectopic ADH from small cell (oat cell) lung carcinoma.

Reasoning: The patient has hypotonic hyponatremia (low Na with low calculated serum osmolality ≈257 mOsm/kg) with inappropriately concentrated urine (Uosm 334 mOsm/kg) and elevated urine Na (45 mEq/L), consistent with euvolemic hyponatremia from SIADH. Normal renal function and electrolytes and the acute mental-status changes fit hyponatremic encephalopathy. Small cell lung cancer is a classic cause of paraneoplastic SIADH.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion).

Reasoning: The patient has hypotonic hyponatremia (calculated serum osmolality ≈257 mOsm/kg) with inappropriately concentrated urine (Uosm 334 mOsm/kg) and urine Na >40 mEq/L with normal renal function — a pattern typical of euvolemic hyponatremia from SIADH. Diabetes insipidus is wrong because DI produces dilute urine (very low Uosm) and hypernatremia or inability to concentrate urine, not the findings shown here. (You should also exclude hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency clinically/lab-wise.)
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

Reason: the patient has hyponatremia (Na 122) with inappropriately concentrated urine (Uosm 334 mOsm/kg) and urine Na >40 mEq/L, findings consistent with euvolemic hyponatremia from excess ADH.
