Reasoning: contralateral (right) hemiparesis and loss of vibration/proprioception indicate involvement of the corticospinal tract and medial lemniscus on the left. Ipsilateral tongue deviation to the left indicates left hypoglossal (CN XII) nucleus/nerve involvement. The triad (contralateral motor + dorsal column loss with ipsilateral CN XII palsy) is characteristic of medial medullary (Dejerine) syndrome. Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) and a pure cortical/internal capsule stroke would produce different cranial nerve and sensory patterns.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is medial medullary syndrome (Dejerine syndrome).

Reasoning: Ipsilateral tongue deviation (left) indicates a left CN XII palsy; contralateral (right) hemiparesis and loss of vibration/proprioception reflect involvement of the pyramidal tract and medial lemniscus — the classic triad of a medial medullary infarct. Lateral pontine (AICA) lesions produce CN VII/facial nucleus signs, decreased facial sensation, taste/ lacrimation issues and vestibular/hearing findings, not an isolated hypoglossal palsy.
CORRECT
Trachoma — chronic follicular conjunctivitis due to Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars A–C). Findings supporting this: endemic origin (Sudan), follicular conjunctivitis with limbal follicles, corneal neovascularization/pannus, matted lashes and preauricular lymphadenopathy.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Trachoma (ocular Chlamydia trachomatis infection, serotypes A–C).

Reason: Child from an endemic area with chronic unilateral follicular conjunctivitis, upper tarsal/limbal follicles and a superior corneal pannus (neovascularization), and preauricular nodes — classic for trachoma. Neisseria would produce a hyperacute, purulent conjunctivitis rather than the follicular changes and superior pannus described.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Trachoma (chronic ocular infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A–C).

Reasoning: The child is from an endemic area (Sudan) and has classic findings — follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and limbus, superior corneal neovascularization/pannus (12 o’clock), eyelash matting, and preauricular adenopathy — all characteristic of trachoma rather than acute inclusion conjunctivitis (D–K) or adenoviral conjunctivitis.
CORRECT
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is trachoma (ocular Chlamydia trachomatis, serovars A–C).

Reasoning: the child is from an endemic area (Sudan) and has a chronic, unilateral follicular conjunctivitis with tarsal follicles and limbal involvement, corneal haziness with neovascularization (pannus), and eyelash matting — classic findings of trachoma. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis would produce purulent discharge, allergic disease is bilateral and intensely itchy with papillae rather than follicles, and adenoviral conjunctivitis is usually more acute and bilateral. The chronic follicular changes and pannus point to trachoma.
CORRECT
Trachoma (ocular Chlamydia trachomatis infection).

Reason: The findings—follicular conjunctivitis on the tarsal conjunctiva and limbus, superior corneal neovascularization/pannus, limbal follicles (Herbert’s-pit–type changes), a subacute 2‑week course in a child from an endemic area (Sudan), and preauricular lymphadenopathy—are classic for trachoma. Neisserial (gonococcal) conjunctivitis is hyperacute with copious purulent discharge, severe pain/chemosis and rapidly progressive corneal ulceration, which this case does not show.
CORRECT
Acute appendicitis — in late pregnancy the enlarged uterus displaces the appendix upward, so appendiceal pain can present in the right upper quadrant. Fever, leukocytosis, vomiting and mild pyuria (irritation/contamination) support this diagnosis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute appendicitis.

Reasoning: In pregnancy the gravid uterus displaces the appendix upward/rightward, so appendicitis can present as acute RUQ pain with fever, vomiting, and leukocytosis. Mild pyuria can occur from local inflammation irritating the urinary tract and does not indicate a primary UTI.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute cholecystitis (acute gallbladder inflammation from gallstone disease).

Reasoning: classic RUQ localization with fever, leukocytosis and vomiting fits acute cholecystitis, and pregnancy increases gallstone risk. Mild pyuria can be incidental or reactive and does not outweigh the RUQ signs. Appendicitis in pregnancy can be displaced upward, but it usually begins periumbilically with migration and often produces more diffuse or right‑sided lower abdominal findings; absence of flank/CVA tenderness makes pyelonephritis less likely. Right‑upper‑quadrant ultrasound (look for gallstones, wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid) would be the next diagnostic step.
WRONG
Acute appendicitis — in late pregnancy the enlarged uterus displaces the appendix upward, so appendiceal pain classically migrates from periumbilical to the right upper quadrant.  
Fever, leukocytosis, vomiting, and an initial vague periumbilical pain that localizes fit appendicitis; mild pyuria can be seen from adjacent inflammation and is not diagnostic of a urinary infection. (In pregnancy, ultrasound ± MRI is used to confirm.)
CORRECT
Acute appendicitis.

Reasoning: She had initial dull periumbilical/epigastric pain that became localized and more severe, with fever, vomiting and leukocytosis — a classic migratory abdominal pain course. In late pregnancy the gravid uterus displaces the appendix upward, so appendicitis can present with right upper‑quadrant tenderness. Mild pyuria can occur with appendicitis (or from contamination) and does not make a UTI more likely here, which would usually produce urinary symptoms and suprapubic pain rather than RUQ pain.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: toxic megacolon from fulminant C. difficile (pseudomembranous) colitis.

Reasoning: recent IV antibiotics and watery diarrhea, high fever, hypotension, tachycardia, marked leukocytosis, metabolic acidosis with elevated lactate, severe abdominal pain/guarding, and abdominal radiograph classically showing a markedly dilated colon — all consistent with C. difficile–associated toxic megacolon.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Toxic megacolon from fulminant Clostridioides difficile (pseudomembranous) colitis.

Reasoning: Recent IV antibiotics followed by watery diarrhea, high fever, hypotension and tachycardia, marked leukocytosis (25,000), metabolic acidosis and elevated lactate indicate severe, toxin-mediated colitis with systemic toxicity. The abdominal radiograph classically shows markedly dilated colon (>6 cm) consistent with toxic megacolon. Crohn’s disease is unlikely here given the acute post‑antibiotic course and sepsis physiology.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: perforated colon from fulminant C. difficile colitis (pneumoperitoneum from colonic perforation).

Reasoning: recent IV antibiotics and several days of watery diarrhea point to C. difficile. Now she has fever, hypotension, tachycardia, marked leukocytosis, lactic acidosis and signs of peritonitis — all consistent with sepsis from bowel perforation. The abdominal radiograph demonstrates free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum), which distinguishes perforation from toxic megacolon (which shows marked colonic dilatation without free intraperitoneal air). This is a surgical emergency.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: fulminant Clostridioides difficile colitis causing toxic megacolon.

Reasoning: recent antibiotic exposure with several days of watery diarrhea, now severe abdominal pain and systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, hypotension), marked leukocytosis (25,000) and elevated lactate, plus the abdominal radiograph showing colonic dilation — this fits toxic megacolon from C. difficile (fulminant CDI). Urgent medical therapy (oral vancomycin ± IV metronidazole; consider rectal vancomycin if ileus) and surgical consultation are indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Toxic megacolon — almost certainly from C. difficile colitis.

Reasoning: recent IV antibiotics followed by watery diarrhea, high fever, marked leukocytosis, hypotension and lactic acidosis indicate severe toxic colitis/sepsis. The abdominal radiograph shows marked colonic dilation consistent with toxic megacolon (>6 cm) and there are peritoneal signs. Crohn disease is a chronic transmural inflammatory bowel disease and is far less consistent with this acute, post‑antibiotic, fulminant presentation.
CORRECT
Rhabdomyolysis with myoglobinuria causing hyperkalemia. (Urine dipstick positive for “blood” from myoglobin without RBCs; ECG changes from hyperkalemia — peaked T waves/widened QRS.)
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Rhabdomyolysis with resulting hyperkalemia (myoglobinuria).

Reasoning: Found down after MDMA use with weakness and slow responses → prolonged immobility/seizure/heat-related muscle breakdown. Urine dipstick positive for “blood” without RBCs is classic for myoglobinuria. The ECG changes (peaked T waves/widening consistent with hyperkalemia) are explained by massive muscle lysis releasing potassium.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Acute hyperkalemia secondary to rhabdomyolysis (stimulant‑induced muscle breakdown).

Reasoning: She was found down after stimulant use (MDMA/cocaine) — risk for prolonged exertion/immobilization and muscle breakdown. The urine dipstick is “blood” positive (most consistent with myoglobinuria when there are no RBCs), and muscle breakdown releases potassium causing weakness and the classic ECG changes (peaked T waves/widened complexes). This fits rhabdomyolysis producing life‑threatening hyperkalemia — check CK and serum K immediately and treat hyperkalemia emergently while giving IV fluids for rhabdo.
CORRECT
Most likely: hyperkalemia due to rhabdomyolysis (myoglobinuria).

Reasoning: found down at a rave with MDMA use → prolonged muscle breakdown; urine dip is “blood” positive from myoglobin (not hematuria). Muscle weakness and the ECG (peaked T waves/widening QRS) are classic for hyperkalemia from rhabdomyolysis — expect very high K+ and markedly elevated CK.
CORRECT
Rhabdomyolysis.

Reasoning: a young drug-intoxicated patient found down with muscle weakness and a urine dipstick positive for “blood” is classic for myoglobinuria from muscle breakdown. The ECG likely shows hyperkalemic changes (e.g., peaked T waves) from release of intracellular K+—a hallmark of rhabdomyolysis. A UTI would usually present with dysuria/frequency, leukocyte esterase/nitrites or bacteriuria, not isolated dipstick “blood” without RBCs. Confirm with serum CK, creatinine, and serum potassium; manage fluids and monitor electrolytes/ECG.
CORRECT
Prolonged status epilepticus causing focal cerebral ischemic injury (neuronal necrosis from excitotoxicity/relative hypoperfusion) in the left MCA cortical territory — i.e., an ischemic infarct rather than transient Todd paralysis.
WRONG
Conclusion: The findings most likely reflect cortical laminar necrosis from excitotoxic/hypoxic injury after prolonged status epilepticus affecting the left temporoparietal cortex.

Reasoning: A >50-minute generalized seizure (status epilepticus) produces sustained metabolic demand, glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and local hypoxic/ischemic injury that selectively kills cortical pyramidal neurons in superficial layers (laminar necrosis). This produces delayed, persistent focal cortical deficits (hemiparesis, homonymous hemianopsia, receptive aphasia) days to weeks after the insult — unlike Todd paralysis (transient, usually <48 h) or an immediate embolic stroke.
CORRECT
Most likely: focal cortical neuronal injury (ischemic/excitotoxic necrosis) from the prolonged seizure (status epilepticus) in the left cerebral hemisphere.

Reasoning: he had a prolonged (>30–50 min) convulsion—status epilepticus—which can cause permanent focal cortical damage by excitotoxicity/ischemia. The deficits (right hemiparesis, right homonymous hemianopia, receptive aphasia) localize to left cortical MCA/temporo‑parietal regions. Todd paralysis would be transient (hours–days) and a brain abscess would usually have fever, systemic signs and a more subacute course; neither fits this presentation as well as seizure‑induced cortical necrosis.
CORRECT
Most likely: an ischemic infarct of the left MCA territory (cortical neuronal necrosis from prolonged seizure/status epilepticus).

Reasoning: his deficits (right hemiparesis, right homonymous hemianopia, receptive aphasia) localize to the left MCA distribution. Todd paralysis is transient (hours to, at most, a few days) and would not persist 2 weeks. A 50-minute generalized seizure/status epilepticus produces very high metabolic demand and can cause local hypoxia/excitotoxic neuronal death (cortical laminar necrosis)/ischemic infarction in the affected hemisphere, which explains the persistent focal deficits.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Cortical laminar necrosis from prolonged seizure (status epilepticus) causing selective cortical neuronal death.

Reasoning: He had a prolonged generalized seizure (≈50 minutes), which produces excitotoxic injury (excess glutamate/Ca2+ influx) that selectively kills cortical pyramidal neurons in a laminar pattern. This delayed neuronal loss in the dominant left temporoparietal/occipital cortex explains his new right hemiparesis, right homonymous hemianopsia and receptive aphasia that developed days–weeks after the event.
CORRECT
Most likely a central retinal artery occlusion (acute retinal ischemia from an embolus, e.g., atherosclerotic/cholesterol plaque). 

Reason: sudden, painless monocular vision loss in an atherosclerotic patient with a pale (ischemic) retina and slight disc swelling and no hemorrhages — classic for CRAO (vs. CRVO, optic neuritis, or giant-cell arteritis).
WRONG
Most likely a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) from an embolus (eg, cholesterol plaque from carotid/cardiac source).

Reasoning: acute, painless monocular vision loss in a patient with vascular disease, plus a pale retina with mild disc edema and no hemorrhages, is classic for CRAO. An ophthalmic artery occlusion would also affect choroidal flow (abolishing the cherry‑red spot and producing more diffuse ischemia) and is less likely here.
WRONG
Most likely: nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) — ischemia of the optic nerve head (posterior ciliary artery territory).

Reasoning: sudden, painless monocular vision loss in a patient with vascular risk factors (HTN, atherosclerosis) with fundus showing a pale, slightly swollen optic disc is classic for AION. Retinal detachment is unlikely because it usually produces flashes/floaters and an elevated, folded retina appearance rather than generalized disc pallor/edema; central retinal artery occlusion would show a pale retina with a cherry‑red spot at the fovea rather than isolated disc pallor. Arteritic AION (giant cell arteritis) is another cause in patients >50 and must be considered if systemic signs/↑ESR are present, but the presentation here fits nonarteritic AION.
WRONG
Most likely a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) from an embolus.

Reasoning: sudden, painless monocular vision loss in a patient with vascular risk factors, fundus showing generalized retinal pallor with slight disc edema and absence of hemorrhages fits CRAO (classically pale retina with a cherry‑red spot). Retinal detachment typically causes flashes/floaters and a “curtain” defect; central retinal vein occlusion shows extensive retinal hemorrhages. This is an ocular emergency requiring immediate ophthalmology evaluation.
WRONG
Most likely a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) from an embolus.

Reason: sudden, painless monocular vision loss in a patient with vascular disease + fundus showing diffuse retinal pallor with slight disc edema and no hemorrhages is classic for CRAO (often with a cherry‑red spot at the fovea). Retinal detachment usually has preceding flashes/floaters and a “curtain” defect; central retinal vein occlusion shows many retinal hemorrhages.
WRONG
Acute mesenteric ischemia — most likely an embolic occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery. 

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulation, pain out of proportion to exam (diffuse tenderness, decreased bowel sounds), high anion-gap metabolic acidosis (consistent with lactic acidosis from gut ischemia), and elevated amylase (can occur with intestinal ischemia). These findings are classic for acute mesenteric ischemia.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute mesenteric ischemia (embolus to the superior mesenteric artery) rather than acute cholecystitis.

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain over hours in a patient with atrial fibrillation who is not anticoagulated is classic for an embolic mesenteric ischemia. Exam with diffuse tenderness and decreased bowel sounds, high anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HCO3 12) and mildly elevated amylase support bowel ischemia/necrosis (amylase can be nonspecifically elevated). Acute cholecystitis would classically cause RUQ tenderness/Murphy’s sign and more localized findings, not sudden diffuse pain with metabolic acidosis. Urgent CT angiography and vascular/surgical evaluation are indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute mesenteric ischemia (likely embolic occlusion of the SMA from atrial fibrillation).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain in an elderly patient with untreated atrial fibrillation and multiple vascular risk factors, metabolic acidosis (HCO3 12 consistent with lactic acidosis), minimal/localizing abdominal findings early (pain out of proportion), and a modestly elevated amylase (can occur with ischemia). These features fit embolic mesenteric ischemia better than acute pancreatitis (no classic epigastric/back pain, no vomiting or gallstone/alcohol history) or simple bowel obstruction. Definitive diagnosis requires prompt CT angiography and urgent vascular/surgical intervention.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute mesenteric ischemia — probably an embolic SMA occlusion.

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain in an elderly patient with atrial fibrillation who is not anticoagulated and extensive vascular disease is classic for embolic mesenteric ischemia. Findings supporting it include "pain out of proportion" with relatively nonspecific abdominal exam, metabolic acidosis (HCO3 12) from intestinal ischemia, and an elevated amylase (can occur with bowel ischemia). Acute pancreatitis is less likely given the clinical context and absence of typical risk factors/symptoms. Confirm with urgent CT angiography and prompt vascular/surgical management.
CORRECT
Acute mesenteric ischemia — more likely than acute cholecystitis.

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain in an elderly patient with atrial fibrillation who is not anticoagulated strongly suggests an embolic event to the mesenteric vessels. The exam shows diffuse tenderness with relatively few focal findings (pain out of proportion), labs show metabolic acidosis (HCO3 12) and an elevated amylase — findings that can occur with intestinal ischemia. Acute cholecystitis typically presents with RUQ pain, fever, Murphy’s sign, and right‑sided findings on exam/imaging and would not explain the metabolic acidosis or the AF‑related embolic risk.
CORRECT
Cluster headache. 

Reason: severe unilateral periorbital pain with ipsilateral lacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis and miosis, restless behavior during attacks, male smoker in his 30s with morning/seasonal pattern — classic trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. Lack of response to indomethacin also argues against paroxysmal hemicrania.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: cluster headache.

Reasoning: severe, unilateral periorbital/forehead pain with ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, lacrimation and rhinorrhea, restlessness during attacks, male smoker with multiple daily morning episodes — all classic for cluster (Horton) headache. Lack of response to indomethacin argues against indomethacin-responsive paroxysmal hemicrania; tension headache would be bilateral and nonautonomic.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Cluster headache (a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia).

Reasoning: The presentation—excruciating unilateral periorbital/frontotemporal pain with ipsilateral autonomic signs (ptosis/miosis, lacrimation, rhinorrhea), male smoker in his 30s, seasonal/periodic attacks and marked restlessness during attacks—is classic for cluster headache. Lack of response to indomethacin helps exclude indomethacin-responsive headaches (paroxysmal hemicrania/hemicrania continua), which are the main alternatives.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: cluster headache.

Reasoning: Recurrent, severe unilateral periorbital/temporal pain with ipsilateral autonomic signs (tearing, rhinorrhea, ptosis and miosis = partial Horner’s), a circadian pattern (morning attacks), male smoker, and marked restlessness are classic for cluster headache. Lack of response to indomethacin makes indomethacin‑responsive paroxysmal hemicrania unlikely; trigeminal neuralgia and migraine have different pain quality/duration and lack this autonomic picture.
CORRECT
Cluster headache.  

This patient has recurrent, severe unilateral periorbital/temporal pain with ipsilateral autonomic features (tearing, rhinorrhea, ptosis with miosis = partial Horner’s), circadian/periodic timing (morning attacks, multiple/day), marked restlessness during attacks, and a typical demographic (young adult male smoker). Tension headache is usually bilateral, pressing/tightening and mild–moderate, associated with pericranial tenderness but lacks the unilateral autonomic signs and the excruciating, stereotyped short attacks seen here.
CORRECT
Traumatic pancreatitis from a pancreatic injury (eg, pancreatic contusion/duct injury from blunt epigastric trauma). Classic delayed epigastric pain, vomiting and fever after handlebar-type trauma; initial CT can be normal early.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: traumatic pancreatic injury with pancreatic duct disruption causing acute (traumatic) pancreatitis.

Reasoning: A direct blow to the epigastrium from handlebars classically injures the pancreas; symptoms often evolve over days as inflammation/enzymatic injury and ductal leaks develop. Early CT can be normal, and delayed presentation with worsening epigastric pain, vomiting and fever fits pancreatic injury/pancreatitis. Diagnosis is supported by elevated amylase/lipase and is best further evaluated with repeat imaging (contrast CT, MRCP) or ERCP if ductal disruption is suspected.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: traumatic pancreatic injury causing acute (posttraumatic) pancreatitis — possibly with pancreatic duct disruption.

Reasoning: a direct blow from the handlebars compressing the epigastrium against the spine classically injures the pancreas. Small pancreatic contusions or ductal injuries are often missed on early CT and present with delayed epigastric pain, fever, vomiting and anorexia over several days. Abdominal compartment syndrome is unlikely here (would present with tense/distended abdomen, oliguria, respiratory compromise and hemodynamic instability), which this patient lacks.  

Next steps: check serum amylase/lipase, obtain repeat imaging (contrast-enhanced CT after 48–72 h or MRCP) and involve surgery/GI (possible ERCP if duct injury suspected).
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: traumatic pancreatic injury causing acute pancreatitis (possible pancreatic duct contusion/transsection).

Reason: a direct epigastric blow from handlebars classically injures the pancreas; pancreatic injury can be radiographically occult early after trauma and present days later with worsening epigastric pain, vomiting, anorexia and fever. Lab tests (serum amylase/lipase) and repeat imaging/ERCP/contrast-enhanced CT are used to confirm and assess duct involvement.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: pancreatic duct injury (pancreatic transection leading to delayed pancreatitis).

Reasoning: handlebar blunt epigastric trauma classically compresses the pancreas against the spine and can disrupt the pancreatic duct. Ductal injury often presents subacutely — worsening epigastric pain, anorexia, vomiting and fever days later — and early CT can be falsely normal. Diagnosis is suggested by elevated amylase/lipase and confirmed with repeat contrast CT/MRCP or ERCP; management ranges from endoscopic stenting/drainage to operative repair depending on duct involvement. Abdominal compartment syndrome is unlikely given the soft, non‑distended abdomen and hemodynamic stability.
CORRECT
Joint aspiration showing needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals that are negatively birefringent on polarized light microscopy (yellow when aligned with the polarizer), consistent with gout.
WRONG
Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals on arthrocentesis (yellow when aligned parallel to polarized light).

Reason: Acute monoarticular hot knee in a patient taking hydrochlorothiazide — a thiazide that decreases uric acid excretion — is most consistent with gout. Pseudogout (rhomboid, positively birefringent calcium pyrophosphate crystals) is less likely here.
WRONG
Conclusion: Purulent synovial fluid with a very high WBC count (>50,000/µL, neutrophil predominant) and likely positive Gram stain/culture (eg, Staphylococcus aureus) — consistent with septic arthritis.

Reasoning: This is an acute, monoarticular, hot painful knee in a diabetic patient with recent trauma and radiographic effusion — classic for septic arthritis. Anti‑CCP is a marker of chronic rheumatoid arthritis (symmetric, erosive polyarthritis), not an acute monoarticular infection.
WRONG
No — this presentation is most consistent with septic arthritis. You would likely find purulent, neutrophil‑predominant synovial fluid (typically >50,000 WBCs), low synovial glucose, and often organisms (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) on Gram stain/culture. Reason: acute, severe monoarticular pain with a hot, swollen knee, diabetes (increased risk), and radiographic effusion fit septic arthritis rather than rheumatoid disease.
WRONG
No — the more likely finding is rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent calcium pyrophosphate (CPPD) crystals on synovial fluid analysis (pseudogout). 

Reason: acute, hot monoarticular knee with an x-ray that typically shows chondrocalcinosis (cartilage calcification) and a recent trauma precipitating an attack are classic for CPPD/pseudogout; anti-CCP would point to chronic rheumatoid arthritis, which doesn't fit this presentation.
CORRECT
Bone marrow aspiration/biopsy with immunophenotyping demonstrating >25% lymphoblasts (TdT positive) — typically B‑cell markers (eg, CD10+, CD19+) consistent with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Bone marrow aspiration/biopsy with flow cytometry (showing ≥25% blasts/lymphoblasts consistent with acute lymphoblastic leukemia) would confirm the diagnosis.

Reasoning: The child with Down syndrome, bone pain, lymphadenopathy, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and marked leukocytosis suggests acute leukemia (most commonly ALL in children). Definitive diagnosis requires demonstration of marrow blasts and immunophenotyping (eg, TdT+, CD10+/CD19+ for precursor B‑ALL), not echocardiography.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Bone marrow aspiration/biopsy with flow cytometric immunophenotyping to demonstrate ≥25% lymphoblasts (and determine B- vs T‑cell lineage) — this is the definitive test for acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

Reasoning: The presentation (Down syndrome, bone pain, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, anemia, thrombocytopenia and very high WBC) is highly suggestive of ALL. Peripheral smear can be suggestive, but diagnosis and classification require bone marrow examination showing increased blasts plus immunophenotyping (and cytogenetics for risk/prognosis).
CORRECT
Yes — a bone marrow aspirate/biopsy (with flow cytometry/cytogenetics) is the test needed to confirm acute leukemia. 

Reason: the history (Down syndrome), fever, bone pain, lymphadenopathy and CBC (anemia, severe thrombocytopenia, marked leukocytosis suggestive of circulating blasts) point to acute leukemia. A peripheral smear may show blasts, but definitive diagnosis and lineage/subtype determination require bone marrow evaluation showing ≥20–25% blasts and immunophenotyping.
CORRECT
No — bone marrow aspiration/biopsy with flow cytometry is most likely to confirm the diagnosis.

Reasoning: the combination of fatigue, bone pain, fever, lymphadenopathy, anemia, thrombocytopenia and marked leukocytosis in a child (and Down syndrome increases leukemia risk) points to acute leukemia. Peripheral blood may show blasts, but definitive confirmation requires bone marrow biopsy demonstrating increased blasts and immunophenotyping to define lineage (eg, ALL vs AML). Echocardiography would not establish this diagnosis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: depersonalization/derealization disorder.

Rationale: she describes recurrent episodes of feeling detached from herself/“outside of my body” with preserved insight, normal neuro exam, no substance or medical cause, and symptoms persisting for weeks. This pattern is classic for depersonalization/derealization rather than psychosis, primary sleep disorder, or neurological disease.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Depersonalization/derealization disorder.

Reasoning: She describes recurrent experiences of feeling “outside of my body” and “watching myself” (classic depersonalization/derealization) with intact reality testing, distress, and symptoms persisting for weeks. She has no frank hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thought/behavior, or other psychotic signs required for brief psychotic disorder, and no neurologic findings. Important next steps are to rule out substance effects and medical causes (eg, seizure, head injury, drug intoxication/withdrawal).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: narcolepsy (with hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations / excessive daytime sleepiness).

Reasoning: her “nightmares” occur during sleep and at sleep–wake transitions (sometimes while awake), and she describes dream‑like out‑of‑body/watch‑myself experiences — classic for hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations rather than primary depersonalization. The chronic fatigue/excessive daytime sleepiness fits narcolepsy. Neurologic exam normal and no substance history also supports a sleep disorder. 

Next steps: ask about cataplexy and sleep paralysis, obtain overnight polysomnography followed by a multiple sleep latency test, and consider referral to a sleep specialist.
WRONG
Most likely: depersonalization/derealization disorder.

Reasoning: Her core symptom is recurrent episodes of feeling detached from herself—“outside of my body,” “watching myself”—which is the hallmark of depersonalization (sometimes with derealization). She has preserved reality testing, a normal neuro exam, no substance use or medical causes, no trauma or psychotic symptoms to suggest PTSD or schizophrenia, and the symptoms have been persistent for weeks and causing distress. Panic disorder/narcolepsy/seizure are less likely because she lacks panic attacks, classic sleepiness/cataplexy or focal neuroseizure features.
CORRECT
I still think the most likely diagnosis is depersonalization/derealization disorder (depersonalization), not brief psychotic disorder.

Reasoning: her chief symptom is a subjective sense of detachment (“outside of my body,” “watching myself”), which is a classic dissociative experience with preserved insight and reality testing. Brief psychotic disorder requires frank psychotic symptoms — delusions, hallucinations, grossly disorganized speech or behavior — which she does not have. She describes dissociation rather than psychosis, and there are no signs of disorganization, loss of contact with reality, or substance/medical causes on the history/exam to suggest an acute psychotic episode. Assessment for substance use, mood/anxiety disorders, and medical causes would still be appropriate.
CORRECT
Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (idiopathic hypertrophic subaortic stenosis). The sustained/double apical impulse and S4 indicate a hypertrophied, stiff ventricle, and HCM is a classic cause of exertional syncope/sudden death in young athletes.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Hypertrophic (obstructive) cardiomyopathy (HCM/HOCM).

Reasoning: A young athlete with exertional syncope/sudden collapse is classic for HCM due to ventricular arrhythmia/obstruction. Findings fit HCM — a double (sustained/forceful) apical impulse and an S4 from a stiff hypertrophied ventricle, and a prominent A wave from atrial contraction against a noncompliant ventricle. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is less likely given the age, presentation with sudden exertional syncope, and typical HCM physical findings.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM, aka idiopathic hypertrophic subaortic stenosis).

Reasoning: Young athlete with exertional syncope and regained consciousness suggests a primary cardiomyopathic arrhythmic/obstructive cause. The exam constellation — a sustained/double apical impulse and an S4 (forceful atrial contraction into a stiff hypertrophied ventricle) and a prominent A wave — is classic for left ventricular hypertrophy with decreased compliance as seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. An outflow‑tract obstruction (HOCM/IHSS) can produce exertional syncope and sudden collapse; the murmur is variable and may be absent at the time of exam. Other causes of sudden syncope in young athletes (e.g., ARVD, congenital coronary anomalies, channelopathies) do not account for the palpable double apical impulse and S4.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: hypertrophic (obstructive) cardiomyopathy.

Reasoning: sudden exertional syncope/sudden collapse in a young athlete is classic for HCM. The physical findings — a palpable double (sustained/“double tap”) apical impulse and an S4 from a stiff, hypertrophied ventricle — strongly point to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The outflow tract murmur of HCM can be variable and may be faint or absent at rest, so lack of an audible murmur does not rule it out.
CORRECT
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Reasoning: Sudden exertional syncope in a young athlete strongly suggests HCM (a common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes). The exam findings — a palpable double/apical impulse and an S4 — are classic for a hypertrophied, stiff left ventricle. A prominent A wave can occur from vigorous atrial contraction against a noncompliant ventricle. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is less likely here because it typically presents later in life with progressive congestive signs (and not with sudden exertional collapse in a young athlete).
CORRECT
Infective endocarditis (likely right‑sided/tricuspid in an IV drug user) with Janeway lesions — painless erythematous/hemorrhagic macules from septic emboli (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus).
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Infective endocarditis with Janeway lesions (septic embolic lesions), not ecthyma gangrenosum.

Reasoning: The patient has IV drug use, a new systolic murmur, and a persistent cutaneous lesion consistent with painless erythematous/hemorrhagic macules on the palms/soles (Janeway lesions) from septic emboli. Ecthyma gangrenosum is classically a rapidly progressive necrotic ulcer with black eschar from Pseudomonas bacteremia in profoundly neutropenic/critically ill patients, which does not fit this presentation.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Infective endocarditis (probably right‑sided/tricuspid in this IV drug user) with septic embolic Janeway lesions of the skin.

Reasoning: He has IV drug use, low‑grade fever, a new systolic murmur, and the described skin lesion is most consistent with painless, erythematous/hemorrhagic macules (Janeway lesions) from septic emboli. This fits S. aureus tricuspid endocarditis in IV drug users. Necrotizing fasciitis is unlikely because there is no severe out‑of‑proportion pain, rapid progression, systemic toxicity, crepitus, or bullae typical of necrotizing soft‑tissue infection.
WRONG
Kaposi sarcoma — vascular, violaceous skin lesions in an HIV-positive, immunocompromised patient (HHV‑8 associated). The presentation (chronic/persistent purple macules/nodules rather than severe pain, systemic toxicity, or rapidly spreading necrosis) and his untreated HIV make Kaposi sarcoma far more likely than necrotizing fasciitis.
WRONG
Ecthyma gangrenosum — most consistent with Pseudomonas bacteremia in an immunocompromised patient.

Reasoning: The lesion’s central necrosis/black eschar with surrounding erythema, a subacute course, and the patient’s immunosuppression (HIV, diabetes, IVDU) point to ecthyma gangrenosum. Necrotizing fasciitis would present with severe, out‑of‑proportion pain, rapid deep tissue spread and systemic toxicity, which are not described here.
CORRECT
Scaphoid fracture.

Rationale: FOOSH injury with focal tenderness in the anatomic snuffbox (between APL/EPB and EPL tendons) and decreased grip strength is classic for a scaphoid fracture. Initial x-rays can be falsely negative — immobilize in a thumb-spica splint and obtain repeat imaging (or MRI/CT) because of risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis of the proximal pole.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Scaphoid (navicular) fracture.

Reasoning: Fall on an outstretched hand with acute wrist swelling and focal tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox (between the APL/EPB and EPL tendons) is classic for a scaphoid fracture. De Quervain’s is an overuse tenosynovitis with a positive Finkelstein test and develops more gradually, not acutely after FOOSH. Important next steps: thumb‑spica immobilization and urgent imaging (initial x‑rays can be falsely negative — consider repeat x‑rays in 10–14 days or MRI/CT/bone scan) because of risk of nonunion/avascular necrosis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Scaphoid fracture.

Reasoning: Classic FOOSH mechanism in a young adult with focal tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox (between APL/EPB laterally and EPL medially), wrist swelling, and decreased grip strength — all typical for a scaphoid fracture. Initial radiographs can be normal, so immobilize the wrist (thumb spica) and obtain repeat imaging (or MRI/CT) because of the risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis of the proximal pole.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: scaphoid fracture.

Reasoning: classic fall on an outstretched hand in a young adult with swelling and focal tenderness in the anatomic snuffbox (between the APL/EPB and EPL tendons) is highly suggestive of scaphoid fracture. Thumb opposition is intact (no median-nerve injury). de Quervain tenosynovitis is usually atraumatic and diagnosed with Finkelstein testing; other wrist fractures/dislocations would have different focal findings. Note: initial radiographs can be normal — immobilize in a thumb spica and obtain repeat x-rays in 10–14 days or advanced imaging (MRI/CT) if concern persists because of risk of nonunion/avascular necrosis.
CORRECT
Scaphoid fracture — classic after a FOOSH with acute wrist swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox (between APL/EPB laterally and EPL medially). De Quervain’s is a chronic overuse tenosynovitis of APL/EPB (positive Finkelstein) and not usually an acute post‑fall snuffbox tenderness with swelling.
CORRECT
An accessory atrioventricular conduction pathway (Bundle of Kent) bypassing the AV node — i.e., Wolff-Parkinson-White pre‑excitation producing ventricular pre‑excitation and risk of re‑entrant tachyarrhythmia.
CORRECT
Conclusion: She has an accessory atrioventricular conduction pathway (Bundle of Kent) causing pre-excitation — Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 

Reasoning: A shortened PR interval, delta wave, and widened QRS are classic for ventricular pre-excitation from an atrium-to-ventricle bypass tract that conducts around the AV node. (Not impulse generation in the AV node itself.)
CORRECT
Conclusion: An accessory atrioventricular pathway (bundle of Kent) causing pre‑excitation — Wolff‑Parkinson‑White (WPW) syndrome.

Reasoning: The ECG classic for WPW shows a short PR interval, a slurred upstroke of the QRS (delta wave) and a widened QRS from early ventricular activation; T‑wave changes are secondary. This pathway bypasses the AV node and predisposes to re‑entrant tachyarrhythmias (which can degenerate to ventricular fibrillation and sudden collapse).
CORRECT
Yes — this is Wolff-Parkinson-White due to an accessory atrioventricular pathway (bundle of Kent) that directly connects atrium to ventricle, bypassing the AV node.  

Reason: the shortened PR interval with a delta wave and widened QRS are classic for ventricular pre‑excitation from an atrium‑to‑ventricle bypass tract; that pathway predisposes to reentrant tachyarrhythmias (which can degenerate to ventricular fibrillation and sudden collapse).
CORRECT
No — the most likely pathology is an accessory atrioventricular pathway (bundle of Kent) causing pre-excitation (Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome).

Reason: a shortened PR interval with a delta wave and widened QRS is the classic ECG pattern of pre-excitation from an accessory pathway that bypasses the AV node, producing early ventricular depolarization and secondary T‑wave changes. Pure AV‑nodal automaticity or AV‑nodal impulse generation would not produce a delta wave or PR shortening and thus does not explain this ECG.
CORRECT
Reactivation (secondary) pulmonary tuberculosis — most consistent with an older diabetic immigrant with recent prison exposure and a productive cough, with the classic cavitary upper‑lobe infiltrate on chest radiograph.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Reactivation (post-primary) pulmonary tuberculosis.

Reasoning: Immigrant with recent prison exposure (high TB risk), uncontrolled diabetes (predisposes to reactivation), and a chronic productive cough with significant sputum. The chest radiograph in this clinical stem classically shows an upper‑lobe cavitary lesion consistent with reactivation TB. COPD is less likely without a smoking history and would not explain the exposure and radiographic cavitation.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema (acute decompensated heart failure) causing pulmonary edema.

Reasoning: the patient has acute severe dyspnea with copious frothy sputum, profound hypoxemia, tachypnea/tachycardia and hypertension — the classic presentation of pulmonary edema. The chest x‑ray demonstrates bilateral perihilar/alveolar ("bat‑wing") opacities consistent with fluid-filled alveoli rather than the hyperinflation/wheezing of asthma. Her age and hypertension predispose to cardiac decompensation; the long flight/prison visit are red herrings (PE or TB less likely given the productive frothy sputum and radiographic pattern).
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema (acute decompensated heart failure) — flash pulmonary edema.

Reasoning: sudden severe dyspnea with hypoxia (SpO2 78%), productive frothy sputum, hypertension and tachycardia, and CXR classically shows bilateral perihilar/alveolar “bat‑wing” edema (with cardiomegaly). These findings fit acute pulmonary edema better than asthma (would cause wheeze, not copious frothy sputum), PE (usually pleuritic chest pain, possible hemoptysis, often a normal CXR), or TB (more indolent course and systemic symptoms).
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: COPD — chronic bronchitis phenotype.

Reasoning: She’s an older patient with acute severe dyspnea and copious purulent sputum production (classic for chronic bronchitis/COPD), marked hypoxemia and tachypnea. Asthma is less likely at this age and typically presents with episodic wheeze and reversible obstruction rather than continuous large-volume sputum. Acute PE or TB are possible given the travel/prison history, but they don’t usually present with massive mucus production and the overall picture fits COPD exacerbation. Definitive diagnosis requires spirometry (post‑bronchodilator FEV1/FVC <0.7) and acute management focuses on oxygen, inhaled bronchodilators, systemic steroids and treating infection if present.
CORRECT
Neurosyphilis from tertiary syphilis. Confirm by demonstrating treponemal serology in the CSF — eg, a positive CSF VDRL (CSF FTA-ABS is an alternative if VDRL negative).
WRONG
Confirm with a treponemal serologic test (eg, FTA-ABS or TP-PA). 

Reason: the combination of aortic root dilation/AR (widened mediastinum, holodiastolic murmur) plus Argyll Robertson pupils and a positive Romberg is classic tertiary syphilis; treponemal-specific serology confirms the diagnosis (CSF VDRL can be used if you specifically need to document neurosyphilis).
CORRECT
Conclusion: Confirm the diagnosis with treponemal serology — e.g., a positive FTA‑ABS (or TP‑PA) test (and, if neurosyphilis is suspected, CSF VDRL).

Reasoning: The patient has signs of tertiary syphilis — aortic root dilation causing aortic regurgitation and widened mediastinum plus neurosyphilis findings (light‑near dissociation of the pupils, positive Romberg). ASO titers are for post‑streptococcal disease and are not relevant. Initial screening is with non‑treponemal tests (RPR/VDRL) but confirmation requires a treponemal test such as FTA‑ABS; CSF VDRL confirms neurosyphilis.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This is tertiary syphilis (syphilitic aortitis causing aortic regurgitation and neurosyphilis/tabes dorsalis); confirm with treponemal serology (FTA‑ABS) — and if you need to prove neurosyphilis specifically, CSF VDRL is diagnostic.

Reasoning: The holodiastolic murmur and widened mediastinum suggest ascending aortic aneurysm/aortic regurgitation from syphilitic aortitis; the Argyll‑Robertson pupils and positive Romberg indicate tabes dorsalis (neurosyphilis). ASO titers are for post‑streptococcal disease and are irrelevant.
CORRECT
Treponemal serologic testing (eg, FTA-ABS) — which would confirm tertiary syphilis.

Reason: the holodiastolic murmur and widened mediastinum suggest syphilitic aortitis with aortic regurgitation, and the light‑near dissociation (Argyll Robertson pupils) plus positive Romberg indicate tabes dorsalis. Treponemal tests confirm the diagnosis; CSF VDRL can be used to document neurosyphilis specifically.
CORRECT
Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

He has classic re-experiencing symptoms (nightmares, daytime flashbacks) plus hyperarousal (insomnia, poor concentration) persisting for 6 weeks after a traumatic event — longer than 1 month, which distinguishes PTSD from acute stress disorder.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Reasoning: He has recurrent intrusive recollections (nightmares, daytime flashbacks) and hyperarousal (insomnia, poor concentration) following a traumatic event, and symptoms have persisted for 6 weeks — longer than the 1-month threshold for PTSD (acute stress disorder would be <1 month). Schizophreniform disorder is unlikely because his symptoms are trauma-related intrusions, not primary psychotic symptoms (delusions/hallucinations) required for that diagnosis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Post‑traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Reasoning: He has direct exposure to a life‑threatening traumatic event (gunshot), plus core intrusion symptoms (recurrent nightmares and daytime flashbacks), and associated hyperarousal/cognitive symptoms (insomnia, poor concentration). Symptoms have persisted ~6 weeks (>1 month), which meets the DSM‑5 duration criterion for PTSD (acute stress disorder would apply only if <1 month).
CORRECT
Yes — posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).  

He was exposed to a life‑threatening traumatic event (gunshot) and has persistent intrusion symptoms (nightmares, daytime flashbacks), plus hyperarousal (difficulty sleeping, poor concentration) that have lasted 6 weeks. PTSD is diagnosed when PTSD-type symptoms persist for more than one month after the trauma (acute stress disorder would be the diagnosis only if symptoms were under one month).
CORRECT
PTSD is still the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: his symptoms (nightmares and daytime flashbacks of the shooting, re-experiencing the trauma, trouble sleeping and concentrating) began after a life‑threatening traumatic event and have persisted for 6 weeks. PTSD requires trauma exposure plus characteristic re‑experiencing, avoidance/negative cognitions or hyperarousal and duration >1 month. Acute stress disorder would be <1 month. Schizophreniform disorder requires prominent psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech/behavior) rather than trauma‑linked re‑experiencing, so it does not fit this presentation.
CORRECT
Preeclampsia with severe features.

She has new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks with significant proteinuria (spot protein/creatinine ≈360/110 ≈3.3 >0.3) plus severe end-organ signs (incapacitating headache/cerebral symptoms, pulmonary edema, hyperreflexia), meeting criteria for severe preeclampsia.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Preeclampsia with severe features (severe preeclampsia).

Reasoning: She is >20 weeks gestation with new-onset hypertension and proteinuria (spot protein/creatinine ≈360/110 ≈3.3, i.e. significant proteinuria). Although BP is <160/110, she has severe features—severe, treatment‑refractory headache and pulmonary edema (bilateral crackles) and neurologic hyperreflexia—meeting criteria for severe preeclampsia.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Preeclampsia with severe features.

Reasoning: She has new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks (150/100) plus significant proteinuria (spot protein/creatinine ≈ 3.3). She also has end‑organ severe features — incapacitating, treatment‑refractory headache and pulmonary edema — which meet criteria for “severe features” even though her systolic/diastolic values are below the 160/110 cutoff. Platelets, AST and creatinine are not consistent with HELLP or renal failure, and there are no seizures to diagnose eclampsia.
CORRECT
Preeclampsia with severe features (severe preeclampsia).

Reasoning: New‑onset hypertension after 20 weeks (150/100) plus significant proteinuria (spot protein 360 mg/dL with urine creatinine 110 mg/dL → protein/creatinine ≈3.3, consistent with ≥3 g/day) establishes preeclampsia. She also has severe features — incapacitating headache (new cerebral symptom), pulmonary edema (bilateral crackles), and hyperreflexia — which qualify it as preeclampsia with severe features. Platelets, AST, and creatinine are not consistent with HELLP or renal failure.
CORRECT
I am sure: this is preeclampsia with severe features.

Reasoning: she has new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks plus significant proteinuria (urine protein/creatinine ≈ 360/110 ≈ 3.3, well above the 0.3 threshold) and signs of end-organ/ severe disease — incapacitating, treatment‑refractory headache and pulmonary edema (bilateral crackles, tachypnea) with hyperreflexia. Those findings meet criteria for “severe features” despite BP <160/110.
CORRECT
Tension pneumothorax from barotrauma due to high PEEP/positive-pressure ventilation.  
High PEEP/overdistention can rupture alveoli → air leak into the pleural space with lung collapse and acute hypoxemia/hemodynamic compromise.
CORRECT
Most likely etiology: tension pneumothorax from barotrauma due to high positive-pressure ventilation/PEEP.

Reasoning: a homeless alcoholic with aspiration likely developed ARDS and required increasing PEEP; sudden hypoxemia and decompensation after raising PEEP is classic for pneumothorax/tension physiology from alveolar rupture with trapped pleural air (causes acute fall in O2 saturation and can impair venous return). Right mainstem intubation is less likely because that typically presents immediately after intubation with unilateral breath sounds rather than sudden collapse after escalating PEEP.
CORRECT
Most likely: tension pneumothorax from barotrauma due to high PEEP.

Reasoning: a mechanically ventilated patient whose PEEP and FiO2 were being escalated can develop alveolar over‑distention and rupture with an air leak into the pleural space. That produces an abrupt fall in oxygenation (and often hypotension) — classic sudden decompensation. This fits the timing (after escalating PEEP) much better than other possibilities (PE, mucus plug, or ET displacement). Immediate exam (absent breath sounds/hemithorax hyperresonance) and emergent needle decompression/chest tube are indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely a tension pneumothorax from barotrauma due to high positive-pressure ventilation/PEEP.

Reasoning: sudden drop in oxygen saturation after increasing PEEP/FiO2 is classic for alveolar rupture with air leak → pneumothorax (which can progress to tension physiology). Positive-pressure ventilation, high PEEP, and diseased/atelectatic lungs (aspiration, pneumonia) predispose to barotrauma. The presentation is much more consistent with an acute pneumothorax than slower causes (progressive ARDS) or embolic events.
CORRECT
Most likely: tension pneumothorax from barotrauma due to high PEEP.

Reasoning: progressively increasing PEEP can overdistend alveoli and cause pleural air leak; a pneumothorax (especially tension) classically produces sudden hypoxemia and hemodynamic deterioration after a period of mechanical ventilation. Right mainstem intubation would usually cause immediate unilateral hypoxia and diminished breath sounds right after tube placement (not a delayed sudden drop after PEEP escalation), so the clinical course favors barotrauma/tension pneumothorax. Immediate needle decompression followed by chest tube is required.
CORRECT
Multiple adjacent rib fractures producing a flail chest (a segment of chest wall fractured in ≥2 places) with underlying pulmonary contusion — causing paradoxical inward motion, impaired ventilation, and respiratory compromise.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: flail chest from multiple adjacent rib fractures (with underlying pulmonary contusion).

Reasoning: the classic paradoxical inward motion of a chest wall segment on inspiration plus diffuse crepitus after blunt trauma indicates multiple rib fractures producing an unstable segment (flail chest). The absent breath sounds and respiratory distress are explained by associated pulmonary contusion/atelectasis. Diaphragmatic rupture would more commonly produce abdominal signs or bowel in the chest, not a focal paradoxical chest‑wall segment.
CORRECT
Most likely cause: a left-sided tension pneumothorax (large air leak with mediastinal compression).

Reasoning: he has unilateral absent breath sounds and subcutaneous crepitus (air leak), severe dyspnea, tachycardia and hypotension consistent with impaired venous return from mediastinal shift. Although paradoxical chest‑wall motion is classically taught for flail chest, the combination of crepitus, unilateral absent breath sounds and hemodynamic compromise is most typical of a large/tension pneumothorax (which is also readily worsened by positive‑pressure ventilation).
WRONG
Flail chest from multiple contiguous rib fractures producing a free chest-wall segment (with associated pulmonary contusion).

Reason: the classic paradoxical inward motion of part of the chest on inspiration plus diffuse crepitus after blunt trauma indicates multiple rib fractures causing a flail segment. The severe pain, respiratory distress and absent breath sounds can reflect the flail segment and underlying lung contusion (or associated pneumothorax), but the paradoxical movement pinpoints flail chest rather than isolated tension pneumothorax or hemothorax.
CORRECT
Flail chest — multiple adjacent rib fractures creating a free chest-wall segment that moves paradoxically (inward on inspiration).  

Reasoning: the key finding is inward movement of the left chest wall during inspiration (paradoxical motion), which is the classic sign of a flail segment from rib fractures (crepitus supports rib injury). Absent breath sounds can reflect underlying pulmonary contusion/atelectasis on that side. Diaphragmatic rupture more commonly presents with abdominal contents or bowel sounds in the hemithorax and often has a delayed presentation; it does not typically produce a localized paradoxically moving chest-wall segment.
CORRECT
The MRI would most likely show dilated Virchow–Robin (perivascular) spaces/gelatinous pseudocysts (T2 hyperintense lesions, often in the basal ganglia/thalamus) with leptomeningeal enhancement — findings characteristic of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis from Cryptococcus neoformans.
CORRECT
No — the MRI most consistent is leptomeningeal enhancement with multiple small cystic "soap-bubble" lesions (dilated Virchow–Robin/perivascular spaces or gelatinous pseudocysts), classically in the basal ganglia, consistent with cryptococcal meningitis.

Reason: the smear likely shows encapsulated yeast (Cryptococcus neoformans); in advanced HIV this produces subacute meningitis with gelatinous pseudocysts on MRI. A single large irregular ring-enhancing necrotic lesion is more typical of toxoplasmosis or a pyogenic abscess and is less likely here.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Multiple small cystic/gelatinous pseudocysts in the basal ganglia and dilated perivascular (Virchow–Robin) spaces — the classic “soap‑bubble” lesions of cryptococcal CNS infection.

Reasoning: The presentation (subacute meningitic picture in an untreated AIDS patient) plus the stained smear (encapsulated yeasts on India ink/mucicarmine) is diagnostic for Cryptococcus neoformans. On MRI cryptococcal meningoencephalitis often shows meningeal enhancement, communicating hydrocephalus, and characteristic gelatinous pseudocysts in the basal ganglia/perivascular spaces (soap‑bubble appearance).
CORRECT
Yes — cryptococcal meningitis. The stained smear is consistent with encapsulated yeast (Cryptococcus), and in AIDS patients cryptococcus produces dilated perivascular spaces/gelatinous pseudocysts in the basal ganglia and thalami that appear as multiple small “soap‑bubble” cystic lesions on brain MRI, often with leptomeningeal enhancement and elevated CSF opening pressure.
CORRECT
I am confident my original answer is correct: this presentation is most consistent with cryptococcal meningitis, which on brain MRI shows multiple "soap-bubble" (gelatinous pseudocyst) lesions in the basal ganglia/perivascular spaces.

Reasoning: subacute headache, fever, confusion and mild nuchal rigidity in a patient with AIDS + an image likely showing encapsulated yeast (India ink/mucicarmine) points to Cryptococcus neoformans. Cryptococcal CNS infection characteristically produces dilated Virchow–Robin spaces/gelatinous pseudocysts (soap‑bubble appearance) on MRI. A single large irregular enhancing lesion with central necrosis would instead favor toxoplasma abscess, pyogenic brain abscess, or primary CNS lymphoma — diagnoses less consistent with the smear and the diffuse meningitic picture.
CORRECT
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Fundoscopy shows an elevated, opaque/gray retina that appears billowing or corrugated with folds (a “sheet” or curtain), often with a linear retinal tear/flap and subretinal fluid; retinal blood vessels may appear to course over the detached, mobile retina and the red reflex is diminished.
WRONG
Correct — Figure E. The history (sudden “curtain” loss, preceding flashes/floaters, high myopia) is classic for a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment; ophthalmoscopy shows an elevated, gray, folded/undulating retina with loss of normal fundus detail and subretinal fluid, as depicted in Figure E.
CORRECT
The correct image is the one showing an elevated, grayish, wrinkled/“corrugated” membrane (a billowing “curtain”) consistent with a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment — not Figure B. 

Reason: Sudden unilateral “curtain” loss of vision with preceding flashes and floaters and high myopia is classic for retinal detachment. On ophthalmoscopy the detached retina appears as a pale, elevated, folded sheet that may undulate with eye movements; a diffuse red haze (often shown in Figure B) would instead suggest vitreous hemorrhage, which does not fit the classic painless curtain history.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is most consistent with a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.  

Reasoning: Sudden “curtain” loss of vision with preceding flashes and floaters in a high myope is classic for a retinal tear with detachment. Fundoscopy in this condition shows an elevated, grayish, wrinkled (billowing) retina with subretinal fluid and often a retinal break—i.e., a flap-like, mobile membrane obscuring the fundus. Pick the image that shows a pale, folded, detached retina (with or without a visible tear). If you tell me which figure matches that appearance I’ll confirm.
WRONG
Figure E — the image showing a pale, elevated, wrinkled/“flapping” retina (curtain of retina with subretinal fluid and often a peripheral retinal tear) is characteristic of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. The history of high myopia, flashes/floaters, and sudden curtain-like vision loss fits this diagnosis.
CORRECT
Boerhaave syndrome — spontaneous (transmural) esophageal rupture from forceful vomiting causing mediastinitis with pneumomediastinum/subcutaneous emphysema (neck crepitus), odynophagia, fever and sepsis.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Boerhaave syndrome — spontaneous esophageal perforation with mediastinitis and subcutaneous emphysema.

Reasoning: The history of recent forceful vomiting after alcohol, progressive chest pain, fever/tachycardia, odynophagia and change in voice, and palpable crepitus in the neck are classic for esophageal rupture with air tracking from the mediastinum into the neck. The LBBB rules out acute ischemia as the cause; the poor dentition/foul breath are distractors from an odontogenic infection. Immediate CT chest with oral contrast and urgent surgical consultation are indicated.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Boerhaave syndrome — spontaneous (forceful vomiting–related) esophageal rupture with mediastinitis.

Reasoning: The patient has a history of recent frequent vomiting, progressive chest pain, odynophagia and voice change plus palpable crepitus in the neck (subcutaneous emphysema) and systemic signs of infection — a classic presentation for esophageal perforation and mediastinitis. Dental pain (dentalgia) would not explain post‑emetic chest pain, odynophagia, or subcutaneous emphysema.
WRONG
No — the most likely diagnosis is Boerhaave syndrome (spontaneous esophageal rupture with mediastinitis).

Reasoning: recent forceful vomiting followed by acute/worsening chest pain, odynophagia and change in voice, fever/tachycardia and borderline hypotension, and palpable crepitus in the neck from air tracking (subcutaneous emphysema) are classic for esophageal perforation. The foul breath and poor dentition can be misleading toward dental infection, but the systemic picture and history of violent emesis point to esophageal rupture rather than simple dental cellulitis.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Ludwig’s angina (bilateral submandibular/submental space cellulitis from a dental source).

Reasoning: classic picture of a dental-origin submandibular infection — poor dentition, gingival erythema, odynophagia, muffled/changed voice, submandibular swelling/crepitus, fever and systemic toxicity. Ludwig’s angina causes rapidly progressive floor-of-mouth and submandibular swelling that can obstruct the airway and requires urgent airway protection, broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and surgical drainage.
CORRECT
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) — most likely posterior semicircular canal canalithiasis. Classic brief, position-triggered spinning spells provoked by a positive Dix‑Hallpike maneuver with transient nystagmus and otherwise normal neuro exam.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), most likely posterior‑canal canalithiasis.

Reasoning: brief, recurrent spinning episodes triggered by head-turning/lying back with a provoked transient nystagmus (positive Dix‑Hallpike), no persistent vertigo or focal neurologic deficits, and normal gait/cranial nerves — all classic for BPPV. Vertebrobasilar stroke is unlikely because stroke causes persistent vertigo or other focal neuro signs rather than short, position‑dependent episodes. Treatment: perform the Epley repositioning maneuver and vestibular rehab as indicated.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), posterior semicircular canal.

Reasoning: classic brief (seconds–minutes) spinning provoked by head/positional changes when going to bed, reproducible vertigo and nystagmus with the Dix–Hallpike maneuver (symptoms triggered by turning head left and laying back) that fatigue/resolve within minutes, no hearing loss or focal neurologic findings, and a normal gait at baseline — all strongly point to canalithiasis of the posterior canal. Central causes, vestibular neuritis (prolonged continuous vertigo), and Ménière disease (hearing loss/tinnitus) are much less likely. Treat with a canalith-repositioning maneuver (Epley).
CORRECT
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), most consistent with posterior‑canal BPPV.

Reasoning:
- Classic sudden, brief (seconds–minutes) spinning vertigo triggered by a change in head position (going to bed/lying back, turning head left).  
- Associated nausea/vomiting and a provoked positional nystagmus on lying back (Dix–Hallpike–type maneuver) that is transient/fatigable.  
- Normal neurologic exam, gait, and no hearing loss make vestibular neuritis, labyrinthitis, or central stroke (which give persistent vertigo or focal deficits) unlikely.  
- Management: canalith repositioning (Epley) is diagnostic and therapeutic.
CORRECT
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Reasoning: the attack was sudden, brief, provoked by a head/position change (going to bed and turning head), reproducible when laid back with head turned to the left (positive Dix–Hallpike–type maneuver) and produced transient positional nystagmus that improved after a couple of minutes. There are no persistent vestibular signs or focal neurologic deficits (normal cranial nerves, normal gait), and symptoms resolved between episodes — all classic for BPPV from otoliths in the posterior semicircular canal.  

Vertebrobasilar stroke is less likely because strokes typically produce continuous rather than very brief, position-triggered vertigo and are usually accompanied by other brainstem/cerebellar findings (diplopia, dysarthria, limb weakness/ataxia, persistent/ direction-fixed nystagmus) or vascular risk factors. If there is any atypical feature, persistent symptoms, progression, or concern for vascular disease, obtain urgent neuroimaging (MRI-DWI) to exclude stroke. Treatment for BPPV is the Epley (canalith repositioning) maneuver.
CORRECT
This presentation is Dressler syndrome — a post‑MI autoimmune (antibody/immune complex–mediated) pericarditis from myocardial necrosis weeks to months after infarction causing pericardial inflammation with fever, pleuritic chest pain, friction rub, and diffuse ST elevations.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Dressler syndrome — an autoimmune (fibrinous) pericarditis occurring after myocardial infarction.

Reasoning: The patient is 2 months post–MI and presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, a high‑pitched friction rub best heard leaning forward, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG — classic for postinfarction pericarditis (Dressler). The timing (weeks–months after MI) and autoimmune reaction to myocardial antigens distinguish it from early post‑MI pericarditis and from pulmonary embolism, which would not produce a pericardial friction rub or diffuse ST elevations. Treatment is typically NSAIDs/colchicine (and rarely steroids).
CORRECT
Most likely Dressler syndrome — a post‑MI autoimmune (fibrinous) pericarditis from antibodies to cardiac antigens.

Reasoning: the timing (2 months after an MI), fever, pleuritic chest pain with a high‑pitched pericardial friction rub and diffuse ST elevations are classic for late postinfarction (Dressler) pericarditis. Troponin can be normal or only mildly elevated in pericarditis/myopericarditis, and although modern reperfusion/stenting has reduced Dressler’s incidence, it still occurs.
CORRECT
Most likely: Dressler syndrome — an autoimmune (antibody‑mediated) fibrinous pericarditis that occurs weeks to months after a transmural MI.

Reasoning: the timing (2 months post‑MI), fever and pleuritic chest pain, a high‑pitched pericardial friction rub best heard sitting up/leaning forward, and diffuse ST elevations are classic for post‑MI (Dressler) pericarditis. (Peri‑infarction pericarditis occurs in the first few days post‑MI; Dressler is a delayed immune response.)
CORRECT
No — the presentation is most consistent with Dressler syndrome (post‑MI autoimmune pericarditis), not pulmonary embolism.

Why: the timing (2 months after MI), fever, pleuritic chest pain with a high‑pitched scratching sound (pericardial friction rub that is best heard when sitting forward/with expiration), and diffuse ST‑segment elevations on ECG point to pericarditis from an autoimmune postinfarction reaction. PE can cause pleuritic pain and tachycardia but would not produce a pericardial friction rub or diffuse ST elevations and more commonly causes hypoxemia/tachycardia rather than this classic post‑MI pericarditis picture.
WRONG
Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome).

Rationale: persistent high fever ≥5 days plus bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, erythematous oral mucosa ("strawberry" tongue), cervical lymphadenopathy, polymorphous rash and extremity involvement (swelling/tenderness) meet diagnostic criteria. Treat urgently with IV immunoglobulin and high‑dose aspirin to reduce risk of coronary artery aneurysms.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Kawasaki disease.

Reasoning: A child <5 with ≥5 days of high fever plus bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, erythematous (strawberry) tongue/mucosa, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, and a polymorphous rash fits classic Kawasaki criteria. The joint symptoms can occur. This is a medium-vessel vasculitis that requires prompt IVIG and aspirin to reduce risk of coronary artery aneurysms. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis would present with granulomatous upper-airway, lung, and renal involvement and is far less likely.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Kawasaki disease.

Reasoning: He meets classic criteria — fever ≥5 days plus bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, erythematous oral mucosa/strawberry tongue, unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and a polymorphous rash. Age (young child) and large-joint arthritis can occur in Kawasaki. The hiking history is a red herring: tick-borne illnesses (eg, RMSF or Lyme) typically have different rash distribution/timing and other features (RMSF often starts on wrists/ankles and becomes petechial; Lyme arthritis appears later and erythema migrans is not a diffuse mucocutaneous eruption). Workup/treatment should include IVIG, high‑dose aspirin and early echocardiography to evaluate coronary arteries.
CORRECT
Kawasaki disease.

He has ≥5 days of high fever plus bilateral nonpurulent conjunctivitis, erythematous oral mucosa/strawberry tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse rash — meeting classic diagnostic criteria (fever ≥5 days + ≥4 principal features). Joint swelling can occur in Kawasaki. Other possibilities (eg, scarlet fever or tickborne rickettsial infection) are less likely given the conjunctivitis and mucosal changes. Prompt treatment with IVIG and aspirin is indicated to reduce coronary artery complications.
CORRECT
Kawasaki disease.

Reasoning: The child has ≥5 days of high fever plus key features of Kawasaki — bilateral nonpurulent conjunctival injection, erythematous “strawberry” tongue/oral mucosa, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse macular rash (and arthralgia/arthritis). This classic constellation in a young child is much more consistent with Kawasaki than granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which typically shows necrotizing granulomatous inflammation of the upper/lower respiratory tract and kidneys (hematuria, lung cavitation) and occurs in older children/adults with c-ANCA positivity — findings absent here. (Tickborne illnesses like RMSF are a consideration with hiking history but the mucosal changes and lymphadenopathy favor Kawasaki.)
CORRECT
Bullous pemphigoid — an autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease in older adults caused by IgG autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins (BP180/BP230). Produces tense, pruritic bullae that are Nikolsky‑negative and show linear IgG/C3 deposition along the basement membrane on immunofluorescence.
WRONG
Correct — this is bullous pemphigoid: autoantibodies (IgG ± C3) deposit linearly at the basement membrane zone (hemidesmosomes BP180/BP230), producing a subepidermal (tense) blister with eosinophils and intensely pruritic lesions in an older adult.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is most consistent with bullous pemphigoid — an antibody‑mediated (Type II) autoimmune blistering disease directed at hemidesmosomal proteins (BP180/BP230), producing tense, subepidermal blisters that are Nikolsky‑negative with linear IgG/C3 along the basement membrane.

Reasoning: Elderly patient with intensely pruritic, thick/tense blisters that do not break with pressure points to subepidermal (not acantholytic) bullae. That pattern (pruritic, tense, Nikolsky‑negative) distinguishes bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus vulgaris (flaccid blisters, Nikolsky‑positive, anti‑desmoglein suprabasal acantholysis) and from dermatitis herpetiformis (IgA granular deposits). The pathogenesis is Type II (autoantibodies against hemidesmosomes), so Type IV is incorrect.
WRONG
Bullous pemphigoid — an autoimmune (type II hypersensitivity) subepidermal blistering disease caused by IgG against hemidesmosomal proteins (BP180/BP230), producing tense bullae that do not rupture (negative Nikolsky sign), classically in older adults. 

Reasoning: The patient’s thick/tense lesions that don’t break with pressure and his age fit bullous pemphigoid; pemphigus vulgaris would give flaccid, easily ruptured blisters with a positive Nikolsky sign.
WRONG
Correct — this is bullous pemphigoid: linear IgG (and C3) deposition along the basement membrane.  

Reason: Elderly patient with pruritic, tense bullae that do not rupture (negative Nikolsky), subepidermal blisters caused by IgG autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins (BP180/BP230). Direct immunofluorescence shows a linear band of IgG/C3 at the dermal–epidermal junction (type II hypersensitivity).
CORRECT
Superior vena cava obstruction (SVC syndrome) from an intrathoracic malignancy—most likely bronchogenic (eg, small‑cell) lung cancer compressing the SVC. 

Rationale: facial/arm swelling, JVD, dilated chest wall veins and orthopnea/headache worse when supine are classic for SVC compression; heavy smoking history makes lung cancer the most likely cause.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome from obstruction of the SVC (most likely malignant compression or thrombosis related to her prior breast cancer/treatment).

Reasoning: Progressive facial and bilateral arm swelling, JVD, prominent anterior chest wall collateral veins, and headache worse when supine/leaning forward are classic for SVC obstruction. Her history of breast cancer and chest radiation (and tamoxifen-associated hypercoagulability) are strong risk factors. Pulmonary embolism typically causes acute dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, hypoxemia and does not produce the described upper‑body venous congestion and chest‑wall collaterals.
WRONG
Most likely cause: superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction from a mediastinal bronchogenic (lung) cancer — classically small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Reasoning: her progressive facial/upper‑extremity edema, jugular venous distention and prominent anterior chest wall collaterals with orthostatic/positional headache are the classic syndrome of SVC compression. The commonest cause in an older heavy smoker is a centrally located lung cancer compressing the SVC. Other causes (eg, thrombosis from catheters or tamoxifen‑related hypercoagulability, postradiation fibrosis, metastatic breast disease) are possible but less likely given her smoking history and the typical clinical picture.
CORRECT
Most likely superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome from bronchogenic (lung) carcinoma compressing the SVC.

Reasoning: The constellation of facial/arm swelling, jugular venous distention, dilated anterior chest wall veins (collaterals), and headaches worse when supine are classic for SVC obstruction with increased venous pressure. In adults the commonest cause is a mediastinal mass—especially bronchogenic lung cancer (strong risk here from a 40‑pack‑year smoking history). Recurrent breast cancer or catheter-related thrombosis are less likely given lack of local lymphadenopathy, bilateral arm involvement, and prominent chest‑wall collaterals.
CORRECT
Conclusion: Superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction—most likely from a mediastinal malignancy (eg, bronchogenic carcinoma causing external compression).

Reasoning: Progressive facial and bilateral arm swelling, JVD, and prominent anterior chest wall collateral veins are classic for SVC syndrome from impaired venous return. Positional headache worsened by lying forward reflects increased intracranial venous pressure. Pulmonary embolism would cause acute dyspnea/pleuritic pain and hypoxemia rather than the chronic head/face/upper‑extremity venous congestion and chest wall collaterals seen here.
WRONG
Acute urinary retention from bladder outlet obstruction due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (nodular hyperplasia of the prostatic transition zone compressing the prostatic urethra), producing an overdistended bladder (suprapubic mass) and preventing passage of a transurethral catheter.
CORRECT
Most likely cause: acute urinary retention from benign prostatic hyperplasia (bladder outlet obstruction from an enlarged prostate).

Reasoning: a distended, dull pelvic mass to the umbilicus is a markedly overfull bladder. The acute post‑op timing (anesthesia/analgesics, IV fluids) commonly precipitates retention in men with underlying prostatic enlargement. Failure to pass a transurethral catheter is consistent with mechanical obstruction at the prostatic urethra. Prostate cancer is less likely to present as sudden postoperative retention without a more gradual history of symptoms.
CORRECT
Most likely cause: acute postoperative urinary retention from anesthetic/analgesic–induced detrusor atony (failure of the micturition reflex), not primary benign prostatic hypertrophy.

Reasoning: the rapid onset of inability to void hours after surgery with a large suprapubic/pelvic mass to the umbilicus that is dull to percussion is classic bladder distension from acute urinary retention. The timing after general anesthesia and perioperative catheterization points to transient inhibition of bladder contraction by anesthetic and opioid effects (and any perioperative anticholinergic agents). Normal WBC/low‑grade temp and the acute post‑op presentation make chronic BPH less likely as the primary cause. Failure to pass a urethral catheter can occur with severe retention or sphincter spasm and is an indication for suprapubic catheter drainage.
WRONG
Most likely acute urinary retention from bladder outlet obstruction due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Reason: a markedly distended bladder palpable to the umbilicus and dull to percussion with progressive inability to void after catheter removal is classic for obstructive retention from prostatic enlargement in a 66‑year‑old. Failed transurethral recatheterization also points to mechanical obstruction at the prostatic urethra. (Postop detrusor atony or infection are less likely given the large palpable bladder, normal WBC/temperature, and inability to pass a catheter.)
CORRECT
No — the most likely cause is benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) causing acute bladder outlet obstruction and urinary retention.
