Reasoning: a 66‑year‑old man after anesthesia with a sudden inability to void, a large suprapubic, dull, tender pelvic mass up to the umbilicus (distended bladder) is classic acute urinary retention. BPH is the common cause in this age group and is often precipitated by anesthesia/immobility or perioperative meds. Prostate cancer more commonly causes a gradual obstructive picture or systemic findings and rarely presents as acute retention; lack of fever, normal WBC, and the immediate postoperative timing favor obstructive BPH rather than infectious prostatitis or malignancy. (If transurethral catheterization fails, suprapubic decompression and urology evaluation are indicated.)
CORRECT
Squamous cell carcinoma arising in a chronic burn scar (a Marjolin ulcer). Chronic nonhealing burn scars notoriously undergo malignant transformation to SCC — biopsy to confirm.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma arising in a chronic burn scar (Marjolin ulcer).

Reasoning: Long-standing nonhealing ulcer in a burn scar that recently changed in appearance is classic for malignant transformation to SCC (Marjolin ulcer). Basal cell carcinoma typically arises on sun-exposed sites (face) as pearly papules with telangiectasias and is unlikely to arise from chronic ulcers.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma arising in a chronic burn scar (Marjolin ulcer).

Reasoning: A long-standing, nonhealing ulcer in a scar/burn site that suddenly changes and becomes painful in an older patient is classic for malignant transformation — most commonly squamous cell carcinoma (Marjolin ulcer). SCC is by far the commonest malignancy to arise in chronic scars/ulcers; other possibilities (basal cell carcinoma, chronic infection, pyoderma gangrenosum) are less likely given the history of a longstanding burn scar with a new aggressive-appearing lesion. Definitive diagnosis requires biopsy.
CORRECT
Squamous cell carcinoma — specifically a Marjolin ulcer (malignant transformation of a chronic burn scar).

Reasoning: a long-standing, nonhealing ulcer arising in a burn scar that recently changed in appearance is classic for Marjolin ulcer, which most commonly is squamous cell carcinoma. The patient’s age and chronic inflammation fit; diabetes-related neuropathy explains poor wound healing and delayed recognition. Confirm with biopsy and treat surgically.
CORRECT
Most likely: squamous cell carcinoma — specifically a Marjolin ulcer arising in a chronic burn scar.

Reasoning: malignant transformation of long-standing scars/ulcers (burn sites) classically produces SCC (Marjolin ulcer) that presents as a painful, rapidly changing nonhealing ulcer. Basal cell carcinoma typically appears as a pearly, telangiectatic lesion on sun‑exposed skin and is less likely to arise in chronic burn scars.
CORRECT
This presentation and CSF (sudden "worst" occipital headache, neck stiffness, papilledema, opening pressure ↑, RBCs present and not decreasing across tubes, ↑protein) are most consistent with a subarachnoid hemorrhage from rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in the circle of Willis. Pathophysiology: congenital focal weakness of the arterial tunica media at branch points → saccular aneurysm formation that ruptures, dumping arterial blood into the subarachnoid space, raising intracranial pressure and causing meningeal irritation.
WRONG
Conclusion: Rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in the circle of Willis causing an acute subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Reasoning: A sudden "worst-ever" occipital headache with neck stiffness, papilledema and raised opening pressure points to SAH. CSF shows persistent RBCs across tubes (rules out traumatic tap), elevated protein and mildly low glucose consistent with blood in the subarachnoid space. The usual mechanism is rupture of a berry aneurysm at arterial branch points (classically the anterior communicating, posterior communicating, or MCA bifurcation) rather than a nonspecific “communicating branch” rupture.
WRONG
Most likely: rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm causing subarachnoid hemorrhage (arterial bleeding into the subarachnoid space).

Reasoning: the sudden “thunderclap” occipital headache, nuchal rigidity, papilledema and vomiting are classic for SAH. CSF shows persistent RBCs across tubes (rules out traumatic tap), elevated opening pressure and increased protein; xanthochromia/hemoglobin breakdown products in CSF follow arterial SAH. Viral encephalitis would produce a more subacute presentation with lymphocytic pleocytosis and usually normal glucose rather than the pattern seen here.
CORRECT
No — this presentation and CSF are most consistent with a subarachnoid hemorrhage from rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm. 

Reasoning: sudden "worst headache" (thunderclap), meningismus, raised opening pressure and blood in CSF that remains constant across tubes (rules out traumatic tap) point to bleeding into the subarachnoid space. Rupture of a berry aneurysm at circle-of-Willis branch points is the common pathophysiology.
CORRECT
Most likely: subarachnoid hemorrhage from rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in the circle of Willis (classically an anterior communicating artery aneurysm).

Reasoning: sudden “worst-ever” thunderclap headache with meningeal signs, papilledema and vomiting fits SAH. CSF shows RBCs present and unchanged across tubes (rules out traumatic tap), elevated opening pressure and raised protein — all consistent with blood in the subarachnoid space. Berry aneurysms form at arterial branch points (congenital weakness of the tunica media) and can rupture, producing the picture described.
CORRECT
Most likely: Dressler syndrome (post‑myocardial infarction autoimmune pericarditis).

Rationale: the patient had an acute MI (VF arrest, regional wall dyskinesia and ST‑elevations). Dressler classically appears weeks (2–10 weeks) after MI. 

What to watch for: fever, pleuritic chest pain worse with inspiration and when supine, pericardial friction rub, and signs of pericardial effusion/tamponade. ECG may show diffuse ST elevation with PR depression. 

Management: usually NSAIDs or high‑dose aspirin; colchicine or corticosteroids for refractory cases; urgent drainage if tamponade develops. Advise him to seek prompt care for new chest pain, fever, dyspnea, or lightheadedness.
WRONG
Most likely complication to warn about: left ventricular (true) aneurysm with risk of mural thrombus and systemic embolization (and heart failure/arrhythmia).

Reason: the post-arrest ECG and bedside echo showing dyskinetic wall motion indicate a transmural infarct that can remodel into a dyskinetic ventricular aneurysm over weeks–months; these aneurysms commonly harbor mural thrombus and predispose to embolic stroke, progressive HF, and arrhythmias.
CORRECT
Most likely complication to counsel him about is left ventricular mural thrombus with risk of systemic embolization (eg, ischemic stroke).

Reasoning: his post-arrest bedside echo showed a dyskinetic LV wall segment — akinetic/dyskinetic myocardium after an MI causes stasis that predisposes to mural thrombus formation and embolic events. Papillary-muscle rupture is unlikely here because that mechanical complication usually presents acutely (typically 2–7 days after an MI) with sudden severe MR and pulmonary edema and would have become clinically evident during the hospital stay. Recommend follow-up echocardiography and discussion of anticoagulation and stroke symptoms to watch for.
WRONG
No — the more likely complication to warn him about is Dressler syndrome (post–myocardial infarction autoimmune pericarditis).

Reasoning: his arrest and dyskinetic wall motion with ST-elevation ECG indicate an acute MI. Dressler syndrome classically occurs weeks after MI (2–10 weeks) and presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub and possible pericardial effusion; treatment is NSAIDs/colchicine (steroids only if refractory). Papillary muscle rupture usually occurs much earlier (within days) and would have produced acute severe MR and pulmonary edema, so it’s unlikely here.
WRONG
Ventricular (true) aneurysm — with risk of heart failure, ventricular arrhythmias and mural thrombus with systemic embolization.

Reasoning: the post‑arrest echo showed a dyskinetic wall segment and the ECG (likely persistent ST elevation with Q‑waves) is classic for a transmural infarct that can remodel into a ventricular aneurysm over weeks. Papillary‑muscle rupture typically presents acutely (3–7 days) with sudden severe MR and pulmonary edema, so it’s less likely after an otherwise uncomplicated 2‑week hospitalization.
CORRECT
A chronic subdural hematoma from tearing of bridging veins after minor head trauma. In elderly patients cerebral atrophy stretches bridging veins, so a small fall → venous bleeding over weeks produces a crescent‑shaped extra‑axial collection on CT and progressive confusion/somnolence.
WRONG
Most likely a chronic subdural hematoma from tearing of bridging veins after a minor head trauma (exacerbated by age-related cerebral atrophy).

Reasoning: the 2‑week, progressively worsening confusion and somnolence, subtle unilateral weakness, and the history/evidence of a fall (ecchymosis) in an elderly patient point to a subacute/chronic subdural. CT would show a crescent‑shaped extra‑axial collection along the convexity; cerebral atrophy in older adults stretches bridging veins, making them prone to rupture with minor head injury.
WRONG
Most likely a chronic subdural hematoma from tearing of bridging veins after minor head trauma (venous bleeding into the subdural space).

Reasoning: an elderly patient with insidious cognitive decline over weeks, somnolence, a recent fall/minor trauma suggested by knee ecchymosis, and the classic crescent-shaped extra-axial collection on noncontrast CT fits subdural hematoma. Brain atrophy in older adults stretches bridging veins, so even minor trauma can cause slow venous bleeding and delayed symptoms. This differs from "increased CSF" (hydrocephalus), which would produce ventricular enlargement on CT rather than a crescentic subdural collection.
WRONG
Most likely a chronic subdural hematoma from rupture of bridging veins after minor head trauma. 

Reason: the gradual 2-week cognitive decline and fluctuating consciousness in an elderly, atrophic brain (prone to stretching of bridging veins) after probable minor trauma (falls; ecchymosis on knee) is classic for venous bleeding into the subdural space producing a crescent-shaped collection on CT.
WRONG
Conclusion: Tearing of bridging veins causing a chronic subdural hematoma.

Reasoning: In an elderly patient with minor trauma, progressive confusion over weeks and a focal bruise, a crescent-shaped extra-axial collection on noncontrast CT is classic for chronic subdural hematoma. Cerebral atrophy is a predisposing factor (it increases tension on bridging veins) but the immediate etiology of his presentation is venous bleeding into the subdural space.
WRONG
This is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) — phage‑encoded S. aureus exotoxins cleave desmoglein‑1 in desmosomes of the superficial epidermis (stratum granulosum), producing widespread superficial blistering with a positive Nikolsky sign and sparing of mucous membranes. Supportive care and anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics are indicated.
WRONG
Correct — this is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome caused by cleavage/destruction of desmoglein‑1. Staph aureus exfoliative toxins (serine proteases) cleave desmoglein‑1 in desmosomes of the stratum granulosum → superficial epidermal sloughing with positive Nikolsky sign and spared mucosa. Treat with anti‑staphylococcal antibiotics and supportive care.
WRONG
Diagnosis: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) — caused by S. aureus exfoliative toxins that cleave desmoglein‑1 in desmosomes, producing superficial epidermal splitting at the stratum granulosum with positive Nikolsky sign; mucous membranes are spared. 

Reasoning: Young child with rapid-onset fever, tender warm erythematous rash with skin sloughing and no mucosal lesions fits SSSS. The pathology is proteolytic disruption of desmosomal adhesion (Dsg‑1), not direct cytotoxic keratinocyte destruction.
WRONG
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome — exotoxin-mediated proteolytic cleavage of desmoglein‑1 in desmosomes causing intraepidermal splitting at the stratum granulosum (loss of superficial keratinocyte adhesion); mucous membranes are typically spared.
WRONG
You are correct — this is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome due to proteolytic destruction of desmoglein-1. 

Reason: rapid-onset fever and widespread tender erythema with epidermal sloughing in a young child, mucosal surfaces spared (unlike SJS/TEN), and positive Nikolsky sign fit SSSS caused by Staph aureus exotoxins that cleave desmoglein-1 in the superficial epidermis.
WRONG
Acute stress disorder.

She has intrusive symptoms (nightmares), avoidance (no longer using her car), hyperarousal (insomnia, palpitations, irritability) and functional impairment beginning after a traumatic sexual assault and occurring within 3 weeks — meeting acute stress disorder (PTSD requires symptoms lasting >1 month).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute stress disorder.

Reasoning: she has a qualifying traumatic stressor (sexual assault 3 weeks ago) and now has intrusive symptoms (nightmares), avoidance (refusing to use her car), hyperarousal/insomnia/irritability (sleeping with lights on, frequent awakenings with palpitations/sweating, shouting at coworkers), and marked functional impairment — all within 1 month of the trauma. PTSD requires similar symptoms that persist beyond 1 month, so the presentation at 3 weeks fits acute stress disorder.
CORRECT
Acute stress disorder.

She sustained a qualifying traumatic event 3 weeks ago and now has intrusion (nightmares), avoidance (won’t use her car), hyperarousal/insomnia and functional impairment — symptoms that occur within 3 days to 1 month after trauma, which fits acute stress disorder. PTSD requires symptoms persisting >1 month, and adjustment disorder would not produce the intrusive re‑experiencing and hyperarousal seen here.
CORRECT
Acute stress disorder.

She has intrusive memories/nightmares, avoidance (won’t use her car), hyperarousal (sleep disturbance, palpitations, irritability) and functional impairment that began after a traumatic sexual assault 3 weeks ago. The timing—symptoms within 3 days to 1 month after the trauma—fits acute stress disorder; PTSD is diagnosed only if symptoms persist beyond 1 month.
CORRECT
Acute stress disorder — symptoms began 3 weeks after a sexual assault and include intrusive memories/nightmares, avoidance (won’t use her car), negative mood/irritability, and hyperarousal (sleep disturbance, palpitations). Because the symptom cluster is present but the duration is under 1 month, the diagnosis is acute stress disorder; it would be PTSD only if symptoms persist beyond one month.
CORRECT
Chancroid due to Haemophilus ducreyi. The presentation of multiple, painful purulent/necrotic genital ulcers with tender suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) is classic for chancroid, unlike HSV (smaller grouped vesicles/ulcers, often recurrent) or primary syphilis (single painless chancre).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi infection).

Reason: The patient has multiple painful, deep purulent ulcers with necrotic bases and tender inguinal adenopathy — classic for chancroid. HSV usually causes smaller grouped vesicles that become shallow ulcers and often recur; LGV (C. trachomatis L1–L3) typically begins with a small painless lesion that often heals and is followed weeks later by unilateral buboes; granuloma inguinale causes painless beefy-red ulcers.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Genital herpes (HSV, most often HSV-2).

Reasoning: The presentation of multiple, painful vulvar ulcers with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is most consistent with HSV — HSV is the commonest cause of genital ulcers in developed settings and often produces multiple grouped painful lesions; primary infections can be larger and more symptomatic. Chancroid (H. ducreyi) classically produces deep, necrotic "soft chancre" lesions with markedly purulent, ragged edges and typically occurs in epidemiologic settings where it’s more prevalent, so it is less likely here. Confirm with HSV PCR or culture and treat with antiviral therapy.
WRONG
Chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi).

Reason: Multiple, acutely painful purulent vulvar ulcers with necrotic bases and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy are classic for chancroid. HSV usually causes grouped shallow vesiculoulcerative lesions with burning or recurrent episodes; primary syphilis causes a single painless chancre; LGV (C. trachomatis L1–L3) typically has a transient/minimal ulcer followed later by unilateral buboes; granuloma inguinale produces painless beefy red ulcers. These features favor chancroid.
CORRECT
Chancroid.

The presentation of multiple, painful purulent vulvar ulcers with necrotic bases and tender inguinal buboes is classic for Haemophilus ducreyi (chancroid). LGV (Chlamydia L1–L3) typically produces a small, often painless or transient primary lesion and then prominent unilateral inguinal/femoral lymphadenopathy days to weeks later—not multiple painful necrotic ulcers at onset—so LGV is less likely.
CORRECT
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). 

Reason: PSC classically occurs in men with ulcerative colitis, produces a cholestatic pattern (elevated alkaline phosphatase), is often pANCA positive, and is AMA negative (distinguishing it from primary biliary cholangitis).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

Reasoning: PSC classically occurs in men with ulcerative colitis, produces a cholestatic picture (elevated alkaline phosphatase), is associated with pANCA, and is typically antimitochondrial antibody–negative. Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly primary biliary cirrhosis) is usually seen in middle‑aged women and is AMA‑positive. Consider MRCP (or ERCP) to look for the characteristic multifocal biliary strictures/beading and surveillance for cholangiocarcinoma.
CORRECT
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

Reason: A young man with long‑standing ulcerative colitis, cholestatic liver tests (ALP 205) with mildly elevated transaminases, positive p‑ANCA and negative antimitochondrial antibody is most consistent with PSC. The p‑ANCA and strong UC association point to PSC over PBC (typically AMA+ in middle‑aged women) or NAFLD (obesity alone doesn’t explain the ALP elevation and UC association). Diagnosis is confirmed with cholangiography (MRCP/ERCP) showing multifocal bile duct strictures and beading.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

Reason: A middle‑aged man with ulcerative colitis, cholestatic lab pattern (ALP disproportionately elevated), positive p‑ANCA and negative antimitochondrial antibody is classic for PSC. PSC is strongly associated with UC and p‑ANCA; PBC is usually AMA‑positive and seen in middle‑aged women. Confirm with cholangiography (MRCP/ERCP — “beading” of bile ducts) and refer to hepatology.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).

Reasoning: PSC classically occurs in men with ulcerative colitis, causes a cholestatic pattern (elevated ALP) with modest transaminase elevations, is often p-ANCA positive, and is typically AMA-negative. Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly cirrhosis) is most common in middle‑aged women and is strongly associated with a positive antimitochondrial antibody.
CORRECT
Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes of heme synthesis (ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase) and causes basophilic stippling. Disorders of the same pathway are the porphyrias — e.g., acute intermittent porphyria (porphobilinogen deaminase deficiency) and porphyria cutanea tarda (uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency) — as well as sideroblastic anemias (defective heme synthesis in mitochondria).
WRONG
Conclusion: This is lead poisoning (acute childhood lead toxicity). The same metabolic pathway (heme synthesis) is involved in porphyrias — e.g., porphyria cutanea tarda and acute intermittent porphyria — and in sideroblastic anemias.

Reasoning: Microcytic anemia with high/normal ferritin, neuropathy (foot drop), abdominal pain, renovaton-related lead exposure, and basophilic stippling on smear point to lead poisoning, which inhibits ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase in the heme synthesis pathway; porphyrias and sideroblastic anemias are other disorders of that pathway.
WRONG
Conclusion: This is lead poisoning → the same pathway is heme/porphyrin biosynthesis — e.g. porphyrias (acute intermittent porphyria, porphyria cutanea tarda) and sideroblastic anemia. 

Reason: Lead inhibits ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase in the heme synthesis pathway, causing basophilic stippling and microcytic anemia. Von Gierke disease affects glycogen metabolism, not heme synthesis, so it’s incorrect.
WRONG
No — the picture and labs fit lead poisoning. Lead inhibits enzymes in the heme‑synthesis pathway (ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase), producing microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling and neurovisceral symptoms. Diseases that involve the same pathway include the porphyrias (eg, acute intermittent porphyria, porphyria cutanea tarda) and sideroblastic anemias (eg, X‑linked sideroblastic anemia), which are all disorders of heme synthesis.
WRONG
Porphyria cutanea tarda — correct. 

This child’s findings (abdominal pain, cognitive changes, foot drop, home renovation exposure, microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling) point to lead poisoning, which inhibits δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and ferrochelatase in the heme‑synthesis pathway. Porphyria cutanea tarda is a porphyria (uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency) affecting the same heme biosynthesis pathway, so it involves the same metabolic pathway as lead poisoning.
CORRECT
Chlamydial cervicitis (Chlamydia trachomatis infection) — presents with postcoital bleeding, blood-tinged/mucopurulent discharge and a friable, tender cervix on exam; common in sexually active women.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Chlamydial cervicitis (nongonococcal cervicitis).

Reasoning: Postcoital pain and blood‑tinged/mucopurulent discharge with a friable cervix that bleeds on swab are classic for cervicitis from sexually transmitted organisms, most commonly Chlamydia trachomatis in young women. Cervical motion tenderness reflects cervical inflammation/early ascending infection. Early pregnancy is less likely because she has ongoing contraception, would usually present with missed menses/positive hCG and would not typically produce a friable, mucopurulent cervix.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: pelvic inflammatory disease (an ascending STI—eg, chlamydia or gonorrhea causing cervicitis with upper tract involvement).

Reasoning: cervical motion tenderness on bimanual exam is the hallmark sign of PID (indicating uterine/adnexal involvement), not isolated cervicitis. Contact bleeding/cervical friability and recent unprotected sex with a new partner point to an STI that has ascended; a normal Pap one year ago makes cervical cancer unlikely.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: chlamydial cervicitis (mucopurulent cervicitis from Chlamydia trachomatis; gonorrhea can present similarly but chlamydia is more common).

Reasoning: acute postcoital bleeding and blood-tinged/mucopurulent discharge with a friable cervix that bleeds on swab are classic for infectious cervicitis. Cervical motion tenderness and recent unprotected intercourse increase likelihood of sexually transmitted infection. Cervical cancer is less likely given the acute 2‑week course and a normal Pap one year ago; trichomonas or BV can cause discharge but not the friable, bleeding cervix. Confirm with NAAT testing (and treat empirically for chlamydia and gonorrhea per guidelines while awaiting results).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Chlamydial cervicitis (possibly early PID).

Reasoning: The exam shows a friable, bleeding cervix with cervical motion tenderness and postcoital bleeding — classic for an STI causing cervicitis (Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause in this age group). Early intrauterine pregnancy would typically present with amenorrhea or positive pregnancy test and usually does not cause a friable, tender cervix with mucopurulent/contact bleeding. Gonorrhea can present similarly, but chlamydia is more common.
CORRECT
A generalized tonic-clonic seizure (likely provoked by alcohol withdrawal) with postictal focal weakness (Todd paralysis) due to transient suppression of the right motor cortex producing left-arm paralysis.
CORRECT
Most likely a seizure with postictal (Todd) paralysis from right cerebral cortical involvement.

Reasoning: Found unconscious with prolonged confusion/orientation only to person, diffuse muscle pain and fatigue (postictal myalgias), a fall-related shoulder bruise, slurred speech, and a focal unilateral deficit (left-arm weakness) that is transient — all classic for a tonic‑clonic seizure followed by focal postictal weakness (Todd paralysis). Normal head CT and LVH on ECG make acute hemorrhagic stroke or cardiac syncope less likely explanations for the focal neurologic deficit.
CORRECT
Most likely: a recent seizure with transient postictal (Todd) paralysis of the left arm from temporary dysfunction of the right motor cortex.

Reasoning: he was found unconscious with a postictal picture (confusion, amnesia for the event, diffuse muscle pain and fatigue), a small shoulder bruise consistent with a fall, chronic alcohol use (predisposes to seizures), a focal isolated left-arm weakness (classic for Todd paralysis after a focal/generalized convulsion), and a normal head CT (seizure/Todd paralysis often show no acute imaging abnormality). Stroke is less likely because the deficits and global symptoms fit a postictal state and the focal arm weakness of Todd paralysis is typically transient.
CORRECT
Most likely a seizure — a focal motor seizure with postictal (Todd) paralysis from transient neuronal exhaustion of the right motor cortex.

Reasoning: found unconscious with postictal confusion and amnesia, diffuse headache/myalgias and fatigue (common after a generalized convulsion), a fall with a shoulder bruise, and a new focal 1/5 weakness in the left arm consistent with Todd paralysis (transient focal weakness contralateral to the seizure focus). Normal CT supports a transient functional postictal cause rather than a new infarct.
CORRECT
Yes — a seizure is most likely. 

Reasoning: the prolonged confusion and amnesia (postictal state), diffuse headache and myalgias, fall with a shoulder bruise, and a focal 1/5 left-arm weakness that is transiently present are classic for a seizure with postictal (Todd) paralysis. Alcohol use increases seizure risk. Cardiac arrhythmia–related syncope usually causes a brief loss of consciousness with rapid recovery and would not explain a protracted confused state or a focal postictal deficit.
CORRECT
Most likely a ruptured hemorrhagic ovarian cyst (e.g., bleeding into a corpus luteum cyst) — ultrasound internal echoes = blood/clot, free fluid in the pouch of Douglas = hemoperitoneum from rupture; preserved vascular walls argues against torsion.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: a hemorrhagic corpus luteum cyst (ruptured), not a simple follicular cyst.

Reasoning: the ultrasound shows a cyst with internal echoes (blood/clot) and a thick, hyper‑echogenic vascular wall (“ring of fire” on Doppler) with a small pouch‑of‑Douglas fluid collection—classic for a bleeding/ruptured corpus luteum. Follicular cysts are usually thin‑walled and purely anechoic and less likely to have peripheral vascularity or intraperitoneal blood.
CORRECT
Most likely a ruptured hemorrhagic corpus luteum cyst (a hemorrhagic functional ovarian cyst) causing a small hemoperitoneum.

Reasoning: a large cyst with increased internal echoes indicates intralesional blood, the hyperechoic vascular “ring of fire” on Doppler is characteristic of a corpus luteum, and the small fluid collection in the pouch of Douglas plus sudden severe pain on presentation are classic for cyst rupture with mild hemoperitoneum. Findings and Doppler hypervascularity argue against torsion or a dermoid/endometrioma.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: ruptured hemorrhagic corpus luteum cyst (ovarian cyst with hemoperitoneum).

Reasoning: patient is an adolescent with regular ovulatory cycles, ultrasound shows a 10 cm cyst with increased internal echoes (blood/clot) and hypervascular (the “ring of fire”) cyst wall typical of a corpus luteum, and the small fluid in the pouch of Douglas plus sudden severe pain two weeks later is consistent with rupture/bleed. Findings are less consistent with torsion (would have reduced flow and severe constant pain) or a dermoid (often complex echogenic elements).
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: ruptured hemorrhagic corpus luteum cyst.

Reasoning: The ultrasound description—large simple cyst with increased internal echoes (blood/clot) and hyperechogenic, vascularized wall (“ring of fire” appearance on Doppler)—plus a small intraperitoneal collection and sudden severe pain are classic for a corpus luteum that has bled and partially ruptured. Follicular cysts are usually thin‑walled, purely anechoic, less vascular, and less likely to present with acute hemorrhage/hemoperitoneum.
CORRECT
Acalculous cholecystitis.

Reason: critically ill postoperative patient on prolonged NPO/TPN with fever, RUQ pain, leukocytosis and modest cholestatic LFT abnormalities — a classic setting for acute acalculous cholecystitis (gallbladder ischemia/stasis and inflammation without stones) rather than typical choledocholithiasis/ascending cholangitis.
CORRECT
Most likely acute acalculous cholecystitis.

Reasoning: A critically ill, postoperative patient on total parenteral nutrition with fever, RUQ tenderness, leukocytosis, jaundice and mildly abnormal LFTs is classic for acalculous cholecystitis. The timing (days after surgery/TPN), RUQ exam findings and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia point to a biliary/ inflammatory hepatobiliary process rather than a hemolytic transfusion reaction, which typically causes predominant indirect hyperbilirubinemia, hemoglobinuria and other hemolysis signs and usually presents earlier.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acalculous cholecystitis.

Reasoning: This is a critically ill, recently operated patient on TPN who developed fever, RUQ tenderness, leukocytosis and jaundice — the classic setting for acalculous cholecystitis (occurs in postoperative/ICU patients with biliary stasis and ischemia). Amylase is normal (argues against pancreatitis). Acute ascending cholangitis is less likely because there’s no prior biliary obstruction history and the pattern of enzymes (only mild alkaline phosphatase/bilirubin rise, modest transaminase elevation) and the setting favor an inflammatory gallbladder process from stasis/ischemia rather than an obstructing CBD stone or transfusion-related hepatitis.
CORRECT
Most likely acalculous cholecystitis.

Reasoning: a critically ill postop patient on total parenteral nutrition with fever, RUQ tenderness, leukocytosis and mild cholestatic LFT abnormalities is classic for acalculous cholecystitis. Risk factors here (recent major surgery, TPN, prolonged hospitalization) favor it over ascending cholangitis (would expect more marked obstructive labs and a history of biliary obstruction) or catheter-related bacteremia (would not explain focal RUQ tenderness). Ultrasound (wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, sonographic Murphy sign) or HIDA can confirm.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acalculous cholecystitis.

Reasoning: He is a recent postoperative, critically ill patient on TPN — classic risk factors. Presentation with fever, RUQ tenderness, leukocytosis and a cholestatic pattern (↑alk phos, ↑direct bilirubin) with jaundice fits acalculous cholecystitis/acute gallbladder inflammation. 

Why not hemolytic transfusion reaction: acute hemolytic reactions occur during/within hours of transfusion; delayed hemolysis (days–weeks) causes predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and falling hemoglobin with positive direct Coombs — not the conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and RUQ tenderness seen here.
CORRECT
Acute delirium (an acute confusional state) — likely delirium from a medical/ infectious cause (postop cholangitis/sepsis or medication-related encephalopathy). 

Rationale: acute onset disorientation, inattention, fluctuating consciousness, visual hallucinations (seeing flies), autonomic signs (tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever) and psychomotor agitation point to delirium rather than a primary psychiatric disorder.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: delirium tremens (severe alcohol withdrawal).

Reasoning: the timing (48–96 hours post-op), marked autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, fever), agitation/psychomotor restlessness, disorientation to place/time, and visual hallucinations (flies) are classic for DT. Next steps: ask about recent heavy alcohol use and start benzodiazepines and supportive care while monitoring vitals and electrolytes.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: acute (hyperactive) delirium — an acute confusional state.

Reasoning: abrupt postoperative onset of inattention/disorientation (oriented to person only), psychomotor agitation/akathisia (unable to sit still, pacing), visual/perceptual disturbance (complaint about garbage/flies), autonomic signs (tachycardia, diaphoresis), and mild fever. This pattern fits hyperactive delirium rather than recurrent cholangitis (which would cause focal RUQ pain, jaundice, higher fevers/sepsis signs) or anticholinergic/serotonin syndromes (skin is sweaty, not dry; no hyperreflexia/clonus described). Common precipitants here include infection, medications/antibiotic encephalopathy, metabolic disturbance, or withdrawal.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: acute delirium (acute confusional state) — probably infection/sepsis‑related.

Reasoning: She has acute onset cognitive disturbance with inattention, disorientation to place/time, psychomotor agitation (unable to sit still), visual misperception/hallucinatory behavior (complaint about garbage/flies), autonomic signs (tachycardia, sweating) and low‑grade fever in the setting of recent cholangitis/post‑op illness. These features fit delirium rather than primary psychiatric illness; medication neurotoxicity or alcohol withdrawal could mimic it but the infectious context makes delirium from systemic illness most likely.
WRONG
Delirium tremens.

Reasoning: The timing (3 days post-op), marked autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis), severe agitation and inability to stay still, disorientation, and apparent visual hallucination (flies) are classic for alcohol withdrawal progressing to delirium tremens (typically 48–96 hours after last drink). Management is urgent benzodiazepines, thiamine, fluids, and close monitoring.
CORRECT
Hemophilia A — congenital factor VIII deficiency (X-linked). Findings: normal PT, prolonged PTT (intrinsic pathway), normal ristocetin (platelet/vWF function intact), and correction with addition of factor VIII — consistent with hemophilia A causing hemarthroses.
CORRECT
Diagnosis: Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency).

Reasoning: Isolated prolonged PTT with normal PT and normal ristocetin/bleeding time points to an intrinsic coagulation factor defect, not a platelet adhesion disorder. The knee hemarthrosis and X‑linked family bleeding history fit hemophilia A, and the abnormality is specifically corrected by adding factor VIII (but not by adding factors IX or XI), confirming factor VIII deficiency. Bernard–Soulier is incorrect because it causes an abnormal ristocetin assay and prolonged bleeding time, which this patient does not have.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency).

Reason: Isolated prolonged PTT with normal PT and normal ristocetin assay indicates an intrinsic-pathway clotting factor problem rather than platelet/vWF dysfunction. The abnormality corrects when factor VIII is added (but not with IX or XI), and the history — a boy with family bleeding tendency and hemarthrosis after minor trauma — fits X‑linked hemophilia A. (The only important mimic is vWD type 2N, which can lower factor VIII levels, but the clinical/laboratory pattern here points to hemophilia A.)
CORRECT
Yes — Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency). 

Reason: isolated prolonged PTT with normal PT points to an intrinsic-pathway factor problem. Normal ristocetin rules out von Willebrand disease/platelet dysfunction. The abnormality is specifically corrected by adding factor VIII (and not by IX or XI), and the X-linked family history and hemarthrosis after minor trauma are classic for hemophilia A.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency).

Reasoning: male child with family history of bleeding, isolated prolonged PTT with normal PT, and the abnormality is corrected by adding factor VIII — all point to factor VIII deficiency. Bernard–Soulier is a platelet adhesion defect (GPIb deficiency) that produces prolonged bleeding time and an abnormal ristocetin assay; here the ristocetin test is normal and coagulation times (PT/PTT) in platelet disorders are usually normal, so Bernard–Soulier does not fit.
CORRECT
IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) — episodic painless hematuria with RBC casts occurring days after a mucosal/URTI fits IgA immune-complex deposition in the glomerular mesangium.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Goodpasture syndrome (anti–glomerular basement membrane disease).

Reasoning: The combination of pulmonary symptoms (dry cough/likely alveolar hemorrhage) and glomerulonephritis with RBC casts — especially after a recent respiratory infection — is classic for anti‑GBM disease causing a pulmonary‑renal syndrome. Anti‑GBM antibodies produce linear IgG/C3 deposition along basement membranes. Microscopic polyangiitis can give a similar picture but is ANCA‑associated (p‑ANCA/MPO) and lacks the linear anti‑GBM immunofluorescence.
WRONG
Most likely diagnosis: Goodpasture syndrome (anti–glomerular basement membrane disease).

Reasoning: The combination of new pulmonary symptoms (dry cough/coarse breath sounds suggesting alveolar hemorrhage) and nephritic urine with numerous RBC casts indicates a pulmonary–renal syndrome from glomerulonephritis. Anti‑GBM disease classically affects middle‑aged men, can be triggered by a preceding respiratory infection, and produces rapidly progressive GN with hematuria and pulmonary hemorrhage. Transitional cell carcinoma causes painless hematuria but would not produce RBC casts or pulmonary findings. Confirm with anti‑GBM antibodies and linear IgG/C3 on renal biopsy; treat with plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.
WRONG
No — the correct diagnosis is Goodpasture syndrome (anti–glomerular basement membrane disease).

Reasoning: RBC casts and hematuria indicate glomerulonephritis (not a lower urinary tract source like bladder cancer). The accompanying pulmonary symptoms (cough, diffuse coarse breath sounds/likely alveolar hemorrhage) plus recent respiratory illness point to a pulmonary–renal syndrome. Anti‑GBM disease classically causes rapidly progressive GN with pulmonary hemorrhage; diagnosis with anti‑GBM antibodies/linear IgG on biopsy and treated with plasmapheresis + immunosuppression.
WRONG
Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: The RBC casts and proteinuria indicate glomerulonephritis, and the respiratory symptoms point to concurrent pulmonary involvement — a pulmonary‑renal syndrome typical of small‑vessel vasculitis. MPA causes pauci‑immune rapidly progressive GN and pulmonary capillaritis (often p‑ANCA/MPO‑ANCA positive). Transitional cell carcinoma would give painless gross hematuria but not RBC casts or accompanying lung disease; anti‑GBM (Goodpasture) is another pulmonary‑renal mimic but is distinguished by anti‑GBM antibodies and linear IF rather than p‑ANCA/pauci‑immune findings.
CORRECT
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (obstetric cholestasis). Classic late‑pregnancy generalized pruritus without rash, elevated serum bile acids and mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with only modest ALT/AST increases fit this diagnosis.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP).

Reasoning: Pruritus in the third trimester with no rash, markedly elevated serum bile acids, mild transaminase elevations, mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, normal abdominal ultrasound and coagulation — all fit ICP. Viral hepatitis is less likely because transaminases are only mildly elevated (viral hepatitis typically causes much higher AST/ALT) and the timing/history are not typical.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP).

Reasoning: Pruritus late in pregnancy with no rash, markedly elevated serum bile acids (15 μmol/L; diagnostic cutoff ≈10), predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and only mild transaminase elevation with normal platelets/coagulation and a normal RUQ ultrasound (no obstructing lesion) is classic for ICP. Other entities (AFLP, HELLP, viral hepatitis, extrahepatic obstruction) are unlikely given the normal coagulation/platelet count, lack of hemolysis or severe transaminitis, and normal imaging.
CORRECT
The most likely diagnosis is intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP).

Reasoning: Classic third-trimester onset of intense pruritus without rash, mild scleral icterus, and an elevated serum bile acid level (15 µmol/L, >10 diagnostic threshold) with only mild transaminase elevations. Normal platelets, PT, and peripheral smear make HELLP, acute fatty liver of pregnancy, and hemolytic processes unlikely; normal RUQ ultrasound and absence of biliary pain argue against obstructive gallstone disease.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (obstetric cholestasis).

Reasoning: Classic third‑trimester generalized pruritus without rash, mild jaundice, and a modest cholestatic LFT pattern with elevated serum bile acids (15 μmol/L; >10 is diagnostic) point to ICP. AST/ALT are only mildly elevated and PT/platelets are normal, whereas acute hepatitis A would usually have much higher transaminases, systemic symptoms, and an incubation period of 15–50 days (travel 3 months ago makes HAV unlikely).
CORRECT
The tracing shows benign early repolarization — J‑point notching/jutting with diffuse, concave ST‑segment elevation (especially precordial leads) without reciprocal changes. This is a normal variant seen in young healthy/athletic individuals and requires no acute treatment.
WRONG
Correct — this tracing is most consistent with first‑degree AV block. The PR interval is uniformly prolonged (>200 ms) with each P wave followed by a QRS (no dropped beats), a pattern often seen as a benign finding from increased vagal tone in young athletes.
CORRECT
Conclusion: This ECG is most consistent with second-degree AV block — Mobitz I (Wenckebach), not third‑degree (complete) heart block.

Reasoning: In an otherwise healthy, asymptomatic young athlete, increased vagal tone commonly produces sinus bradycardia and Mobitz I AV block — characterized by progressive PR-interval prolongation followed by a dropped beat and grouped beating with a narrow QRS. In contrast, third-degree AV block shows complete AV dissociation with independent atrial and ventricular rates (no progressive PR prolongation), usually produces symptoms and is not typical in an asymptomatic athletic patient. Management is conservative if asymptomatic.
WRONG
No — this tracing is most consistent with sinus bradycardia from athletic conditioning (increased vagal tone). Reason: there are P waves before every QRS with a regular (but slow) rhythm and no AV dissociation or dropped beats; in complete (third‑degree) heart block you would see AV dissociation with P waves marching through independent of the QRS.
WRONG
You are correct — this ECG is most consistent with first-degree AV block.  

Reason: the PR interval is uniformly prolonged (>200 ms) but every P wave is followed by a QRS (1:1 conduction) with a constant PR interval. There is no AV dissociation (which you would see in third‑degree block), nor are there dropped beats or progressive PR prolongation (which would suggest Mobitz I or II). In a young athlete this is often a benign finding from increased vagal tone.
CORRECT
Fat embolism syndrome from marrow fat (fat emboli) — classic after long‑bone/hip fracture and manipulation: acute respiratory distress, neurologic impairment, and petechial rash within 24–72 hours.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: fat embolism syndrome.

Reason: classic triad of hypoxemic respiratory failure, neurologic changes (drowsiness, confusion), and petechial rash occurring within 24–72 hours of long‑bone fracture/orthopedic surgery. Fever, tachycardia, and mild thrombocytopenia support this diagnosis. Thyroid storm would not explain the petechial rash or the typical timing after a femoral fracture/surgery.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: Fat embolism syndrome.

Reasoning: After a recent femoral fracture and orthopedic manipulation she has the classic triad — acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, neurologic changes (drowsiness/disorientation), and a petechial rash on the chest — plus fever and tachycardia. The timing after long‑bone injury/repair and the presence of petechiae and mild thrombocytopenia strongly favor fat embolism over a thrombotic pulmonary embolus, which rarely produces a petechial rash or prominent neurologic symptoms.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: fat embolism syndrome.

Reasoning: The classic triad—acute respiratory distress with hypoxemia, neurologic changes (drowsiness, confusion), and a petechial rash—occurs within 24–72 hours of long‑bone fracture or orthopedic manipulation (here a femoral neck fracture and prosthesis). Fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and a mild thrombocytopenia are also typical. Massive thromboembolic PE is less likely because it usually lacks the petechial rash and prominent neurologic symptoms seen here and typically has a different timing and risk profile.
CORRECT
Most likely diagnosis: fat embolism syndrome.

Reasoning: the classic triad—respiratory distress with hypoxemia, neurological impairment (drowsiness, confusion), and petechial rash—occurs 24–72 hours after long‑bone fracture or orthopedic manipulation (here a femoral neck fracture and hip surgery). Tachycardia and fever are typical. Thyroid storm is unlikely without a history of hyperthyroidism or the other autonomic/GI features of thyrotoxicosis and would not explain the characteristic petechial rash.
CORRECT

CORRECT

Reasoning: age and exam (slightly enlarged, smooth, nontender prostate), classic obstructive LUTS (weak stream, nocturia, daytime frequency), and recurrent cystitis in a man (suggesting incomplete emptying) all point to BPH.
